THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company, Respondent,
        v.
        South Carolina Bank and Trust f/k/a First National Bank, Michael G. Lee and Cheri B. Lee, Defendants, 
        Of whom Cheri B. Lee is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â OlinÂ  D.Â  Burgdorf, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-051
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 7, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Heath Preston Taylor, of West Columbia, for Appellant.
        G.D. Morgan, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this declaratory judgment action, Cheri B. Lee appeals the masterâ€™s holding that she was not entitled to recover insurance proceeds under a homeowners policy issued by South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company (Farm Bureau) because the fire that damaged the home was intentionally set by Michael Lee, a named co-insured.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This case was tried on stipulated facts agreed to by the parties, and the salient facts follow.Â  Michael and Cheri Lee resided at 3470 Timberline Drive in Orangeburg (the insured residence).Â  Farm Bureau insured the residence under a homeownerâ€™s policy listing both Michael and Cheri Lee as named insureds.Â  Under the definitions section of the policy, â€œyouâ€ and â€œyourâ€ refer to the â€œnamed insuredâ€ and the spouse, if the spouse is a resident of the same household.Â  The policy contained the following exclusions:

  We do not insure for loss caused directly or indirectly by any of the following.Â  Such loss is excluded regardless of any other cause or event contributing concurrently or in any sequence to the loss.
  Intentional loss, meaning any loss arising out of any act committed:
  a.  By or at the direction of any insureds; or
  b. With the intent to cause a loss; or
  c.  In a domestic dispute between insureds, family members, or others

Under Conditions, the policy provides as follows:

  Intentional Loss.Â  If you or any person insured under this policy causes or procures a loss of property covered under this policy for the purpose of obtaining insurance benefits, then the policy is void and we will not pay you or any other insured for this loss.
  Concealment or Fraud.Â  If you or any other insured under this policy has intentionally concealed or misrepresented any material fact of circumstance, or made false statements or engaged in fraudulent conduct relating to this insurance, whether before or after a loss, then this policy is void to you and any other insured.

On October 8 and 15, 2001, Mr. Lee intentionally set fire to two homes in the Orangeburg area, neither of which was the insured residence.Â  Then, on November 4, 2001, law enforcement officers observed Mr. Lee intentionally setting fire to the insured residence.Â  Mr. Lee was subsequently arrested in conjunction with all three intentional fires.Â  On November 30, 2001, Mr. Lee was released on bond subject to electronic monitoring.[2] Â While Mr. Lee was out on bond, the insured residence was again intentionally set on fire on December 12, 2001.Â  At the time of this fire, the electronic monitoring devices on Mr. Leeâ€™s leg and in his residence had been tampered with and disabled.Â  Mr. Lee was arrested and charged in connection with this fire.Â  
Mr. Lee pled guilty to the intentional fire at the insured residence on November 4, 2001, as well as the two intentional fires in October 2001.Â  As a result of his guilty pleas to the three prior fires, the charge for the December 12, 2001 fire at the insured residence was nolle prossed.Â  Mr. Lee received fifteen years confinement for arson.Â  Farm Bureau admitted Cheri Lee was not involved in the intentional setting of any of Mr. Leeâ€™s fires.Â  
Farm Bureau filed a declaratory judgment action seeking an order from the trial court declaring that Farm Bureau does not owe any proceeds under the insurance policy on the insured residence to either Michael or Cheri Lee.Â  Ms. Lee counterclaimed for coverage under the policy, arguing she was an innocent co-insured.[3]Â  The matter was referred to a master-in-equity who denied coverage to Ms. Lee on the grounds that the policy precluded any recovery because the other named insured, Michael Lee, intentionally set fire to the insured residence on December 12, 2001.Â  Ms. Lee filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion requesting the master to rule on whether Farm Bureau had proven Mr. Leeâ€™s motive in setting the fire of December 12 as required in a civil arson action under Carter v. American Mutual Fire Ins. Co., 297 S.C. 218, 220, 375 S.E.2d 356, 357 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The master issued an amended order finding, in addition to what was contained in the first order, that even if motive was required, Farm Bureau had met its burden and proved all the elements of civil arson.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Declaratory judgment actions are neither legal nor equitable; therefore, the standard of review depends on the nature of the underlying issues. Â Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 279, 580 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  When the purpose of the underlying dispute is to determine whether coverage exists under an insurance policy, the action is one at law. Â Horry County v. Ins. Reserve Fund, 344 S.C. 493, 497, 544 S.E.2d 637, 639-40 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, findings of fact of the trial judge will not be disturbed on appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assoc. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  When an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate court is free to determine if the trial judge properly applied the law to the facts. Â In re Estate of Boynton, 355 S.C. 299, 301, 584 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In such a situation, the appellate court does not have to defer to the trial judgeâ€™s findings. Â Id. at 301-02, 584 S.E.2d at 155.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Cheri Lee argues that as an innocent co-insured she was entitled to receive the insurance proceeds from her policy with Farm Bureau.Â  Specifically, she alleges the trial court erred in holding that she was not entitled to recover insurance proceeds because Farm Bureau failed to satisfy the elements of civil arson as set forth in Brown v. Allstate Ins. Co., 344 S.C. 21, 25, 452 S.E.2d 723, 725 (2001), and Carter v. American Mutual Fire Ins. Co., 297 S.C. 218, 220, 375 S.E.2d 356, 357 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  On appeal, Ms. Lee concedes the record contains ample evidence that the fire was of incendiary origin, and that Michael Lee had the opportunity to start the fire of December 12; accordingly, she only contends the trial court erred in finding Farm Bureau established motive.[4]Â  We disagree.
In this matter, Farm Bureau was not required to prove the motive of Michael Lee because Farm Bureau did not rely on the common law defense of civil arson; rather, Farm Bureau relied on the specific policy exclusion contained in Michael and Cheri Leeâ€™s homeownerâ€™s policy to deny coverage.Â  As a result, the cases relied upon by Ms. Lee are inapplicable to this situation.Â  Brown and Carter only addressed the common law defense of civil arson; neither based a decision upon the insurance policyâ€™s intentional loss exclusion or the fraud and concealment exclusion that Farm Bureau relied upon in this action.[5]Â  
Accordingly, we find South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Kelly, 345 S.C. 232, 547 S.E.2d 871 (Ct. App. 2001), controlling in this matter.Â  In Kelly, the named insuredâ€™s son set a series of three fires at the insured residence causing significant damage to the home.Â  Id. at 235, 547 S.E.2d at 873.Â  Farm Bureau paid over $100,000 in insurance proceeds to the father after the first two fires, but after the third fire, the son admitted to intentionally setting all three fires.Â  Id.Â  Thereafter, Farm Bureau filed an action to recover the proceeds paid to father.Â  Id.Â  The father argued that even though his son was a named insured under the policy the father, as an innocent co-insured, should be allowed to recover under the policy.Â  Id. at 239, 547 S.E.2d at 875.Â  This court relied solely on the policy language to deny coverage to father even though he was an innocent co-insured.Â  Id.Â  The policy in Kelly denied coverage for any act committed by or at the direction of any insured with the intent to cause a loss.Â  It also provided that if a named insured or any person under the policy caused or procured a loss to the property, then the policy was void.Â  The policy also contained a concealment or fraud provision that could void the policy.Â  The language used in the Kelly policy is identical to the language in this action.Â  Therefore, Ms. Leeâ€™s status as an innocent co-insured is immaterial, and the trial court properly found Ms. Lee was not entitled to recover under the Farm Bureau policy on the insured residence.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the trial court finding Cheri Lee is not entitled to any insurance proceeds is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ.,Â  concur,

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] An electronic transmitter was placed on Mr. Leeâ€™s leg, and an electronic receiver was installed at his current residence.Â  
[3] Mr. Lee neither filed a claim with Farm Bureau for proceeds nor did he counterclaim for coverage.
[4] Our courts have held that in order to deny coverage based on the common law defense of civil arson, an insurance company must prove that the fire was of an incendiary origin, as well as that the party had the opportunity and motive to set the fire.Â  Brown, 344 S.C. at 25, 452 S.E.2d at 725; Carter, 297 S.C. at 220, 375 S.E.2d at 357.Â  
[5] Moreover, even if Farm Bureau relied on the common law defense of civil arson, sufficient evidence of motive exists to support the finding of the trial court.Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDINGÂ Â  EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Steven David Frazier, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-052Â 
Heard January 9, 2007 â€“ Filed February 7, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe , all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Steven David Frazier appeals his conviction for involuntary manslaughter, arguing the trial court erred in not giving the full jury charge on proximate cause when the jury requested to hear the charge again. Frazier also contends the trial courtâ€™s recharge was a charge on the facts.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On the evening of November 21, 2001, Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Deputy Kevin Lewis was dispatched to 35 Emma Street in Greenville, where he met the victim, James Williams.Â  Williams informed Deputy Lewis that he went to the location to visit his ailing aunt.Â  As he approached the house, Frazier, a distant cousin, met him on the porch.Â  Frazier, apparently upset because of some past comment Williams made regarding Frazierâ€™s mother, grabbed and shook Williams, threw him off the porch, and then drove away from the scene. 
Lewis noticed Williams was visibly upset and had a one-inch bruise on the right side of his head, a cut on his left index finger, and a cut behind his left knee.Â  Williams also complained of soreness in both his left shoulder and ankle and stated he sustained his injuries when he was thrown from the porch.Â  Although an ambulance soon arrived, Williams declined to leave and said he would go to the hospital on his own. 
Lewis prepared a report of the incident and labeled it as a simple assault and battery.Â  Because Lewis did not see any initial aggravating circumstances, he advised Williams to follow up with the magistrateâ€™s office and gave him the necessary paperwork.
At the hospital, nurse Nika Fowler examined Williams.Â  Fowler noticed abrasions to Williamsâ€™s chest, posterior, knee, and head.Â  Williams also complained of pain in his left shoulder and right thumb.Â  In her notes, Fowler recorded that Williams weighed 250 pounds, had a prior heart valve replacement, and was taking Lipitor and Coumadin, a blood-thinning medication.Â  The hospital discharged Williams several hours later, and he left without assistance.Â  
On November 28, Williams complained about excruciating leg pain and had his brother take him to the emergency room.Â  Although Williams did not seem to be doing any better, the hospital released him.Â  
The next day, Williams, while at home, complained of a severe headache and again asked his brother to take him to the hospital.Â  When the brother arrived at the house, however, Williams could not move because his left leg was numb and ended up calling an ambulance to transport him.Â  At the hospital, doctors discovered Williams had a subdural hemorrhage over the right side of his brain.Â  Williams had surgery to relieve the pressure on his brain, but died December 2, 2001.Â  Dr. Michael Ward, Chief Medical Examiner for Greenville County, opined the cause of death was complications of blunt force trauma to the head, with subdural hemorrhage and cerebral hypoxia.
Frazier was subsequently charged with involuntary manslaughter.Â  At trial, Frazier claimed the doctorsâ€™ gross negligence in failing to earlier diagnose Williamsâ€™s subdural hemotoma was an intervening cause of his death.Â  During the hearing, the defense presented evidence that Williamsâ€™s estate had filed a malpractice suit against the hospital and several members of its medical staff.
The trial courtâ€™s charge to the jury provided in pertinent part as follows:

  Now, ladies and gentlemen, our law recognizes that there may be more than one proximate cause.Â  The act of two or more persons may combine and concur together as a proximate cause [of] the death of a person.Â  
  A defendantâ€™s act may be regarded as the proximate cause if it [is] a contributing cause of the death of the deceased.Â  A defendantâ€™s act need not be the sole cause of the death, provided that it be a proximate cause contributing to the death of the deceased.Â  
  I charge you that it is not a defense to show that the deceased might have recovered had he been treated according to the most approved surgical or medical standard or as a reasonably prudent physician would have treated in the case.Â  
  If, however, the death was caused not by the injury that the deceased received, but was caused by erroneous medical care; that is, where the medical treatment was so gross that it was the cause of the death, then this defendant would not be guilty of involuntary manslaughter.Â  
  Ladies and gentlemen, the fact that other causes contributed to the death would not relieve this defendant of responsibility.Â  If the conduct of this defendant contributed mediately or immediately to the death of the alleged victim in this case he would be responsible.Â  
  In other words, the acts or conduct of this defendant must be only a proximate cause of the death.Â  It need not be the direct, immediate or sole cause.Â  It is sufficient if the cause of death resulted naturally from the acts or conduct of this defendant, as, for example, and only for example, where the direct cause of death was a disease, infection or condition caused by or resulting from the conduct of the defendant.Â  Proximate cause means the real cause, the efficient cause, without which the event in question would not have occurred. 

Neither side objected to the trial courtâ€™s initial jury instructions. 
During deliberations, the jury requested a recharge on â€œcircumstantial evidence and the rule of proximate cause as it relate[d] to the verdict.â€Â  The trial court recharged the jury as follows:

  With respect to proximate cause, ladies and gentlemen, the fact that other causes contributed to the death of the deceased in this case would not relieve this defendant from responsibility.Â  If his conduct contributed mediately or immediately to the death of the alleged victim, then he would be guilty. 
  Â In other words, our law recognizes that there may be more than one proximate cause.Â  The act of two or more persons may combine and concur together as a proximate result of the cause of death of a person.Â  
  Now, the defendantâ€™s act may be regarded as a proximate cause if it is a contributing cause of the death of the decedent.Â  A defendantâ€™s act need not be the sole cause of death, provided, of course, that it be a proximate cause contributing to the death of the decedent.Â  

The trial court then asked if the recharge aided the jury in its deliberations, and the jury foreman responded, â€œ[Y]es, sir.â€Â  The trial court then recharged the jury on circumstantial evidence.Â  After the trial court finished, defense counsel objected to the trial courtâ€™s recharge and requested that the trial court re-instruct the jury that â€œas far as that recklessness would relieve someone, would break the chain of proximate cause.â€Â  The trial court declined to charge the jury any further.Â  Counsel also objected unsuccessfully to what he contended was the trial courtâ€™s impermissible comments on the facts during the recharge.
After deliberating, the jury convicted Frazier of involuntary manslaughter.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  We disagree with Frazierâ€™s argument that, when the jury asked to be recharged on the issue of proximate cause, the trial court erred in refusing to repeat the instruction that if the jury found gross medical negligence caused Williamsâ€™s death, it could conclude that Frazier was not legally responsible. Â 
A trial court is required to â€œcharge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.â€[2]Â  A jury charge is deemed correct when the charge, read as a whole, adequately covers the applicable law.[3]Â  When a jury requests an additional charge, the trial court need only charge the parts of the initial charge necessary to answer the juryâ€™s request.[4]Â  Moreover, to warrant a reversal, the trial courtâ€™s â€œrefusal to give a requested charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial.â€[5]Â  
In the present case, the trial courtâ€™s initial jury charge contained a lengthy explanation of proximate cause.Â  In the charge, the trial court also explained the law regarding intervening medical gross negligence.Â  The charge included instructions that, if the jury found the medical treatment Williams received was â€œso gross that it was the cause of death,â€ Frazier would not be guilty.Â  When the jury requested a recharge, the jury foreman specifically asked only about the â€œrule of proximate causeâ€ and did not ask about intervening medical causation.Â  Furthermore, after the trial courtâ€™s recharge, the trial court asked if the reissued cause charge aided the jury, and the foreman responded in the affirmative.Â  
We therefore hold the trial courtâ€™s recharge was sufficient.Â  Here, the jury inquired about only proximate cause and, in response to the trial courtâ€™s inquiry, indicated it was satisfied with the recharge. Â In addition, because intervening medical causation was adequately covered by the first charge, we can discern no prejudice to Frazier.[6]Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in failing to recharge the jury on the law regarding intervening medical causation. 
2.Â  Next, Frazier argues the trial courtâ€™s recharge on proximate cause amounted to impermissible commentary on the facts of the case. Â Â We disagree.
The South Carolina Constitution provides, â€œJudges shall not charge the juries in respect to matters of fact, but shall declare the law.â€[7]Â  This provision mandates that the trial court â€œrefrain from all comment which tends to indicate . . . Â opinion as to the weight or sufficiency of evidence, the credibility of witnesses, the guilt of the accused, or as to the controverted facts.â€[8]Â  The rationale behind the constitutional provision is that our justice system is based on the notion that every person charged with a crime has an â€œabsolute right to a fair and impartial trial.â€[9]Â  Fundamental to the concept of a fair and impartial trial is the requirement of neutrality on the part of the trial court.[10]Â  
We hold the trial court, in recharging the jury, did not comment on the facts of the case.Â  Frazier points to the portion of the trial courtâ€™s recharge that provided as follows: Â â€œNow, the defendantâ€™s act may be regarded as a proximate cause if it is a contributing cause of the death of the decedent.Â  A defendantâ€™s act need not be the sole cause of death, provided . . . that it be a proximate cause contributing to the death of the decedent.â€Â  (emphasis added by Frazier).Â  The recharge does not reference any specific testimony or facts nor did the trial court inject any opinion as to the weight of the evidence against Frazier.Â  The trial court merely recharged the jury with the applicable law regarding proximate cause.Â  Â Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s recharge on proximate cause.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 450, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000).Â  
[3]Â  Id. (citing Keaton v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 448, 495-96, 514 S.E.2d 570, 574 (1999)).Â  
[4]Â  State v. Barksdale, 311 S.C. 210, 216, 428 S.E.2d 498, 502 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
[5]Â  Hughey, 339 S.C. at 450, 529 S.E.2d at 727 (citing Ellison v. Parts Distrib., Inc., 302 S.C. 299, 301, 395 S.E.2d 740, 741 (Ct. App. 1990)).Â  
[6]Â  See Â Rauch v. Zayas, 284 S.C. 594, 596, 327 S.E.2d 377, 378 (Ct. App. 1985) (noting a trial courtâ€™s â€œfailure to charge in greater detail is not error if the details were covered in the original chargeâ€).
[7]Â  S.C. Const. Art. V Â§ 21.Â  
[8]Â  State v. Kennedy, 272 S.C. 231, 234, 250 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1978) (citations omitted).Â  
[9]Â  Id.Â  
[10] Id.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
      Cracker Barrel Old Country Store, Inc., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        J.C. Faw, Appellant,
        Denny's Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-053
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed February 7, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Thomas L. Stephenson and Brian T. Price, both of Greenville, for Appellant.
        William B. Darwin, Jr. and Robert M. Barrett , both of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Cracker Barrel and J.C. Faw appeal from the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Dennyâ€™s, Inc., in which the court held a deed restriction prohibiting the use of the burdened property for any â€œfamily styleâ€ or â€œsit downâ€ restaurant prohibited Cracker Barrel from building and operating a restaurant on adjoining, unburdened property when the burdened property would be used for access to the restaurant. Â Â We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In June of 1992, Dennyâ€™s purchased a piece of property on Highway 290 in Spartanburg County from the Spartangreen Neighborhood Associates Group (SNAP) for construction and operation of a family style restaurant.Â  As part of this conveyance, SNAP imposed restrictive covenants in favor of Dennyâ€™s on remaining property along or near Highway 290.Â  The Declaration of Restrictive Covenants provided: â€œneither all nor any portion of the Burdened Property shall be used for any â€˜family style or sit-downâ€™ restaurant business.â€Â  The covenants did not prohibit the use of the property as a â€œfast-foodâ€ restaurant, employee cafeteria, vending machine food dispensary, or snack bar operated in connection with a convenience store.Â  
In January of 2001, J.C. Faw acquired from SNAP and the South Carolina Department of Transportation a 3.2 acre tract, which consisted of aÂ  portion of the burdened property, Parcel F, as well as two unburdened parcels, Parcels A and E.Â  The restricted property, Parcel F is a narrow strip bordering SpartanGreen Boulevard, a two-lane road providing access to Highway 290.Â  Faw subsequently entered into negotiations with Cracker Barrel for sale of the 3.2 acre tract.Â  It is undisputed that Cracker Barrel would build and operate a â€œfamily styleâ€ or â€œsit downâ€ restaurant on Parcels A and E.Â  The only means of access to this restaurant would be across Parcel F to SpartanGreen Boulevard.Â  Dennyâ€™s restaurant is across SpartanGreen Boulevard from the proposed Cracker Barrel restaurant site.Â  Â Â 
Cracker Barrel was aware of the restriction on Parcel F and recognized that if its title insurance company could not insure over the restricted parcel, it may have a deal breaker situation.Â  In an effort to evade the restriction, Faw and Cracker Barrel attempted to dedicate Parcel F to the County of Spartanburg.Â  The county declined the offer, but the Town of Duncan subsequently agreed to the dedication if the remainder of the property was annexed into the town.[1]Â  
In March of 2004, Cracker Barrel and Faw executed a real estate sale contract for the property.Â  The contract provided for a reduced acreage due to the proposed dedication to the Town of Duncan.Â  It also required Faw to remove the deed restriction within an allotted time.Â  When Dennyâ€™s learned of Cracker Barrelâ€™s plans, it raised its objections to the development of the restaurant and warned that it would seek legal action if the sales agreement continued. 
Cracker Barrel brought this declaratory judgment action in February of 2005 asking the court to find the restriction did not prevent Cracker Barrel from constructing its restaurant on the unrestricted property or using the property subject to the restriction in order to access SpartanGreen Boulevard.Â  Dennyâ€™s answered and asserted cross claims again Faw and the Town of Duncan seeking injunctive relief to uphold the restriction as well as actual and punitive damages against Faw.Â  Faw subsequently attempted to terminate the sales contract. 
Dennyâ€™s filed a motion for summary judgment, which the trial court granted.Â  The court noted Cracker Barrel could not operate the proposed restaurant without the use of Parcel F for access and this use violated the restriction.Â  It held deeding the property to the Town of Duncan or any other governmental entity would not eliminate the restriction, and thus would not nullify Cracker Barrelâ€™s prohibited use of the property.Â  In addition, the court found the equities in the case weighed overwhelmingly in favor of enforcing the restriction.Â  Thus, the court enjoined Faw from selling the property to Cracker Barrel, and declared that the deed restriction on Parcel F prohibits the use of the entire tract for a â€œsit downâ€ or family style restaurant.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
Cracker Barrel argues the trial court erred in enjoining the property for its restaurant.Â  We disagree.Â  
As restrictive covenants are contractual in nature, the paramount rule of construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the parties as determined from the whole document.Â  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 863-64 (1998).Â  The court in Taylor elucidated:

  The court may not limit a restriction in a deed, nor, on the other hand, will a restriction be enlarged or extended by construction or implication beyond the clear meaning of its terms even to accomplish what it may be thought the parties would have desired had a situation which later developed been foreseen by them at the time when the restriction was written.Â Â  It is still the settled rule in this jurisdiction that restrictions as to the use of real estate should be strictly construed and all doubts resolved in favor of free use of the property, subject, however, to the provision that this rule of strict construction should not be applied so as to defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the instrument.Â  

Id.Â  at 4, 498 S.E.2d at 864 (internal quotations and citations omitted).
In the present case, the language of the restriction is clear and unambiguous.Â  Thus, we must enforce the language of the restriction in accordance with its plain meaning.Â  See Heape v. Broxton, 293 S.C. 343, 345, 360 S.E.2d 157, 158 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œWhere the language used in a restrictive covenant is unambiguous, there is no room for construction and the language must be enforced in accordance with its plain meaning.â€).
The Texas Court of Civil Appeals addressed a similar issue in H. E. Butt Grocery Company v. Justice, 484 S.W.2d 628 (Tex. Civ. App. 1972).Â  In that case, a restrictive covenant made for the benefit of HEB prohibited â€œthe use of any portion thereof for the purpose of conducting thereon a food store or food department . . . .â€ Â Id. at 629. Â The plaintiffs sought to sell their land to a developer who would erect a grocery store on land not covered by the restriction but would use land in the restricted tract for parking, ingress, and egress.Â  The Texas court explained the purpose of the restriction â€œwas to prohibit the restricted tract from being used as any necessary part of a competing supermarket with HEB.â€Â  Id. at 630.Â  It found the proposed food store could not be conducted without the use of the restricted area as ingress and egress as well as parking and delivery or groceries to customersâ€™ cars were â€œessential to conducting the proposed food store, and all would take place on the restricted tract.â€ Id. at 630-31.Â  Thus, the court held the proposed use of the restricted tract was violative of the covenant.Â  Id. at 631.
The Florida District Court of Appeals, relying on the above case, found a restrictive covenant that prohibited the property from being used as a pharmacy prevented a Walgreenâ€™s Pharmacy from using the restricted property for parking, ingress, and egress to the store it sought to build on adjoining, unrestricted property. Eckerd Corp. v. Corners Group, Inc., 786 So.2d 588 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2000).Â  Â Â Â Â 
Similarly, the Colorado Court of Appeals held a restriction imposed by Burger King that provided the premises â€œwill not be used or be permitted to be used directly or indirectlyâ€ for a fast-food restaurant prevented a neighboring McDonaldâ€™s from using the property for parking and access.Â  Sawdey v. Kopas Corp., 495 P.2d 1153 (Colo. Ct. App. 1972).Â  The court found the language of the covenant was clear and unambiguous and forbid â€œthe use of the land for parking and access when such use is an incident to the prohibited use of the landâ€ as a fast-food restaurant.Â  Id. at 1154.Â  
Cracker Barrel relies on the Supreme Court of Nevadaâ€™s decision in Nevada Food King, Inc. v. Reno Press Brick Company, 400 P.2d 140 (Nev. 1965). In that case, Nevada Food King leased property for a grocery store and had the following provision included in the lease: â€œLessor shall not lease any property owned by it in that general vicinity for operation of a retail grocery, or meat market, nor shall itself operate the same.â€Â  Id. at 140.Â  The lessor sought to develop a shopping center which would include a supermarket on property adjacent to the property defined as the â€œgeneral vicinityâ€ in the lease.Â  The lessor sought a declaration that the proposed shopping center development would be provided with access through, and parking upon, property located with the â€œgeneral vicinityâ€ area.Â  Id.Â  The court found the covenant was silent as to parking and did not restrict assess to a supermarket located on adjacent property or parking thereon. Id. at 142.Â Â Â  Relying on the maxim â€œexpressio unius est exclusio alteriusâ€ â€“ the expression of one thing excludes others- the court held the restriction did not prohibit parking and access on the property.Â  Id.
In Nevada Food King, the restriction included the much narrower term â€œoperateâ€.Â  In contrast H. E. Butt and the other cases involved the broader term â€œuseâ€ and held that use of restricted land for access constituted a violation of covenants restricting property from use as certain businesses even though the buildings of the businesses were located on unrestricted properties.Â  We find these cases persuasive.Â  Â Â We hold the use of Parcel F for access to a Cracker Barrel is essential to the prohibited use of the land for a sit-down or family style restaurant.Â  As the trial court found, â€œParcel F would directly benefit the proposed Cracker Barrel restaurant by affording access to it, and would represent an integral and valuable part of the restaurantâ€™s business.â€Â  Such a use violates the plain meaning of the language of the restrictive covenant.Â  Accordingly, we rule the trial court did not err in concluding the restriction prevented Cracker Barrel from operating a â€œsit downâ€ or family style restaurant on Parcels A and/or E as Cracker Barrel would have no alternative but to use Parcel F for access to the restaurant.[2]Â  Â Â Â 
Cracker Barrel contends that when balancing the equities, the restrictive covenant should not be enforced.Â  

  The issuance of a mandatory injunction depends upon the equities between the parties, and it rests in the sound judicial discretion of the court whether such an injunction should be granted.Â  Where a great injury will be done to the defendant, with very little if any to the plaintiff, the courts will deny equitable relief.Â  

Hunnicutt v. Rickenbacker, 268 S.C. 511, 515-16, 234 S.E.2d 887, 889 (1977).Â  In Honnicutt, the court reversed a portion of an order that granted a mandatory injunction requiring the removal of a commercial building erected in violation of restrictive covenants.Â  Instead, it allowed the appellants the opportunity to convert the building to residential use to be in compliance with the restrictions.Â  Id. at 517, 234 S.E.2d at 890.Â  
In the present case, Cracker Barrel has not begun construction of its restaurant or even closed on the property.Â  The damages it would sustain due to enforcement of the restriction would be minimal.Â  In addition, Faw, the present owner of the property, would not be damaged.Â  Barry Bush, Fawâ€™s Director of Real Estate, testified the property was worth more than the $1,330,000 price set forth in the contract with Cracker Barrel.Â  Although Fawâ€™s property could not be used for a â€œfamily styleâ€ restaurant, it could be used for any other type of business.Â  
Cracker Barrel asserts the fact that since the restriction was filed the property lost access to Highway 290 pushes the equities substantially in its favor.Â  We disagree.Â  Dennyâ€™s bargained for the restriction to protect its business from similar competition.Â  This restriction included the land fronting SpartanGreen Boulevard known as Parcel F.Â  The proposed Cracker Barrel would be directly across SpartanGreen Boulevard from Dennyâ€™s restaurant with access across the restricted property.Â  Â If Cracker Barrel were allowed to use Parcel F for access, Dennyâ€™s would lose the benefit of the bargain it made when creating the restriction.Â  Cracker Barrel does not contend the restriction against competition is unreasonable and in fact included a similar restriction in its contract with Faw.Â  We agree with the trial court that the equities weigh in favor of enforcing the restriction.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the above stated reasons, the order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, concur.Â 

[1] On December 14, 2004, Faw executed a deed conveying Parcel F to the Town of Duncan.Â  The deed was not recorded and the Town agreed to give the property back if the Cracker Barrel contract could not close.Â  
[2] Cracker Barrel does not challenge the trial courtâ€™s ruling that deeding the property to the Town of Duncan or any other governmental entity would not eliminate the restriction.Â  Accordingly, that ruling is the law of the case.Â  See Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (stating an unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case and requires affirmance).Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Anne Galbreath-Jenkins, Appellant,
        v.
        Floyd Ronald Jenkins, Jr., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Tommy B. Edwards, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-054
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 7, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Margaret D. Fabri, of Charleston, for Appellant.Â  
        Anne Frances Bleecker, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Anne Galbreath-Jenkins (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding her in both civil and criminal contempt and failing to find Floyd Ronald Jenkins (Father) in civil contempt.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
The parties were married August 17, 1991 and have one child, born in 2002.Â  The parties separated on June 28, 2003.Â  They entered into a Separate Maintenance and Support Agreement, which was approved by the family court.Â  The agreement discussed custody and visitation and contemplated Motherâ€™s relocation from Charleston to Williamsburg, Virginia, to be near her family.Â  In the spring of 2004, Wife moved from Williamsburg to Orrâ€™s Island, Maine.Â  
In 2004, the parties began having trouble concerning visitation.Â  Most of the problems stemmed from Motherâ€™s refusal to allow Father overnight visitation with the child.Â  There were numerous instances where Father had traveled to Maine to see the child and was not allowed overnight visitation he believed he was entitled to.Â  
These disagreements led to Father filing a complaint in September 2004 seeking modification of the custody and visitation provisions of the final order. Â A temporary hearing was set for November 1, 2004.Â  On Fatherâ€™s petition, the family court also issued a rule to show cause ordering Mother to appear and show cause why she should not be held in contempt for failing to allow overnight visitation and for alienating the childâ€™s affections from Father.Â  The hearing was continued by consent.Â  
Prior to the temporary hearing, the parties reached an agreement and submitted an interim order to the court.Â  That order states in pertinent part:

  The attorneys and the parties will use their best efforts to settle all pending issues prior to mediation.Â  If the parties cannot, then they shall attend mediation that must be completed by December 7th.Â  

Mediation was scheduled for December 3, 2004.Â  However, this date was later postponed by agreement because Motherâ€™s counsel had to undergo medical testing.Â  The mediation was rescheduled for February 22, 2005.Â  Mother was made aware of the new mediation date and initially planned to appear by telephone.Â  However, before the mediation date, Mother informed Father she had no obligation to mediate and that she did not plan to participate.Â  Father appeared for the mediation, but Mother was not there.Â  
Father then filed a second petition asking the family court to issue a rule to show cause based on Motherâ€™s failure to attend mediation.Â  The hearing was held on April 21, and May 17 and 18, 2005.Â  The family court held Mother in civil contempt for alienation of affection and for her failure to allow overnight visitation.Â  Mother could either serve ninety days in jail or reimburse Father $8,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees incurred in bringing the action.Â  She was also required to give Father an additional week of summer vacation with the child in 2005.Â  The family court also held Mother in criminal contempt for her failure to appear at the scheduled mediation.Â  She was ordered to pay a $500 fine, which she has done, and attend mediation.Â  The family court did not hold Father in contempt for filing a new action prior to mediation.Â  
Mother filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion asserting the family court erred (1) in finding Mother in contempt for denying Father overnight visitation; (2) in finding Mother in willful contempt for removing a picture of Father from the childâ€™s bedroom; (3) in finding Mother in criminal contempt for failing to appear at mediation; (4) in failing to find Father in contempt for failing to seek mediation prior to filing a new action; and (5) in failing to find Father in contempt for his refusal to timely sign a quit claim deed in order to effectuate the closing on the marital home.[2]Â  The motion was denied and this appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  A finding of contempt rests within the sound discretion of the trial court and results from willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989).Â  â€œA trial courtâ€™s determination regarding contempt is subject to reversal where it is based on findings that are without evidentiary support or where there has been an abuse of discretion.â€ Â Henderson v. Puckett, 316 S.C. 171, 173, 447 S.E.2d 871, 872 (Ct. App. 1994). Â â€œEven though a party is found to have violated a court order, the question of whether or not to impose sanctions remains a matter for the courtâ€™s discretion.â€ Â Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 503, 597 S.E.2d 897, 900 (Ct. App. 2004). Â â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€ Â Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
A proceeding and judgment involving criminal contempt is heard on appeal as if from a judgment in a criminal case.Â  In re Moore, 79 S.C. 399, 400, 60 S.E. 947, 947 (1908).Â  In criminal cases, an appellate court reviews errors of law only and is bound by factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 147, 199 S.E.2d 61, 65 (1973); State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 388, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother contends the family court erred in finding her in contempt in numerous instances and in failing to find Father in contempt.Â  We disagree.Â  
Contempt results from a partyâ€™s willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396, 597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œA willful act is one which is â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€ Â Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)). Â â€œ[B]efore a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€ Â Widman, 348 S.C. at 119, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.â€Â  Hawkins, 359 S.C. at 501, 597 S.E.2d at 899.Â  â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the order.â€Â  Widman, 348 S.C. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.Â  Furthermore, it is generally recognized that where a contemnor is unable, without fault on his part, to obey a court order, he is not to be held in contempt.Â  Hicks v. Hicks, 280 S.C. 378, 381, 312 S.E.2d 598, 599 (Ct. App. 1984). 
The instant case involves both civil and criminal contempt.Â  â€œThe purpose of civil contempt is â€˜to coerce the defendant to do the thing required by the order for the benefit of the complainant.â€™â€Â  Poston v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106, 111, 502 S.E.2d 86, 88 (1998).Â  Civil contempt must by proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id. at 113, 502 S.E.2d at 89.Â  The primary purposes of criminal contempt, on the other hand, are to preserve the courtâ€™s authority and to punish the disobedience of its orders.Â  Id. at 111, 502 S.E.2d at 88 (citing State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 128, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994)).Â  Criminal contempt must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Id. at 113, 502 S.E.2d at 89.
I.Â Â Failure to Allow Overnight Visitation 
Mother contends the family court erred in finding her in civil contempt for failing to allow Father overnight visitation with the child. Â We disagree.Â  
The agreement contains numerous provisions regarding visitation with the child.Â  Section Twelve, Paragraph (a) of the agreement provides that â€œ[u]ntil [the child] reaches the age of three (3) years old, Husband/Father will have unlimited, unsupervised visitation time with [the child].Â  This time will be spent in Williamsburg, Virginia and [the child] will not be spending overnights with Husband/Father.â€Â  However, immediately following that paragraph, the agreement states: 

  (b) In addition to the unrestricted visitation as referenced above in paragraph (a), Husband/Father shall have visitation with [the child] for six (6), eight (8) hour periods, being solely responsible for [the child]â€™s supervision for these . . . [visits], to occur over a six (6) month period. . . .Â  After six (6) months and the six (6), eight (8) hour periods are accomplished by Husband/Father, Husband/Father shall then, in addition to the unrestricted visitation as set forth above in paragraph (a), Husband/Father shall be entitled to one (1) weekend of overnight visitation per month.Â  

This paragraph is followed by the statement that â€œ[u]pon [the child] reaching her second (2nd) birthday, Husband/Father will be entitled to seven (7) consecutive overnight days per year with [the child], so long as the prior visitation has gone well and [the child] is demonstrably happy with [Husband/Father]â€™s visitation.â€Â  
Although Paragraph (a) standing alone would seem to prevent overnight visitation by Father until the child is three, it can also be interpreted to mean that when the child attains age three, Father would be entitled to overnight visitation even if he does not meet the requirements set out in the following paragraphs.Â  Paragraphs (b) and (c) set forth conditions whereby Father can enjoy overnight visitation in addition to those he would be entitled to if he merely waited until the child attained age three.Â  Once Father complied with those conditions, he was entitled to overnight visitation prior to the child reaching age three.Â  The family court considered the provisions of the agreement and found Father had clearly met his overnight visitation requirement by July of 2004. Â See Browning v. Browning, 366 S.C. 255, 264, 621 S.E.2d 389, 393 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œWhen parties merge their settlement agreement into a decree, the family court transforms it from a contract between the parties to a decree of the court.Â  Thereafter, the agreement, as part of the court order, is fully subject to the family courtâ€™s authority to interpret and enforce its own decrees.â€) (internal citations omitted).Â  There is no dispute that Father visited the child at least once per month beginning in November of 2003.Â  It seems apparent from the record that Mother was not complying with the spirit of the agreement or with the specific provisions allowing visitation once the conditions outlined had been met.Â  
Though Mother contends Father had not met his requirements, much of her argument is based on her belief that the final order approving the October 29, 2003 agreement was not signed until March of 2004, and consequently, the â€œsix monthsâ€ would not have begun until then.Â  However, though the order was not signed until March 26, 2004, it was made effective nunc pro tunc to December 19, 2003.Â  
Mother further argues the family court incorrectly placed the burden on her to show that Father had not met the time requirements.Â  This was not in error as a prima facie case of contempt had already been made and the burden then shifted to Mother.Â  See Widman, 348 S.C. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705 (â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the order.â€).Â  Furthermore, because the family court was in a better position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and credibility, its findings should be given broad discretion.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in finding Mother in civil contempt for failure to allow overnight visitation.Â  
II.Â Â Conduct Engaged to Undermine the Childâ€™s Affection and Respect for Husband 
Mother contends the family court erred in finding her in contempt for undermining the childâ€™s affection and respect for Father.Â  We disagree.Â  
The agreement states, in relevant part: 

  The parents further agree that they will consult with each other and cooperate in making decisions regarding [the child], and that neither of them shall do or say anything to [the child] or within her hearing, directly or indirectly, to undermine [the child]â€™s affection and respect for the other parent.Â  Each parent agrees to speak to each other and of each other in a respectful manner at all times, especially in front of [the child] and will insist and to the extent possible ensure that friends and family members abide by this strict rule as well.Â  

The family court found Mother in contempt for undermining the childâ€™s affection and respect for Father for numerous reasons including denying overnight visitation, in yelling at him in front of the child, and in taking Fatherâ€™s photograph out of the childâ€™s room.Â  
The family court specifically found, and we agree, the yelling incident, standing alone, is probably not sufficient to trigger a citation of contempt.Â  However, that coupled with the numerous other instances of Motherâ€™s behavior, is enough to find her in civil contempt.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s holding of civil contempt was not erroneous.Â  
III.Â Â Failure to Attend Mediation 
Mother contends the family court erred in finding her in criminal contempt for not attending the February 22, 2005 mediation.Â  Father argues Mother has waived her right to appeal this issue by paying the fine ordered by the family court.Â  We agree and find the appeal of that issue is waived.Â  See Chappell v. Chappell, 282 S.C. 376, 377-78, 318 S.E.2d 590, 591 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding that father, who paid contempt fine for â€œinterfer[ing] with the due administration of justiceâ€ by attempting to pay child support arrearages to clerk in loose change, waived right to appeal).Â  
IV.Â Â Failure to Seek Mediation Before Filing of New Action 
Mother contends the family court erred in refusing to find Father in contempt when he filed a new action in family court without first seeking formal mediation.Â  We disagree.Â  
The agreement states in pertinent part: 

  Both parties agree that should problems, issues or concerns arise they will first seek the advice of a child psychologist/therapist, return to mediation and upon last resort return to the Family Court to resolve the visitation issues related to the child.Â  

and further states: 

  The parties agree that if any disagreement should arise concerning this Agreement that cannot be settled directly between themselves by negotiation, they will first attempt in good faith to mediate the dispute with the services of a professional mediator of mutual choice.Â  

However, the agreement does not state that a party cannot file an action prior to mediation.Â  The agreement states that the parties shall return to family court only as a last resort.Â  Fatherâ€™s action raised the issues and prompted the mediation process.Â  So although Father did file an action, the result of that filing was that mediation was set as contemplated by the agreement.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s ruling finding Father was not in contempt for filing his action.Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] This issue is not raised on appeal.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Melvin Douglas Woods, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-055
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 8, 2007


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant argues the trial judge erred by refusing to issue the jury an additional charge with regard to reasonable doubt as part of a supplemental Allen charge, when reasonable doubt had already been explained to the jury in the initial charge.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
Appellant Melvin Douglas Woods (â€œWoodsâ€) was indicted on a charge of second-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor, his eleven-year-old step-daughter (â€œVictimâ€).Â  After mistrials in March and October 2004, the case was called for a third jury trial on February 7, 2005.
The trial court gave a thorough and unchallenged jury instruction that included an explanation of the â€œreasonable doubtâ€ standard.Â  After deliberating, the jury sent a note to the court requesting a copy of the court record, and after further deliberations (amounting to a total of approximately two hours), a second note stating they were unable to reach a verdict. Â Â The court then gave the jury an Allen charge pursuant to Allen v. United States, 164 U.S. 492 (1896).Â  As part of this charge, the trial court concluded by stating:

  [I]f I can give you any help on the law, that is if you like any further definition of any of the matters of law which I have explained to you, be they reasonable doubt . . . or any legal questions whatsoever, I would be glad to try to clarify the law . . . if that will assist in your decision.Â Â  

After the charge had been completed and the jury exited, defense counsel requested that the charge of reasonable doubt be given again to the jury.Â  The trial judge refused, stating he believed that would â€œput too much emphasis on the reasonable doubt . . . I told them if they wanted any more instruction on any issue of law, Iâ€™ll give it to them, but they havenâ€™t requested that, so Iâ€™m going to respectfully decline to do that.â€Â  
The jury returned a verdict of guilty, and the trial court sentenced defendant.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court is required to charge the current and correct law.Â  Stokes v. Spartanburg Regâ€™l Med. Ctr.,  368 S.C. 515, 520, 629 S.E.2d 675, 678 (Ct. App. 2006).Â Â  Where a request to charge is timely made and involves a controlling legal principle, a refusal by the trial judge to charge the request constitutes reversible error.Â  Koutsogiannis v. BB&T,  365 S.C. 145, 149, 616 S.E.2d 425, 427-28 (2005). To warrant reversal, the refusal to give a requested charge must have been erroneous and prejudicial.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
We find the case of Orton v. United States, 221 F.2d 632 (4th Cir. 1955) instructive.Â  In Orton, the defendants were convicted after an initial charge that explained reasonable doubt and a subsequent, supplemental Allen charge that did not include any further explication of reasonable doubt.Â  Defendants appealed, arguing in part that the supplemental charge was in error because it did not include a repetition of the initial charge on presumption of innocence and reasonable doubt.Â Â  The circuit court of appeals affirmed the district court:

  [W]e think [the trial court] could very well assume that the jury had in mind instructions which he had given only an hour and a half before. Â Jurors should be given credit for having ordinary intelligence; and if there is one doctrine of the criminal law which they probably understand better than any other it is the presumption of innocence and the burden resting upon the prosecution to establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Nothing said in the supplemental charge had any tendency to becloud this doctrine and there was no reason to repeat what had been said plainly with regard thereto.

Orton at 635-36.
The same is true here.Â  The supplemental charge here was given approximately two hours after the initial charge. Â Â The original charge included an explanation of reasonable doubt.Â  The supplemental charge included a statement that the judge would be happy to offer the jury â€œany further definition of any of the matters of law which I have explained to you, be they reasonable doubtÂ  . . . or any legal questions whatsoever, I would be glad to try to clarify the law [for] you[.]â€Â  Nothing said in the supplemental charge had any tendency to confuse the jurors with respect to the law of reasonable doubt.Â  We find no error, and the judgment of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J, and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Marsha Tennant, Appellant,
        v.
        Beaufort County School District, Employer, and South Carolina School Board Insurance Trust, Carrier,  Defendants,
        of whom Beaufort County School District is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Master In Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-056
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 8, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James H. Moss, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
        Andrew D. Smith, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â During the fall of 2001, Marsha Tennant was employed as a special education teacher in the Beaufort County School District.Â  Tennant, along with her aides Yolanda Hamilton and Ieeia Grimes-Singleton, taught ten emotionally disturbed students at Ladyâ€™s Island Middle School.Â  As the 2001 school year progressed, Tennant became concerned that her aides were not performing their jobs in a satisfactory manner.Â  Tennant worried that her aidesâ€™ poor performance could impact upon her studentsâ€™ welfare and result in violations of federal guidelines for her studentsâ€™ individualized education programs.Â  
On the morning of October 18, 2001, Tennant felt physically ill after an argument with Hamilton.Â  Tennant sought the medical advice of Karen Williams, the school nurse. Â Williams checked Tennantâ€™s blood pressure and recorded it at an elevated 158/98.Â  Tennant left the nurseâ€™s station briefly to go to the main office and returned to see Williams approximately twenty minutes later.Â  Upon her return, Tennant complained of dizziness, sweating, chest pain, and neck pain.Â  Williams observed that Tennantâ€™s breathing was labored and called EMS out of fear that Tennant had suffered a heart attack.
Emergency medical personnel transported Tennant to Beaufort Memorial Hospital by ambulance and measured Tennantâ€™s blood pressure to be 178/108.Â  Tennantâ€™s treating physician at the hospital, Dr. Saeed Rehman, assessed Tennantâ€™s experience as a â€œstress reaction.â€Â  Dr. Andrea Hucks, Tennantâ€™s family physician, theorized that Tennant suffered a â€œpanic attackâ€ based on her reported symptoms and diagnosed Tennant with â€œsituational depression and panic disorder.â€Â  Additionally, Tennant was examined by Dr. Dyana Lowndes-Rosen, a licensed practicing psychologist.Â  Lowndes-Rosen determined Tennant suffered a single anxiety attack, and in her medical opinion felt Tennant did not require additional treatment or medications and could return to work because there was no resulting psychological disability from the anxiety attack.Â  Tennant later came under the care of Kathryn Jacobson, who has a bachelorâ€™s degree in sociology and psychology and a masterâ€™s degree in social work.Â  Jacobson diagnosed Tennant with post-traumatic stress disorder and believed, as of her deposition on May 27, 2002, that Tennant could not return to the classroom in the near future.Â  Tennant did not return to work at Ladyâ€™s Island Middle School following the incident, opting instead to work from home from August of 2002 for the University of South Carolina on a part-time basis.Â  
Tennant filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim alleging injuries to her â€œbrain and body.â€Â  After a hearing on October 10, 2002, the single commissioner issued an order on September 19, 2003 denying Tennantâ€™s claim.Â  The single commissioner found the greater weight of the evidence did not support Tennantâ€™s assertions that she sustained an injury in the course of her employment or that the conditions of her employment were either unusual or extraordinary.Â  An appellate panel of the workersâ€™ compensation commission, in its order dated May 17, 2004, affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s order, but also included in the record Jacobsonâ€™s previously excluded testimony and considered the testimony on the issue of causation.Â  The circuit court, by its order dated July 5, 2005, affirmed the appellate panelâ€™s ruling.Â  Tennant appeals.Â  
1.Â Â Tennant argues the circuit court erred by not considering the opinions of Jacobson and Hucks.Â  The single commissionerâ€™s order stated as follows: â€œGreater weight was given to the opinion of Dr. Dyana Lowndes-Rosen versus Dr. Andrea D. Hucks and Kathryn Jacobson.Â  Dr. Lowndes-Rosen is a licensed practicing psychologist, while Dr. Hucks practices internal medicine.â€Â  Although the single commissioner did not feel Jacobson qualified to render an opinion on causation, the appellate panel made Jacobsonâ€™s deposition part of the record and stated â€œ[a]lthough records which were excluded by the hearing commissioner are allowed in by this panel and considered, the end result is the same.â€Â  The circuit court concluded, and we agree, that the appellate panel considered Jacobsonâ€™s testimony but chose to give it no weight.Â  See Stone v. Traylor Brothers, Inc., 360 S.C. 271, 274, 600 S.E.2d 551, 552 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œIn an appeal from the Commission, neither this court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact . . . .â€).
2.Â Â Tennant next argues the circuit court erred in not finding that substantial evidence in the record supported a finding of unusual strain and exertion which allegedly caused Tennantâ€™s injury and subsequent disability.Â  Tennant also argues the circuit court erred in finding against her where substantial evidence in the record established that Tennantâ€™s alleged injury stemmed from an unusual or extraordinary condition at her workplace.Â  The circuit court, in finding substantial evidence existed in the record to support the appellate panelâ€™s ruling, specifically noted that 1) Tennantâ€™s position, Â teaching children who suffered from a wide range of problems, placed her in a naturally stressful environment, and noted specific instances of abnormal behavior from several of Tennantâ€™s students; 2) Topeeza Tillman, Tennantâ€™s direct supervisor, testified that conflicts like the one between Tennant and her aides were not unusual or extraordinary; 3) Beaufort County School District ultimately addressed Tennantâ€™s complaints and removed the aides from the classroom; 4) Jacobson conceded that a panic attack can be triggered without an unusual or extraordinary circumstance; and 5) Lowndes-Rosen determined Tennant suffered a single anxiety attack with no resulting psychological disability.Â  We agree with the circuit court that substantial evidence exists in the record to support the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Tennant did not suffer a compensable injury.Â  Because there is substantial evidence to support the appellate panelâ€™s ruling, we affirm.Â  See Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000) (â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Full Commission.â€); Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 136, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981) (â€œ[T]he possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent [the Commissionâ€™s] finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€); Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 455, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œWhere there are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the Commission are conclusive.â€).
AFFIRMED.[1]
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Melvin Rhodes, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-059
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 8, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Melvin Rhodes appeals from his conviction of shoplifting, third or greater offense.Â  He argues the trial judge erred in failing to order a mental evaluation to determine whether Rhodes was competent to stand trial.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On February 5, 2005, a customer at the Dollar General Store in North Augusta observed Rhodes leave the store with merchandise in his pants.Â  The customer, who happened to be an off-duty police officer, followed Rhodes out of the store, and spoke with Rhodes about the merchandise.Â Â  The police were called, and Rhodes was arrested for shoplifting.Â  Upon searching Rhodes, officers found seven packs of menâ€™s boxer shorts, two packs of menâ€™s T-shirts, and a set of sheets.Â  
The day before trial, Rhodes requested a mental evaluation to determine his capacity to stand trial.Â  Rhodes claimed he suffered from schizophrenia and depression, for which he took medication.Â  The trial judge engaged in a colloquy with Rhodes.Â  During this conversation, Rhodes admitted that he had been in court before, that he had been evaluated before, and that he spoke with his attorney about his mental condition.Â  Rhodes was also able to answer the trial judgeâ€™s questions regarding his age, the medications he was taking, and the length of time he had been in jail.Â  After engaging in this conversation with Rhodes, the trial judge denied Rhodesâ€™ request for a mental evaluation. 
Rhodes was convicted of shoplifting, third or greater offense.Â  He was sentenced to ten yearsâ€™ imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rhodes argues the trial judge erred in failing to order a mental evaluation to determine whether Rhodes was competent to stand trial.Â  We disagree.
Pursuant to section 44-23-410 of the South Carolina Code (2002), a trial judge must order a mental evaluation when the judge â€œhas reason to believeâ€ that the defendant is not mentally competent to stand trial.Â  Thus, the decision to order a mental evaluation is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge, who was able to observe the defendant and evaluate the facts presented on the question of competency.
Â State v. White, 364 S.C. 143, 147, 611 S.E.2d 927, 929 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Because the determination is left to the trial judgeâ€™s discretion, it will not be overturned absent a clear showing of abuse of discretion.Â 
Id.
â€œThe established test in South Carolina for determining a defendantâ€™s competency to stand trial is whether the defendant has the present ability to consult with his attorney with a reasonable degree of rational understanding.â€Â  Sims v. State, 313 S.C. 420, 422, 438 S.E.2d 253, 254 (1993).Â  Here, the trial judge engaged Rhodes in a conversation, and during that conversation, Rhodes demonstrated his ability to understand and respond to questions.Â  Rhodes also admitted to speaking with his attorney about his mental health problems and his case in general, thereby demonstrating his ability to consult with his attorney.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion by refusing to order a mental evaluation.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, Rhodesâ€™ conviction for shoplifting, third or greater offense, is
 AFFIRMED.  
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215(a), SCACR.
