title: J.H. Seale and Son v. Munn
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
J.H. Seale and Son, Inc., Respondent,
v.
Rhett Munn, individually, and Rhett Munn d/b/a Carolina Entertainment,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Linwood S. Evans, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-061
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William E. Hopkins, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
Marvin E. McMillan, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant Rhett Munn appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s refusal to grant Munnâ€™s motion to dismiss and holding that Munn is personally liable for unpaid invoices from J.H. Seale & Son, Inc. for petroleum.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Jay Richardson, an officer of J. H. Seale & Son, Inc., contacted his long term friend, Munn, about purchasing petroleum from J.H. Seale for convenience stores known as Munn-E-Saver. Â J.H. Seale and Munn began doing business together in April of 1995 without a written agreement. Â J.H. Seale billed Carolina Entertainment for the petroleum at Munnâ€™s request.[2]Â  On August 4, 1995, Munnâ€™s close corporation Carolina Music Company, Inc., changed its name to Carolina Entertainment, Inc. 
J.H. Seale brought this action on June 27, 2001 to collect payment for five unpaid invoices totaling $28,251.00. Â Munn moved to be dismissed from the action and for Carolina Entertainment, Inc. to be substituted as the defendant.Â  After a trial, the master denied Munnâ€™s motion to dismiss and found Munn personally liable to Seale for $18,451.92.[3]Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Motion to dismiss 
Munn argues the master erred in denying his motion to dismiss Munn individually because the master did not review the pleadings and Munn was not individually liable to Seale.Â  We disagree.
Munn asserts the master should have granted his motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP. Â Under this rule, the trial court may dismiss a claim when the defendant demonstrates the plaintiff has failed to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action in the pleadings filed with the court.Â  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 232-33, 553 S.E.2d 496, 499 (Ct. App. 2001)Â  Â â€œA motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6) should not be granted if facts alleged and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle the plaintiff to relief on any theory of the case.â€Â Â  Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 202, 584 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2003) The ruling on the motion to dismiss must be solely based on the allegations in the complaint. Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 300, 457 S.E.2d 601, 602 (1995). 
In this case, Seale contends in his complaint that Munn is individually liable for goods and services â€œprovided at the request of Defendant and for which the Defendants promised to pay.â€ Â The complaint lists â€œRhett Munn, individually and Rhett Munn, d/b/a Carolina Entertainmentâ€ as the only defendants.Â  The complaint implicates Munn individually for promising to pay.Â  Thus the complaint contains a theory of recovery against Munn, which prevents the granting of the motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6).Â  
Additionally, Munn argues that the master did not review the pleadings.Â  During the hearing the master stated that the Clerkâ€™s case file had been misplaced. Â Counsel for Seale provided the pleadings to the master for the hearing.Â  Counsel for Munn stated that he did not have a problem with Sealeâ€™s attorney providing the documents to the master. Â Munn never made any objection concerning the missing file.Â  Thus, we find Munnâ€™s argument is not preserved for our review. See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
Although Munn insists his motion was only one to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), he cites evidence presented at the hearing to support his argument that the master erred in holding him individually liable.Â  We find no error in the masterâ€™s ruling.Â  
This is an action at law.Â  See Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992) (â€œAn action for breach of contract seeking money damages is an action at law.â€)Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless those findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by error of law.Â  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of Ca., 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).
â€œCommon law, as reflected in the law of agency, requires that one who claims to be acting in a corporate capacity (thereby avoiding individual liability) must disclose that he or she is acting as an agent for the corporation rather than as an individual.â€Â  F. Lodge Oâ€™Neal & Robert B. Thompson, Â Oâ€™Neal and Thompsonâ€™s Close Corporations and LLCâ€™s: Law and Practice Â§8:9 (2004).Â Â  â€œThe burden is on the one claiming the agency relationship to prove that such disclosure took place.â€Â  Id.Â  
This court has found individuals responsible for a debt when they failed to disclose they were acting on behalf of a corporation.Â  Mail Mart, Inc. v. Action Mktg. Consultants, Inc., 281 S.C. 167, 314 S.E.2d 351 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In Mail Mart, the plaintiff alleged in its complaint that it provided individual defendants, Lewis and Edwards, advertising services pursuant to an oral contract.Â  Id. at 168, 314 S.E.2d at 352.Â  In their answer, Lewis and Edwards denied that they, as individuals, contracted with the plaintiff and affirmatively alleged that â€œany dealings that they had with the plaintiff were done as agents and employees of Action Marketing.â€Â  Id.Â  Â The president of the plaintiff testified he met with Lewis and Edwards at the Atlanta Airport sometime in August 1979 and entered into a marketing contract with them.Â  Id.Â  He further testified that he believed that his negotiations were with Lewis and Edwards alone.Â  Id.Â  At no time, he said, did they purport to represent Action Marketing or any other corporation.Â  Mail Mart, 281 S.C. at 168, 314 S.E.2d at 352.Â  The jury found in favor of the plaintiff against Lewis and Edwards individually.Â  Id. at 169, 314 S.E.2d at 363.Â  This court affirmed, finding the verdict was â€œclearly supported by the evidence.â€Â  Id. at 170, 314 S.E.2d at 363.Â  Â Â 
Like the plaintiff in Mail Mart, Jay Richardson, an officer with J.H. Seale, testified that he was unaware that Munn was acting on behalf of a corporation when they entered into an agreement for J.H. Seale to provide Munn petroleum.Â  Richardson acknowledged that he was aware Munn was involved with a corporation known as Carolina Music Company, Inc.Â  However, Munn directed J.H. Seale to bill the invoices not to Carolina Music Company, Inc. but to Carolina Entertainment.Â  Carolina Music Company, Inc. did not change its name to Carolina Entertainment, Inc. until four months after Richardson and Munn made their agreement.Â  Thus, at the time the agreement was made, no corporation with the name Carolina Entertainment, Inc. even existed.Â  Richardson maintained no one ever told him that Carolina Entertainment was a separate legal entity or a corporation.Â  He asserted that if he had known Carolina Entertainment was a corporation, he would have asked for a personal guarantee from Munn.Â  He claimed he expected payment from Munn.Â  He stated he never knew Munnâ€™s position, that Carolina Entertainment was the party responsible for the debt, until this lawsuit was filed.Â  
Munn asserts the payment of invoices with checks written on Carolina Entertainmentâ€™s account signed by J.B. Brown evidences J.H. Sealeâ€™s knowledge of the corporation.Â  However, the payment of bills using corporate checks is not sufficient to disclose the agency relationship.Â  Oâ€™Neal & Thompson, at Â§8:9.Â Â  
Munn also calls the courtâ€™s attention to the fact that the invoices for which J.H. Seale seeks payments were dated over five years after the parties began doing business and the Articles of Amendment were filed with the Secretary of State reflecting the name change from Carolina Music Co., Inc. to Carolina Entertainment, Inc.Â  Munn states, â€œCarolina Entertainment, Inc. was a valid South Carolina corporation as of July 15, 1995 . . . .â€Â  The business agreement between J.H. Seale and Munn, however, began in April of 1995, four months before the name change.Â  Munn acknowledged he never sent out any written notice to his customers or vendors concerning the name change nor could he specifically recall telling anyone from J.H. Seale about the change.
Munn did testify that he told Richardson to bill Carolina Entertainment, Inc. rather than just â€œCarolina Entertainment.â€Â  Although Munn presented evidence contradicting that of J.H. Seale, this court may not re-weigh the evidence but must only determine whether there is evidence supporting the masterâ€™s ruling. Kiriakides v. Atlas Food Sys. & Serv. Inc., 343 S.C. 587, 594, 541 S.E.2d 257, 261 (2001).Â  Accordingly, as we find evidence in the record to support the masterâ€™s ruling that Munn was individually liable, we must affirm.Â  
II.  Piercing the Corporate Veil 
Munn argues the master erred in holding him personally liable for the unpaid invoices because the master did not conduct a piercing the corporate veil analysis.Â  This issue was neither raised to nor ruled upon by the master.Â  Therefore, it is not properly before this court.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
Furthermore, there was simply no veil to be pierced.Â  The master held Munn directly liable for the invoices based on his actions rather than under a theory of piercing the corporate veil.Â  We find no error.Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the masterâ€™s decision is 
 AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Four of the five invoices in the record have â€œCarolina Entertainmentâ€ listed as the purchaser.Â  The other invoice has the purchaser listed as â€œCarolina Entertainment Company.â€
[3]  This amount of the debt was decreased to $18,451.92 due to payments previously made. Â The amount of the debt is not in dispute on appeal.Â Â Â

 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Citifinancial Mortgage, Inc., et al., Respondent,
v.
Emma Kennedy a/k/a E.B. Kennedy, Transouth Financial Corporation and Greenwood Trust T/A The Discover Card,
Defendants,
Of Whom Emma Kennedy is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â Haig Porter, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-062
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007

DISMISSED


  
    
      
Emma Kennedy, of Lake City, for Appellant
Roy F. Laney and Nikole D. Haltiwanger, both of Columbia, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Emma Kennedy appeals the special refereeâ€™s decision upholding a default judgment in favor of Citifinancial Mortgage Company, Inc. (Bank) which resulted in the foreclosure of her home.Â  Kennedy contends that she was not afforded service of process in accordance with Rule 4(d), SCRCP.[1]Â  
FACTS
On December 4, 2004, Bank filed a foreclosure action against Kennedy for her property located at 424 Lyerly Street in Lake City, South Carolina.Â  On February 5, 2005, Constable Walter Phillips delivered the amended summons and complaint to Kennedyâ€™s residence, and Carrol Gray accepted delivery.Â  In his affidavit of service, Phillips noted that Gray, a sixty-five-year-old male, lived at the residence.Â Â Â  
No response to the summons and complaint was ever submitted, and on June 2, 2005, the special referee held a hearing and entered a default judgment against Kennedy ordering the property sold at public auction.[2]Â  On October 26, 2005, the special referee awarded a deed to the public auctionâ€™s highest bidder.Â Â Â  
On November 3, 2005, Kennedy filed a Rule 60(b), SCRCP, motion to vacate the special refereeâ€™s default judgment and the sale of the property on the grounds that she was not served process.Â  On November 23, 2005, the special referee held a hearing and denied Kennedyâ€™s motion.Â  The order was filed on November 30, 2005, and written notice of entry of the order was mailed to Kennedy on December 5, 2005.Â  
Kennedy filed a second Rule 60(b) motion on November 30, 2005, and by order dated December 30, 2005, this motion was denied.Â  During the December 15, 2005 hearing on this motion, Carrol Gray testified that he stayed at the residence a few days a week and accepted service on behalf of Kennedy.[3]Â  Gray went on to testify that he presented Kennedy with the summons and complaint the following day.Â  Kennedy admitted to receiving the summons and complaint, and she further testified that she brought this process to a lawyer within the thirty day period within which she was required to respond.Â  
On January 11, 2006, Kennedy filed her notice of appeal referencing only the special refereeâ€™s December 30, 2005 order and not the November 30, 2005 order denying the initial Rule 60 motion to set aside the default judgment.Â  Accordingly, Kennedy notes only when she received written notice of the December thirtieth order and not the date she received written notice of the November thirtieth order.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Kennedy attempts to appeal from the December 30, 2005 order denying her second Rule 60(b) motion.Â  There are many procedural and, ultimately, jurisdictional problems with this request.Â  In an abundance of caution and with a desire for procedural leniency with pro se litigants within the bounds of the law, we will entertain an analysis which explores all possible avenues.
First, we must note that Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR, requires an appellant to serve a written notice of appeal to all respondents within thirty days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment.[4]Â  Because the requirement of service of notice of appeal is jurisdictional, failure to meet this deadline deprives this court of the ability to consider the appeal.Â 
Elam v. S.C. Dept. of Transportation, 361 S.C. 9, 14-15, 602 S.E.2d 772, 775 (2004).Â  This court has â€œno authority or discretion to â€˜rescueâ€™ the delinquent party by extending or ignoring the deadline for service of the notice.â€Â  Id.Â  Â 
Bank asserts that Kennedyâ€™s notice of appeal (NOA) was filed fifty days after the special refereeâ€™s November 23, 2005 order (the order was actually filed on November 30, 2005).Â  However, Rule 203, SCRCP, does not provide that NOA be filed within thirty days of the entry of judgment; it requires the NOA be filed within thirty days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment.Â  Therefore, the thirty days began to run when Kennedy received the written notice which was mailed to her on Monday December 5, 2005.Â  Since Kennedy only appeals from the December 30, 2005 order in her NOA, she does not note when she received notice of the November 30, 2005 order.Â  Nonetheless, we find it likely Kennedy received the written notice on or before Saturday, December 10, 2005, which would render her January 11, 2006 NOA untimely.[5]Â  
If we were to accept and analyze Kennedyâ€™s notice of appeal as it reads to appeal only from the December 30, 2005 order denying her second Rule 60(b) motion, her appeal would fail.Â  Once the time to file notice of appeal concerning the November 30, 2005 order had expired, that order, â€œright or wrong,â€ became the law of the case and res judicata would preclude any further review on the issues decided therein.Â  See Ulmer v. Ulmer, 369 S.C. 486, 490, 632 S.E.2d 858, 861 (2006) (holding portion of a judgment that is not appealed presents no issue for determination by the reviewing court and constitutes, rightly or wrongly, the law of the case).Â  The special refereeâ€™s order denying Kennedyâ€™s Rule 60(b) motion, enforcing the default judgment for foreclosure, and enforcing the sale of the residence at public auction became unappealable once the time for service of notice of appeal for that order had expired.Â  Therefore, the relief sought by Kennedy no longer would be available to her through appeal of the December thirtieth order. 
In an effort to provide Kennedy with the benefit of the doubt in this matter, we next endeavor to analyze her notice of appeal as though she intended to appeal from the November 30, 2005 order.Â  We do not find this analysis to prejudice Bank because they briefed this appeal as though Kennedy had appealed from the November thirtieth order.Â  In fact, Bankâ€™s assertion that Kennedyâ€™s notice of appeal was not timely is based on time elapsing from the November thirtieth order (Bank refers to it as the November 23, 2005 order.). 
In response to the denial of her first Rule 60(b), SCRCP, motion, Kennedy filed a second Rule 60(b) motion.Â  Important to note is the fact that unlike a Rule 50, 52 or 59, SCRCP, motion, a Rule 60(b) motion does not have any tolling effect on the right to appeal from the challenged judgment.Â  Coward Hund Construction Co., Inc. v. Ball Corp. and Carolina Glass Contractors, Inc., 336 S.C. 1, 5-6, 518 S.E.2d 56, 59 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œTherefore, the time to appeal continues to run from the entry of the judgment that the Rule 60(b) motion challenges.â€Â  Id.Â  Â Â Â Thus, if we treat Kennedyâ€™s second motion as it is captioned, a Rule 60(b) motion, the time to serve notice of appeal would have expired prior to her January 11, 2006 service.Â  
â€œIt is the substance of the requested relief that matters â€˜regardless of the form in which the request for relief was framed.â€™â€Â 
Richland County v. Kaiser, 351 S.C. 89, 94, 567 S.E.2d 260, 262 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  It is possible that Kennedyâ€™s second Rule 60(b) motion should be considered as a Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Even if we were to make that assumption, Kennedyâ€™s appeal would still fail.
Although a timely Rule 59(e) motion normally will toll the time within which an appellant must serve his notice of appeal, a successive Rule 59(e) motion will not do so.Â  Quality Trailer Products, Inc. v. CSl Equipment Company, Inc., 349 S.C. 216, 219, 562 S.E.2d 615, 617 (2002).Â  In Quality Trailer, the denial of a post-trial motion for JNOV was followed by a virtually identical motion captioned pursuant to Rules 52, 59, and 60, SCRCP.Â  Id. at 218, 562 S.E.2d at 616-17.Â  The court found â€œthe time for filing appeal is not extended by submitting the same motion under a different caption.â€Â  Id. at 220, 562 S.E.2d at 618.Â  Kennedyâ€™s first and second post-trial motions each assert only that she did not receive service of process, and we see no substantive difference between them.[6]Â  We find Kennedyâ€™s second motion, even were we to treat it as a Rule 59(e) motion, would be successive to her previous Rule 60(b) motion and would therefore not toll the time to submit notice of appeal.
CONCLUSION
We see no means by which this court can take jurisdiction over this appeal.Â  Based on the foregoing, Kennedyâ€™s appeal is
 DISMISSED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] Through a notice of hearing dated April 27, 2005, Kennedy was mailed a written notice of the hearing, but she failed to appear.Â Â Â  
[3] At the outset of this hearing, Bank asserted that this second Rule 60(b) motion was identical to the previously decided Rule 60(b) motion.Â  Bank requested that the special referee not entertain this successive motion.Â  The special referee stated that he was inclined to grant the motion, but he held it in abeyance.Â  The special referee went on to say that the two motions were â€œbasically the sameâ€ and that he â€œtended to agreeâ€ with Bank.Â  Despite the refereeâ€™s statement that you canâ€™t make the same motion over and over again and his finding of â€œlittle or no substantive differenceâ€ between the motions, he decided Kennedy had expanded on her motion â€œsomewhatâ€ and since everyone was present they would go ahead with the hearing.Â  Ultimately, the referee denied Bankâ€™s motion even though he concluded he might be â€œright or wrong.â€Â  
[4] Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR, applies to appeals from the court of common pleas.Â  However, Rule 203(b)(4), SCACR, dictates that notice of appeal from a special refereeâ€™s decision shall be served in the same manner. 
[5] We note the appellant
has the burden of providing this Court with a sufficient record upon which we can make a decision.Â 
State v. 192 Coin-Operated Video Game Machines, 338 S.C. 176, 195, 525 S.E.2d 872, 882, (2000).Â  Kennedy has failed to include the date she received the November 30, 2005 order.Â  
[6] We are not persuaded that because Kennedyâ€™s second motion references testimony from the first hearing, it is substantively different from her initial Rule 60(b) motion.

PER CURIAM:Â  Jorg and Yvette Bewersdorf brought this action against the South Carolina Department of Public Safety and Colleton County after Jorg hit a cow while riding his motorcycle on Highway 17-A in Colleton County and was injured.Â  The trial judge granted both respondents a directed verdict, and the Bewersdorfs appeal.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities: Â Vaughan v. Town of Lyman, 370 S.C. 436, 441, 635 S.E.2d 631, 634 (2006) (â€œ[the public duty rule] holds that public officials are generally not liable to individuals for their negligence in discharging public duties as the duty is owed to the public at large rather than anyone individually.â€) (quoting Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™tof Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 388, 520 S.E.2d 142, 149 (1999)); Estate of Haley ex rel. Haley v. Brown, 370 S.C. 240, 252, 634 S.E.2d 62, 68 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œWhen the evidence yields only one inference, a directed verdict in favor of the moving party is proper.â€); McDill v. Markâ€™s Auto Sales, Inc., 367 S.C. 486, 490, 626 S.E.2d 52, 55 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œThe qualification of an expert witness and the admissibility of his or her opinion are matters resting within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€); Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 406, 570 S.E.2d 176, 183 (2002) (â€œFor a court to find a witness competent to testify as an expert, the witness must be better qualified than the jury to form an opinion on the particular subject of the testimony.â€); Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997) (stating rule requiring submission of issue to jury whenever there is material evidence tending to establish issue in mind of reasonable juror does not require submission of speculative, theoretical, and hypothetical views to jury).
AFFIRMED.

title: Brickyard Plantation Property Owners Association v. Araujo
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Brickyard Plantation Property Owners Association, Inc.,
Appellant,
v.
Jose G. Araujo and Madeline A. Araujo, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-065
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John Joseph Dodds, III, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
Stanley E. Barnett, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The Brickyard Plantation Property Owners Association, Inc. (â€œPOAâ€), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding the POA approved Jose and Madeline Araujoâ€™s application to construct a dock, denying the POAâ€™s request for an injunction and attorneyâ€™s fees, and holding the water body adjacent to the Araujosâ€™ property is legally navigable.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
I.
In February 2002, the Araujos purchased property adjacent to a small body of water in a development called Brickyard Plantation.Â  The property was sold subject to the Declaration of Covenants and Restrictions for Brickyard Plantation (â€œCovenantsâ€).Â  
The Araujosâ€™ main purpose for purchasing this property was to construct a dock that would allow them to use the adjacent water body.Â  Under section 7.2 of the Covenants, any structural improvement, including docks, must be approved by the Architectural Review Board of the POA (â€œARBâ€).Â  Section 7.2 also provides:

In the event the ARB fails to approve or disapprove any request within thirty (30) days after complete written plans and specifications have been submitted to it, the same shall be deemed approved, and this article shall be deemed to have been fully complied with, provided, however, that no such failure to act shall be deemed an approval of any matters specifically prohibited by any other provisions of this Declaration.

In September 2003, the Araujos submitted a dock permit application to the Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (â€œOCRMâ€), which approved the permit.Â  Before formal approval from OCRM, however, the POA learned of the Araujosâ€™ desire to build a dock and requested the Araujos send it information on the proposed dock.Â  The POA also sent a letter to OCRM (and a copy to the Araujos) asserting that no docks were allowed on â€œlakes, marshes or lagoons without permission of the POA and ARB Board of Directors,â€ and that the POA decided not to allow any docks on ponds, marshes, lakes or lagoons under its control. 
In October 2003, in response to the POAâ€™s request, the Araujosâ€™ contractor faxed a copy of the OCRM permit application and drawings to Stephen Wright, the President of the POA.Â  The contractor included a letter indicating the Aruajos would formally request approval from the home owners association after an OCRM permit was secured.Â  In November 2003, prior to a formal request by the Aruajos, the POA informed the Araujos by letter that their â€œsubmittal was reviewed by the POA board and a decision was made to deny your request based on . . . the Covenants and Restrictions.â€Â  This letter was not based on any decision or action made by the ARB; however,the letter further stated that â€œ[t]he POA and ARB Board of Directors have made a decision not to allow any dock to be constructed on the ponds, marshes, lakes or lagoons; they are only permitted on the deep water of the Horlbeck Creek.â€Â  
By permit dated January 21, 2004, OCRM approved the Araujosâ€™ dock.[2]Â  
On January 20, 2004, the Araujos attended a POA board meeting to submit the first formal request for approval by the ARB of the dock they planned to construct.[3]Â  At the meeting, the Araujos provided the POA property managerâ€”an agent of the POA and the ARBâ€”with a $50 application fee and a letter addressed to the POA regarding the construction of their dock.Â  The letter expressly provided: â€œThis is a request for ARB and or [sic] Brickyard Board of Elected Representatives for approval of said dock below.â€Â  The property manager placed the materials in the Araujosâ€™ file.Â  Thereafter, via an undated letter mailed around February 11, 2004, the POA informed the Araujos their dock would not be allowed pursuant to the Covenants.Â  
On March 5, 2004, Mrs. Araujo visited the POAâ€™s management office to examine her file.Â  Mrs. Araujo noticed the information submitted at the January board meeting, including the $50 application fee, were still in their file and had not been given to the ARB.Â  Mrs. Araujo asked the property manager to submit the materials to the ARB at their next meeting and write a note explaining the events surrounding the Araujosâ€™ submittal.Â  
On March 11, 2004, the Araujosâ€™ materials were submitted to the ARB.Â  The ARB did not approve the Araujosâ€™ dock based on sections 7.36 and 7.44 of the Covenants.Â  By a letter dated March 15, 2004, the ARB denied the Araujos request to construct a dock.Â  
Thereafter, the Araujos began construction of their dock, believing the OCRM and the Covenants authorized it.Â  The POA filed this action seeking an injunction requiring the removal of the Araujosâ€™ dock and a monetary fine.Â  The circuit court held the POA approved the Araujosâ€™ dock by default under section 7.2 of the Covenants, and the Araujos could construct and maintain their dock.Â  In addition, the circuit court held the water body adjacent to the Araujosâ€™ property was legally navigable.Â  The POA filed a motion to alter or amend judgment.Â  The circuit court modified its original order but did not alter the overall findings in the case.Â  This appeal follows.Â Â  
II.
â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is in equity.â€ Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Marshland Trust, Inc., 358 S.C. 655, 661, 596 S.E.2d 380, 383 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  On an appeal in an action in equity, tried by the judge alone, without a reference, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.Â 
Campbell v. Carr, 361 S.C. 258, 263, 603 S.E.2d 625, 627 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Nevertheless, â€œthis broad scope of review does not require the appellate court to ignore the findings below when the trial court was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â 
Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n, 358 S.C. at 661, 596 S.E.2d at 383.Â Â Â Â Â  
III.
The POA argues the circuit court erred in holding the ARB approved the Araujosâ€™ dock by default.Â  Specifically, the POA contends the court erred in finding the Araujosâ€™ filed an application to construct a dock with the ARB on January 20, 2004 and misinterpreted the relevant Covenants.Â  We disagree.
A.Â  Application to Construct Dock
The record shows that the Araujos appeared at the January 20, 2004 POA board meeting and submitted several forms regarding the construction of their dock, an application fee, and a letter addressed to the POA.Â  The minutes from the January POA board meeting provide that the Araujos â€œaddressed the board concerning their dock applicationâ€ and presented their â€œdock request.â€Â  The letter that accompanied the Araujosâ€™ submittal provides: â€œThis is a request for ARB and or [sic] Brickyard Board of Elected Representatives for approvalâ€ to construct a dock.Â  In addition, Mrs. Araujo testified that she informed the POA board that she wanted the materials submitted to the ARB â€œper covenants and restrictions.â€Â  Mr. Araujo also testified that he considered the materials submitted at the January POA board meeting to be an application for approval to construct a dock.Â  This evidence supports finding the Araujos submitted a complete application to the POA and the ARB on January 20, 2004.Â  Moreover, where there is discrepancy in testimony, we may defer to the circuit courtâ€™s findings.Â  See Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n, 358 S.C. at 661, 596 S.E.2d at 383. 
B.Â  Interpretation of CovenantsÂ Â Â Â  Â Â  
Under section 7.2 of the Covenants, once a party submits an application requesting to construct a dock, the application is automatically approved if the ARB fails to approve or disapprove the request within thirty days.Â  This approval by default, however, does not apply for â€œany matters specifically prohibited by any other provisions of [the Covenants].â€Â  In this case, the ARB notified the Araujos that their request was denied on, at the earliest, March 15, 2004, which is well beyond the thirty day deadline for an application submitted on January 20, 2004.Â Â  
The POA contends sections 7.36(c) and 7.44 of the Covenants specifically prohibit the Araujosâ€™ dock.Â  Section 7.36(c) provides that â€œ[n]o dock, pier, or wharf shall be constructed on any lagoon and no dock, pier, or wharf shall be constructed on the marsh without approval of the Developer or ARB and the Association.â€[4]Â  Section 7.44 provides, â€œ[n]o docks, landings, or other structures may be located in or adjacent to any lake or lagoon without the prior written consent of the Developer.â€Â  The Covenants, therefore, expressly authorize the construction of a dock when approved by the appropriate person or board, i.e., the building of a dock is not a â€œmatter[] specifically prohibited by any other provisions of [the Covenants].â€
â€œAs voluntary contracts, restrictive covenants will be enforced unless they are indefinite or contravene public policy.â€Â 
Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assoc., 358 S.C. at 661, 596 S.E.2d at 383.Â  â€œThe language of a restrictive covenant is to be construed according to the plain and ordinary meaning attributed to it at the time of execution.â€Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, __, 631 S.E.2d 539, 542 (2006).Â  â€œRestrictive covenants are contractual in nature, so that the paramount rule of construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the parties as determined from the whole document.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001) (quoting Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4-5, 498 S.E.2d 862, 863-64 (1998)).Â  â€œIt is still the settled rule in this jurisdiction that restrictions as to the use of real estate should be strictly construed and all doubts resolved in favor of free use of the property, subject, however, to the provision that this rule of strict construction should not be applied so as to defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the instrument.â€Â  Id.Â  
We find neither section 7.36 nor section 7.44 prohibits construction of the Araujosâ€™ dock.Â  Both sections expressly allow for construction upon approval by the ARB.Â  At best, the various covenants are ambiguous, which requires a resolution in line with the free use of the property.Â  Because the construction of a dock is not in all cases â€œspecifically prohibitedâ€ by either section, the application was automatically approved under section 7.2 as the ARB failed to act within thirty days of submission. 
C.     Injunction and Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
Because we find the circuit court correctly held the ARB approved the Araujosâ€™ dock by default, we also hold the circuit court did not err in failing to grant an injunction on the Araujoâ€™s dock.Â  Likewise, the circuit court correctly declined to award the POA attorneyâ€™s fees.
Section 8.1 of the Covenants authorizes the POA to enforce the Covenants.Â  Section 8.9 allows the POA to recover attorneyâ€™s fees where an attorney is employed to bring an action for breach of the Covenants.Â  As discussed above, we find the Araujos did not breach the Covenants; therefore, the POA is not entitled to recover attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
IV.
The POA argues the circuit court erred in holding the water body at issue was â€œlegally navigableâ€ and â€œa public navigable water.â€Â  At trial, the POA alleged that lots adjacent to tidal ponds were subject to different restrictions than lots adjacent to Horlbeck Creek.Â  To refute this contention, the Araujos argued and the circuit court found that the tidal pond adjacent to the Araujosâ€™ property is â€œlegally navigableâ€ and â€œa public navigable water.â€Â  Because we base our holding on the language in the restrictive covenants, we find the issue of navigability is not necessary for the resolution of the appeal.Â  Accordingly, we will not address this issue.Â  See Binkley v. Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation Dist. of Fountain Inn, 348 S.C. 58, 76 n.36, 558 S.E.2d 902, 911 n.36 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThis court will not issue advisory opinions that have no practical effect on the outcome.â€).
V.
For the reasons set forth herein, the decision of the circuit court is

AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  OCRM issued the Araujosâ€™ permit despite the POAâ€™s letter because the POA failed to demonstrate ownership of the water body.Â  
[3]  It is uncontested that the January 20, 2004 application was the first formal request by the Araujos for approval of the dock.Â  There is no contention by the POA that the activity in late 2003 was either an application by the Araujos or a formal rejection by the POA or ARB.Â  In the trial court and on appeal, the focus of the POA is on the Covenants in the context of the January 20, 2004 application.
[4]  The inclusion of â€œthe Developerâ€ has no relevance to this case.Â  The Developer was only authorized to grant approval before it sold a certain number of properties, at which time all approval rights transferred to the ARB pursuant to section 7.2 of the Covenants.Â  At all times relevant for this action, the ARB had the right of approval for the construction of a dock.Â

title: Computer Products v. JEM Restaurant Group
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Computer Products, Inc., Appellant,
v.
JEM Restaurant Group, Inc., John E. McGrath, Monolith Software Solutions, Inc., and W. David
Valmus, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-066
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Paul E. Tinkler and Spiro S. Ferderigos, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
B. Craig Killough, John A. Jones, and Susan Taylor Wall, all of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Computer Products, Inc. (Computer Products) appeals orders of the circuit court granting summary judgment to JEM Restaurant Group, Inc. (JEM), John E. McGrath (McGrath), Monolith Software Solutions, Inc. (Monolith), and W. David Valmus (Valmus).Â  Computer Products argues the circuit court erred in not finding: (1) an agency relationship between Valmus and Computer Products; (2) a duty of loyalty and/or fiduciary duty Valmus owed to Computer Products; and (3) that McGrath aided or abetted Valmusâ€™s breach of loyalty and/or fiduciary duty.Â  Computer Products also argues the circuit court erred in its application of: (1) South Carolina Trade Secrets Act; (2) Unfair Trade Practices Act; and (3) the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  We affirm.[1]
I.Â  Computer Products failed to preserve its argument regarding the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Valmus was an agent because it did not make this argument in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  West v. Newberry Elec. Coop., 357 S.C. 537, 543, 593 S.E.2d 500, 503 (Ct. App. 2004) (certiorari denied) (holding issue that is neither addressed by the circuit court in the final order nor raised by way of Rule 59(e) motion is not preserved for review).Â  
II.Â  Computer Products argues that because Valmus was an agent/employee of Computer Products, Valmus had a duty of loyalty to Computer Products.Â  However, at trial, Computer Products conceded that Valmus was an independent contractor, not its employee; therefore, this argument is without merit.Â  See, e.g., Kirkland v. Allcraft Steel Co., Inc., 329 S.C. 389, 392-93, 496 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1998) (finding a concession made at trial precludes a party from contesting the issue on appeal).
III.Â  Computer Products contends that the circuit court erred in finding as a matter of law that McGrath did not aid or abet Valmusâ€™s breach of loyalty and/or fiduciary duty.Â  Because we have determined that no duty of loyalty and/or fiduciary duty existed between Valmus and Computer Products, we need not address this issue.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating the appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of a prior issue is dispositive).
IV.Â  Computer Products failed to preserve its argument regarding the circuit courtâ€™s finding that as a matter of law the South Carolina Trade Secrets Act is inapplicable, or in the alternative that Computer Products did not meet its burden of proof. Â Humbert v. State, 345 S.C. 332, 337, 548 S.E.2d 862, 865 (2001); Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 460, 535 S.E.2d 438, 445 (2000) (holding that where a trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument raised, and appellant makes no Rule 59(e) motion to obtain a ruling, the appellate court may not address the issue).
V.Â  Computer Products abandoned its argument regarding its allegation that the circuit court erred in finding as a matter of law that McGrath did not violate the Unfair Trade Practice Act.Â  Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship., 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1993) ( â€œAn issue raised on appeal but not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and will not be considered by the appellate court.â€). Â The issue is also abandoned as to McGrath because Computer Productsâ€™ presentation of this issue in its brief is conclusory and lacks supporting authority.Â  Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 600, 608 S.E.2d 587, 593-94 (Ct.App.2005) (noting when an appellant fails to cite any supporting authority for his position and makes
conclusory arguments, the appellant abandons the issue on appeal).
VI.Â  Â Computer Products argues the circuit court erred in finding as a matter of law that a covenant of good faith and fair dealing is inapplicable. Â Computer Products did not bring a claim for breach of contract; therefore, its cause of action for breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing does not succeed as a matter of law.Â  See Rotec Servs., Inc. v. Encompass Servs., Inc., 359 S.C. 467, 471-473, 597 S.E.2d 881, 883-884 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding there can be no separate cause of action for breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing because it is subsumed under the claim for breach of contract.)Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Mark D. Watt, individually and as an agent for Diane M. Watt and William J. Watt, Respondent
        v.
        Charlie Gallowayâ€™s Furniture Shop, Inc., d/b/a Furniture Depot Design Center and Charlie M. Galloway, Jr., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Anderson County
James D. Jolly, Jr., Special Referee 

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-072
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        William E. Phillips,Â  of Anderson, for Appellants.
        Richard E. Thompson, Jr., of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charlie Gallowayâ€™s Furniture Shop, Inc., d/b/a Furniture Depot Design Center and Charlie M. Galloway, Jr., (collectively â€œGallowayâ€) appeal the special refereeâ€™s finding that J. Jackie Watt (decedent) owned forty percent of Gallowayâ€™s Furniture Shop, Inc.Â  Galloway also contends the special referee erred in finding the action was not filed beyond the statute of limitations.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On March 2, 1989, Galloway and decedent jointly purchased property on which Gallowayâ€™s Furniture Shop was operated.Â  A disagreement arose over the operation of the business and, on February 7, 1996, decedent filed suit against Galloway alleging he was a forty percent shareholder in the corporation.Â  Decedent alleged the parties could no longer work together and asked for the corporation to be dissolved.Â  Galloway filed an Answer and Counterclaim alleging decedent was a thirty-nine percent shareholder.Â  Decedent maintained he was a forty percent shareholder, and thereafter, Galloway filed an Amended Answer and Counterclaim alleging decedent did not own any shares of the corporation because he failed to provide adequate consideration.Â  Decedent filed a reply denying the allegations and asking that Gallowayâ€™s counterclaim be barred by the statute of limitations.Â  On January 16, 1998, the case was referred to a special referee.Â  
On September 13, 1998, decedent passed away.Â  An estate was opened and it was determined that his heirs were his three children:Â  Mark D. Watt, Diane M. Watt, and William J. Watt, of whom Mark Watt was appointed the personal representative.Â  After the death of his father, Mark Watt approached Galloway concerning his fatherâ€™s share of the corporation.Â  This was followed by a second visit, at which time Mark Watt asked Galloway to value the corporation so that he could determine the value of his late fatherâ€™s share.Â Â Â  According to Mark Watt, Galloway gave a figure of $250,000 but stated that â€œthey shouldnâ€™t record all of that figure because [decedent] only owned thirty-nine percent of it.â€Â Â  In December 2001, Mark Watt had another conversation with Galloway concerning the probate of his fatherâ€™s estate.Â  During this conversation, Galloway told Mark Watt that decedent did not own any interest in the corporation, and as such, there would be no division.Â  At this time, Mark Watt became concerned and consulted an attorney. Â Â 
On October 18, 2002, Mark Watt, individually and as an agent for the estate, filed a lawsuit alleging decedent was a forty percent shareholder of the corporation and asking for judicial dissolution of the corporation, a court ordered sale of shares, and a partition of the property. Â In his Second Amended Answer and Counterclaim, Galloway alleged decedent was merely an employee of the corporation and did not own any shares.Â  Galloway further alleged that even if decedent did own shares, the complaint should be dismissed as filed beyond the applicable statute of limitations.Â  A hearing was held September 27-29, 2005, at which the special referee found decedent was a forty percent shareholder in the corporation and the action was not filed beyond the applicable statute of limitations.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA corporate dissolution, under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-300 et seq., is an equitable relief.  The provisions of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-14-310(d), allowing for appropriate alternative relief including a buyout of shareholders by other shareholders or the corporation, are also equitable.â€  Kiriakides v. Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc., 338 S.C. 572, 581, 527 S.E.2d 371, 375-76 (Ct. App. 2000) affâ€™d as modified, 343 S.C. 587, 541 S.E.2d 257 (2001) (citations omitted).Â  Our scope of review for a case heard by a Master-in-Equity or special referee who enters a final judgment is the same as that for review of a case heard by a circuit court without a jury.  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1990) (citations omitted).Â  In an equity action, the appellate court may review the evidence to determine the facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence.Â  Florence County Sch. Dist. #2 v. Interkal, Inc., 348 S.C. 446, 450, 559 S.E.2d 866, 868 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, the appellate court does not disregard the findings of the special referee who was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Tiger, at 237, 391 S.E.2d at 543.Â  Furthermore, the appellate court is not bound by the trial courtâ€™s legal determinations.Â  Â Swindler v. Swindler, 355 S.C. 245, 249, 584 S.E.2d 438, 440 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Iâ€™on, L.L.C.Â  v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 411, 526 S.E.2d 716, 718-19 (2000)).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Ownership
Galloway contends the special referee erred in finding the decedent owned forty percent of the corporation.Â  He contends the evidence established that the decedent never paid for any shares of stock, as requested by Galloway.Â  We disagree.Â  
The evidence presented at trial supports the special refereeâ€™s findings.Â  One of the witnesses, Patricia Sparks, a bookkeeper for Price Bookkeeping and Tax Service, testified she had prepared tax returns for Galloway Furniture for a number of years.Â  At one point, Galloway and the decedent brought papers to her office and told her that the corporate papers were to be changed so that the decedent would have a share in the corporation. Â She did not remember the exact percentages each were to retain but did remember that Galloway was to retain a greater percentage than decedent.Â  Galloway told her to issue shares in both Gallowayâ€™s and the decedentâ€™s names.Â  A copy of the stock certificates with both Galloway and the decedentâ€™s names was entered into evidence.Â  
As to the question of whether the decedent failed to pay for his shares, Sparksâ€™ testimony at a previous deposition was that it was her understanding the decedent was not required to pay for his shares of stock because they were issued to him in return for the work he did for the business and for his help in building the business.Â  She said this understanding was based on what both the decedent and Galloway had told her.Â  However, at trial Sparks testified that at some point Galloway told her that the decedent was supposed to have paid for the shares but never did.Â  Â Â 
The special referee also based its decision on the testimony of Kirk Messick, the certified public accountant that did all the accounting for Galloway Furniture after Sparks.Â  Messick testified that in examining the books and records presented to him when he began working for Galloway, he noticed that the decedent and his social security number were both listed on the previous yearâ€™s tax return under Compensation of Officers.Â  Messick further testified that at the time he took over the bookkeeping from Price Accounting Service and Sparks, the records showed that the decedent was a forty percent owner of the business.Â  
The only testimony presented at trial to show the decedent did not own shares of Galloway Furniture was that of Galloway himself and his repeated assertions that decedent did not pay for his shares.Â  However, the testimony of the other witnesses clearly supported the special refereeâ€™s finding that decedent owned forty percent of the corporation and that the consideration for those shares was his work for the corporation.Â  Furthermore, by this courtâ€™s calculation, the number of shares listed on the stock certificates in the record showed decedent owned forty percent of the corporation.[2]Â  Â Â Given the special referee was in a better position to judge the creditability of the witnessesâ€™ testimony and the ample evidence in the record, we defer to his finding that decedent owned forty percent of the corporation. Â See Tiger, at 237, 391 S.E.2d at 543.Â  
II.Â  Statute of LimitationsÂ  
Galloway contends the special referee erred in failing to dismiss the causes of action based on the applicable statute of limitations.Â  Specifically, Galloway contends the suit is untimely because the heirs should have known about the suit in September 1998, when their father passed away, yet the suit was not filed until 2002, four years later.Â  We disagree.Â  
Both the 1998 action filed by the decedent and the 2002 action filed by the heirs maintained the same causes of action: judicial dissolution of the corporation and court-ordered sale of shares.Â  The 1998 action was never dismissed, but was ended on January 16, 1998 pursuant to a consent order appointing a special referee. Â Galloway never moved to have the 1998 case dismissed.Â  
Section 15-3-530(9) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides a statute of limitations of three years in cases involving an action against the directors or stockholders of a corporation to enforce a liability.Â  This cause of action is not considered to have accrued until the date of discovery by the aggrieved parties of the facts upon which the liability is created.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(9) (Supp. 2005).Â  In the instant case, Mark Watt did not discover that his fatherâ€™s ownership in the corporation was at question until a discussion with Galloway in November 2001.Â  Until this time, Mark Wattâ€™s previous conversations with Galloway indicated the decedent had at least some ownership in the corporation.Â  After Mark Watt realized his fatherâ€™s shares were in dispute, he contacted a lawyer and filed the present action on October 18, 2002, well within the three year statute of limitations period.Â  Accordingly, the special referee was correct in finding the instant action was filed within the applicable statute of limitations.Â 
    CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the special refereeâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The number of shares shown on the stock certificates as owned by Galloway is 58,137.Â  The number of shares shown on the stock certificates to be owned by the deceased is 38,758.Â  As Sparks testified there were only two stock certificates issued for the corporation, the total shares issued was 96,895.Â  Exactly forty percent of the total number of shares issued is 38,758, the number of shares shown to be owned by the decedent.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Ex Parte:
        Murdell McFarlin, individually and as daughter and next friend of Floyd B. Walker, Sr., an incapacitated person, Appellant,
        In the matter of Floyd B. Walker, Sr.
        
        v.
        James H. Renfrow, Jr., Guardian ad Litem, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-073
Heard January 9, 2007 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, 
DISMISSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Jan L. Warner, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
        James H. Renfrow, Jr., of Dillon, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Â In this probate matter, Murdell McFarlin appeals orders of the circuit and probate courts based on lack of jurisdiction and ex parte communication.Â  We affirm in part, vacate in part, and dismiss the remainder as moot. 
FACTS
In March of 2000, McFarlin applied to the judge of the Marlboro County Probate Court to be appointed guardian and conservator for her father, Floyd B. Walker. Â After a hearing, the probate court appointed McFarlin as guardian but held the issue of conservatorship in abeyance.Â  The probate court appointed Ralph Kelly guardian ad litem in the conservatorship proceedings.Â  McFarlin was eventually appointed conservator. Â 
McFarlin filed the conservatorâ€™s annual accounting for the years 2001, 2002, and 2003.Â  In February 2003, the probate judge informed McFarlin by letter that she failed to use the accounting method and format required by the probate court in her annual accountings.Â  In July of 2004, the probate judge informed McFarlin the conservatorship would be audited, and required her to provide bank records and other supporting documentation within thirty days.Â  McFarlin contacted accountant David E. Martin to review the documents and assist her in preparing an accounting.Â  McFarlin also retained an attorney to represent her.Â  
On October 22, 2004, the probate judge summoned McFarlin to appear at a hearing set for November 30, 2004, and to produce all financial records and accounting.Â  Prior to the hearing, the judge and the judgeâ€™s secretary investigated McFarlinâ€™s records and issued subpoenas for cellular phone and bank records.Â  On November 22, 2004, the probate judge held a pre-trial conference and informed McFarlinâ€™s attorney he had concerns about the handling of Walkerâ€™s finances based on his and his secretaryâ€™s investigation. Â Although McFarlinâ€™s accountant stated he had reconciled the accounts, the judge allegedly refused to review these records, finding them â€œjust too much to go through.â€Â  The judge also allegedly concluded McFarlinâ€™s hiring of an attorney indicated guilt, and if she â€œpressed for a hearing,â€ he would â€œturn [her] over to the Solicitorâ€ to face criminal charges.Â  At the pretrial conference, the probate judge decided to cancel the hearing scheduled for November 30, and in its place directed McFarlinâ€™s attorney and the guardian, Kelly, to meet on November 30 at the attorneyâ€™s office to review the financial records and accounting.Â  
Kelly failed to appear at the meeting. Â He was, instead, at a hearing being held in probate court, apparently without the knowledge of McFarlin or any of her representatives.Â  As a result of that hearing, the probate judge issued an ex parte order freezing Walkerâ€™s accounts, finding McFarlin had â€œexpended funds from the . . . accounts in a manner that does not comply with the South Carolina Statute for Conservators. . . .Â  Until the court may conduct a full hearing on the merits . . . the conservator shall not administer or distribute any of the protected personâ€™s assets. . . .â€ Â The probate judge also summoned McFarlin to appear at a hearing on January 10, 2005 to review the accounting and ordered her to forward Walkerâ€™s bills to his attention. Â 
In December, McFarlinâ€™s current attorney replaced her original attorney and appealed the order freezing accounts to the circuit court.Â  A few days later, and while the appeal was pending, the probate court appointed James H. Renfrow, Jr. as guardian ad litem and attorney for Walker.Â  That same day, Renfrow filed a petition requesting:Â  (1) McFarlin provide a full and complete accounting; (2) McFarlin be removed and a successor conservator appointed; (3) a temporary conservator be appointed until a successor conservator could be appointed; and (4) McFarlin be required to pay actual and punitive damages if the accounting proved the funds had been misappropriated.Â  
Shortly thereafter, McFarlin moved to vacate all orders and recuse the probate judge on the grounds of:Â  (1) lack of jurisdiction; (2) failure to comply with the statutory law of South Carolina; and (3) violation of judicial ethics, including ex parte communications, threatening criminal prosecution, self-investigating, and advising McFarlin she should not seek counsel.Â  
On January 10, 2005, the probate judge held a hearing on Renfrowâ€™s motion for the appointment of a temporary conservator and a continuance.Â  The probate judge granted Renfrowâ€™s request for a temporary conservator.Â  McFarlin filed a second notice of appeal on January 19, 2005, and on January 28, 2005 the probate judge granted Renfrowâ€™s motion for a continuance, but denied McFarlinâ€™s motion to vacate and recuse himself. Â McFarlin filed a supplemental notice of appeal on January 28, 2005.Â  The probate judge filed a return with the circuit court on February 9, 2005.Â  The probate judge then, on February 17, 2005, recused himself from any further participation in the matter. Â 
In March of 2005, the circuit court heard the appeals brought by McFarlin and issued an â€œundatedâ€ order remanding the case to the substitute probate judge for rulings, and suggesting the probate judge notify law enforcement should he discover any criminal discrepancies.Â  On April 28, 2005, McFarlin moved to reconsider the circuit courtâ€™s order.Â  On June 2, 2005, the circuit courtâ€™s law clerk went to the probate judgeâ€™s office and retrieved the original files from the guardianship and conservatorship proceedings. Â Six days later, on June 8, 2005, the circuit court issued an amended order, affirming the probate court.Â  This appeal followed.Â  During the pendency of this appeal, Walker died and McFarlin was appointed executor by the Fulton County, Georgia, Probate Court. Â 
APPEALABILITY
Renfrow, the guardian ad litem, argues the appeal should be dismissed as interlocutory and not immediately appealable.Â  We disagree.
The probate courtâ€™s order froze the accounts â€œuntil a court may conduct a full hearing on the merits.â€Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order affirmed the probate court.Â  An order freezing the accounts is in the nature of an injunction.Â  Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 367 S.C. 1, 5, 623 S.E.2d 833, 835 (2005) (interpreting order freezing assets as an injunction).Â  Under the South Carolina Code, injunctions are immediately appealable.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(4) (Supp. 2006); Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 308 S.C. 125, 127, 417 S.E.2d 532, 534 (1992) (finding order in the nature of an injunction immediately appealable).Â  We accordingly find the circuit court order, although interlocutory in nature, immediately appealable.
ISSUES ON APPEAL
I.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
McFarlin initially argues the probate court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to enter the orders appointing a guardian and temporary conservator due to the failure to comply with statutory requirements.Â  We disagree.
â€œSubject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 150, 526 S.E.2d 222, 227 (2000).Â  The probate court has subject matter jurisdiction over incapacitated persons.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 62-1-302(a)(2) & 62-5-102(a) (Supp. 2006).Â  The probate court may have violated the statutory requirements to observe conditions and report to the court and the statutory requirements governing the medical examination of the person alleged to be incapacitated.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 62-5-303(b) (examinations regarding guardianships) & 62-5-407(b) (examinations regarding conservatorships) (1987).Â  However, the alleged violations of statutory requirements did not deprive the probate court of its subject matter jurisdiction over incapacitated persons.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Meek, 352 S.C. 523, 530, 575 S.E.2d 846, 849 (Ct. App. 2002) (finding failure to comply with statutory requirements did not divest the family court of subject matter jurisdiction). 
II.Â  Judicial Conduct
McFarlin contends the circuit court erred by failing to vacate orders issued by the probate judge based on the probate judgeâ€™s alleged judicial misconduct.Â  â€œThe Commission [on Judicial Conduct] has jurisdiction over judges regarding allegations that misconduct occurred before or during service as a judge . . . .â€Â  Rule 3(b)(1), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR (Supp. 2006).Â  As this court has no authority regarding this issue, we decline to address it.Â  
III. Â Ex Parte Communication
McFarlin also alleges the circuit court erred by issuing a ruling after allegedly engaging in ex parte communication with the probate judge.Â  We disagree.
Ex parte communication consists of â€œprohibited communication between counsel and the court when opposing counsel is not present.â€Â  Brown v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 354 S.C. 436, 440 n.3, 581 S.E.2d 836, 838 n.3 (2003).Â  In this case, the circuit courtâ€™s law clerk retrieved the probate courtâ€™s files in the guardianship and conservatorship proceedings, including records not provided to McFarlin.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308(b) (Supp. 2006) (requiring the probate court to file a return when an appeal is taken to the circuit court).Â  
The records purportedly contained handwritten memos and notations of the probate judge taken during the guardianship and conservatorship proceedings.Â  After reviewing the probate courtâ€™s records, the circuit court issued an amended order affirming the judgment of the probate judge.Â  
McFarlin argues the circuit courtâ€™s review of the probate judgeâ€™s memos and notations permitted the probate judge to have an ex parte voice in the appeal to the circuit court, in violation of section 62-1-308 of the South Carolina Code.Â  Section 62-1-308(f) provides:Â  â€œA judge of a probate court must not be admitted to have any voice in judging or determining an appeal from his decision or be permitted to act as attorney or counsel.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308(f) (Supp. 2006).Â  We decline to equate the circuit courtâ€™s review of the probate judgeâ€™s file with the inappropriate participation by a probate judge in an appeal.Â  Furthermore, the alleged ex parte communication involved communications between the courts, and is therefore not violative of the general rule prohibiting ex parte communication.Â  Accordingly, we find no reversible error on this ground.Â  
IV.Â  Issuance of Orders Following Notices of Appeal
McFarlin contends the circuit court erred by not finding the probate judge improperly continued to issue orders after notices of appeal had been filed and served and argues this court should vacate the probate court orders.Â  We agree in part. 
The timing of relevant events is determinative of this issue.Â  The events occurred as follows:

  
    3/22/00:
    McFarlin petitions to be appointed guardian. 
  
  
    4/25/00: 
    Order appointing McFarlin guardian.  
      Order appointing Ralph Kelly guardian ad litem. 
    
  
  
    Jan. 2001: 
    Order appointing McFarlin conservator. 
  
  
    11/30/04:
    Order freezing accounts. 
  
  
    12/9/04:  
    Notice of appeal of 11/30/04 order filed. 
  
  
    12/30/04:  
    Probate court order appointing Renfrow guardian ad litem. 
  
  
    1/10/05: 
    Probate court order denying McFarlin’s motions to vacate and recuse. 
  
  
    1/13/05:
    Probate court order appointing temporary conservator. 
  
  
    1/19/05:
    Second notice of appeal filed, appealing order appointing temporary conservator and orders denying McFarlin’s motions. 
  
  
    1/28/05:
    Probate court order granting Renfrow’s motion for continuance; denying McFarlin’s motions. 
  
  
    1/28/05:
    Supplemental notice of appeal of the January 28, 2005 order filed.  
  

The probate code provides:Â  â€œWhen an appeal according to law is taken from any sentence or decree of the probate court, all proceedings in pursuance of the order, sentence, or decree appealed from shall cease until the judgment of the [appellate court] is had.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308(c) (Supp. 2006).Â  The circuit court acts solely as an appellate court in appeals from the probate court.Â  Id.Â  â€œUpon the service of the notice of appeal, the appellate court shall have exclusive jurisdiction over the appeal.â€Â  Rule 205, SCACR (Supp. 2006).Â  Once the notice of appeal is served, the circuit court has exclusive jurisdiction except for matters not affected by the appeal.Â  Bunkum v. Manor Props., 321 S.C. 95, 98-99, 467 S.E.2d 758, 760 (Ct. App. 1996). 
We find the probate court lost jurisdiction over the matters affected by the appeal after McFarlin filed and served the notice of appeal of the November 30, 2004 order.Â  We find all issues addressed by the probate court thereafter, except the issue appointing Renfrow as substitute guardian ad litem in the December 30, 2004 order, were affected by the appeal.Â  Accordingly, we vacate the probate court orders dated January 10, 2005 and January 28, 2005.
As to the December 30, 2004 order appointing Renfrow substitute guardian ad litem, we conclude the probate court had continuing jurisdiction over this matter, even after the notice of appeal was filed.Â  However, we also find this order effective only until the date of Walkerâ€™s death.Â  Beyond that date, the guardianship expired.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-5-306 (1987) (terminating the authority of a guardian upon the death of the ward).Â  
V.Â  Probate Court Orders Issued Without Findings of Fact; Factual Findings Made Without a Hearing
McFarlin contends the circuit court erred by not finding the probate court issued orders affecting substantial rights of McFarlin and Walker without making findings of material facts and allegations.Â  We need not address this issue based on the disposition of the case.Â  
McFarlin also argues the probate court erred in making the factual finding in its November 30, 2004 order, without a hearing, that McFarlin had â€œexpended funds from the . . . accounts in a manner that does not comply with the S.C. Statute for Conservators. . . .â€Â  We need not address this issue as it is moot due to Walkerâ€™s death.Â  The Georgia Probate Court in Fulton County has jurisdiction over Walkerâ€™s estate and, accordingly, the matters pending in the South Carolina Probate Court, pursuant to the circuit courtâ€™s order, are moot.Â  â€œA case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon existing controversy.Â  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.â€Â  Byrd v. Irmo High School, 321 S.C. 426, 431, 468 S.E.2d 861, 864 (1996) (quoting Mathis v. S.C. State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973)).Â  In this case, Walkerâ€™s death moots the issues surrounding McFarlinâ€™s handling of Walkerâ€™s affairs in the jurisdiction of the probate court of Marlboro County.Â  
VI.Â  Circuit Courtâ€™s Orders
McFarlin argues the circuit court erred in making findings of fact and issuing rulings with regard to issues not on appeal to the circuit court.Â  The order on appeal to the circuit court was the November 30, 2004 order freezing all accounts in the name of either Floyd B. Walker, Jr. or Murdell W. McFarlin.
Pursuant to the provisions of the probate code, a hearing on an appeal from the probate court â€œmust be strictly on appeal and no new evidence must be presented.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-308(d) (Supp. 2006).Â  In her notice of appeal, McFarlin raised procedural and jurisdictional issues and the failure of the probate judge to recuse himself.Â  We agree that in its order the circuit court made factual findings that exceeded the scope of its jurisdiction on appeal and were based on new evidence on which no finding was made by the probate court in the order on appeal.Â  To the extent the circuit court made factual findings as to improper expenditures on the part of McFarlin, the order of the circuit court is vacated.Â  
The circuit court also affirmed the probate courtâ€™s order to the effect that all the accounts are frozen.Â  Because of the death of Floyd B. Walker, both the guardianship and conservatorship are terminated, and any issues pending in the probate court of Marlboro County are likewise terminated.Â  Any persons having claims related to the conduct of the conservatorship may have recourse in the Georgia Probate Court, or as may be otherwise indicated.
CONCLUSION
We initially find the order on appeal to be interlocutory but immediately appealable.Â  We decline to rule on the allegations of judicial misconduct or the probate courtâ€™s factual findings.Â  We affirm on the issues of subject matter jurisdiction and ex parte communications.Â  We likewise affirm the circuit courtâ€™s order to the extent it affirmed the probate courtâ€™s appointment of a guardian ad litem until Walkerâ€™s death.Â  We vacate the circuit courtâ€™s order to the extent it made factual findings as to the propriety of McFarlinâ€™s expenditures.Â  We finally dismiss the order as moot to the extent it affirms the probate courtâ€™s order to set a hearing date on the propriety of McFarlinâ€™s expenditures. 
AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED IN PART, DISMISSED IN PART.
GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.
