THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Charles Smalls, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Aiken County 
Â Brooks P. Goldsmith, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-074
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Ailleen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott;
        Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, Â for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charles Smalls appeals his convictions for two counts of first degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor, and lewd act upon a child. Â Smalls argues the trial judge abused his discretion by allowing the State to present inadmissible hearsay testimony. Â We affirm.
FACTS
Smalls was accused of sexually molesting his girlfriendâ€™s eight-year-old granddaughter (Victim).Â  Shortly after the alleged assault, the police took Victim to the hospital, where she was examined by Nurse Amanda Abbott.Â  Nurse Abbot witnessed the external genitalia exam conducted by Doctor Platt, who found no physical evidence of sexual abuse.[1]Â  
Nurse Abbot, whom the lower court qualified as an expert in â€œsexual assault nurse examination,â€ testified that she conducted the interview for the purposes of medical diagnosis and treatment, and evidence collection. Â Nurse Abbottâ€™s testimony describing Victimâ€™s account was as follows:

  [Victim] went into detail to tell me what happened to her earlier in the evening . . . . She just said that he was in the trailer with her and that he â€“ she was in the kitchen and he pushed her into the bathroom and when she did, she hit her elbow on the bathtub.Â  And he grabbed her by the hand to take her into the bedroom.
  While they were in the bathroom, he had pulled up her skirt and pulled her panties down.Â  When they went into the bedroom, he had gotten a red thing out of the drawer and put it on his private parts.Â  He started touching himself and white stuff went into the red thing.Â  He was touching her private parts with his hand.Â  And grandma came into the room.Â  

When asked if Victim indicated whether there was digital penetration, Nurse Abbott responded: â€œYes, she did.â€Â  Although Nurse Abbott did not describe â€œdigital penetrationâ€ in her written summary of Victimâ€™s testimony, she checked off â€œdigital penetrationâ€ on an attached checklist.Â  
Smalls timely objected to Nurse Abbottâ€™s testimony recounting Victimâ€™s story, arguing it was hearsay exceeding the scope of the medical diagnosis exception in Rule 803(4), SCRE.Â  Pursuant to this objection, the trial judge allowed Smalls to obtain a proffer of exactly what testimony the State would elicit from Nurse Abbot in order to be able to more fully argue his objection.Â  Thus, outside the presence of the jury, the State examined Nurse Abbott in substantially the same way, eliciting substantially the same testimony as that presented to the jury and described above.Â  Then, after hearing arguments from both parties, the trial judge overruled Smallsâ€™ objection.[2]Â  
Victim, who was nine years old at the trial, testified in detail.Â  She provided an account consistent to that later provided by her grandmother and Nurse Abbott, but also describing Smalls penetrating her digitally, and attempting penile penetration.Â  Victim testified about talking to Nurse Abbott afterwards, but said that she did not tell her everything because she was afraid.Â  
 In addition, Victimâ€™s grandmother testified that as she walked into the trailer, she heard Victim say â€œQuit, Charles,â€ and saw Smalls zipping up his pants.Â  Victimâ€™s grandmother also testified about what Victim told her about the incident.Â  This testimony was consistent with Victimâ€™s account, including the penile penetration but not mentioning digital penetration. Â Although the grandmotherâ€™s written statement did not specifically state that Victim reported penile penetration, it did state that he put a condom â€œon his [penis], . . . and . . . he was messing with her, it wonâ€™t hurt â€“ it wonâ€™t hurt her.â€Â  
The jury convicted Smalls of two counts of first degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor, and one count of lewd act upon a child.Â  He was sentenced to two concurrent terms of twenty years imprisonment suspended on service of thirteen years imprisonment and three years probation, and a concurrent term of ten years imprisonment and service of three years probation, respectively. Â This appeal followed.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
A trial judgeâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Only errors so substantial that they result in a verdict which would not otherwise have been rendered require reversal.Â  State v. Jolly, 304 S.C. 34, 39, 402 S.E.2d 895, 898 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  A defendant seeking reversal based on error in admission of evidence has the burden of showing that evidence was prejudicial.Â  State v. McElveen, 280 S.C. 325, 327, 313 S.E.2d 298, 299 (1984).Â  Improperly admitted hearsay which is merely cumulative to other evidence may be viewed as harmless.Â  State v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 329, 247 S.E.2d 334, 337 (1978).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Smalls argues the trial judge abused his discretion by allowing the State to present Nurse Abbottâ€™s hearsay testimony. Specifically, Smalls argues that testimony from Nurse Abbott describing digital penetration was hearsay outside the scope of the medical exception.Â  We disagree.
Rule 803(4), SCRE, permits the introduction of hearsay for â€œpurpose of medical diagnosis or treatment,â€ stating:

  Statements made for the purpose of medical diagnosis or treatment and describing medical history, or past or present symptoms, pain, or sensations, or the inception or general character of the cause or external source therefore insofar as reasonably pertinent to diagnosis or treatment . . . .

Smalls points out that during Abbottâ€™s in-camera proffer, she diagnosed the victim with â€œalleged sexual assault,â€ but that during her trial testimony no medical diagnosis or conclusion was presented to the jury.Â  This is irrelevant because the â€œmedical exceptionâ€ to the hearsay rule does not require that testimony be introduced for the purpose of presenting a medical diagnosis.[3]Â  Rather, the rule requires that the statements introduced were made for the purpose of medical diagnosis or treatment.Â  See Rule 803(4), SCRE.
Smalls references this courtâ€™s case of State v. Burroughs, 328 S.C. 489, 492 S.E.2d 408 (Ct. App. 1997), to support his contention that Nurse Abbottâ€™s testimony was inadmissible.Â  His reliance on Burroughs is ill-founded, as it is readily distinguishable from this case.Â  In Burroughs, a statement that an alleged rapist â€œasked for a hugâ€ was found outside the scope of the â€œmedical diagnosisâ€ exception because it was not â€œreasonably pertinentâ€ to the victimâ€™s diagnosis or treatment.Â  In contrast, Nurse Abbottâ€™s testimony addressed the physical contact described by Victim and the use of a condom during the alleged assault.Â  The extent of physical contact in a sexual assault is certainly reasonably pertinent to medical diagnosis and treatment, so as to assess the extent of possible physical injury.Â  The use of condoms is reasonably pertinent to diagnosis and treatment of possible sexually transmitted disease and pregnancy.Â  
Smallsâ€™ reference to State v. Brown is likewise unhelpful because Nurse Abbott did not introduce Victimâ€™s identification of Smalls. State v. Brown, 286 S.C. 445, 334 S.E.2d 816 (1985) (holding victimâ€™s identification of alleged rapist examination was inadmissible hearsay because perpetratorâ€™s name was not necessary for diagnosis and treatment). 
The trial judgeâ€™s careful adherence to the limitations of the medical exception is evidenced by his requiring the exclusion of testimony by Nurse Abbott about the lubricant used by Smalls in the alleged assault. Â We therefore find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s admission of Nurse Abbottâ€™s testimony.Â  
CONCLUSION 
Based on the foregoing, Smallsâ€™ convictions for first degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor, and lewd act upon a child areÂ  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Dr. Platt did not perform an internal genitalia exam because the hospital did not have the specialized equipment required to examine a small child. 
[2] The judge forbade the State from referencing lubricants in the testimony before the jury, reasoning that that portion of Victimâ€™s story did not fall under the medical diagnosis exception.Â  (R. 182).Â  
[3] Hearsay, including that excepted under the â€œmedical exceptionâ€, is that species of testimony given by a witness who relates, not what she knows personally, but what others have told her, or what she has heard said by others.Â  It is a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.Â  Fed.R.Evid. 801(c).

PER CURIAM:Â  Hassan Trent appeals his conviction for possession of heroin with intent to distribute in close proximity to a school or playground.Â

        v.
        Thomas Andrew Gallagher, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-076
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 13, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jessica Ann Salvini, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this criminal appeal, Thomas Andrew Gallagher appeals the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of his appeal from a disorderly conduct conviction in magistrateâ€™s court.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2) and the following authorities:[1] 
1.Â  As to Gallagherâ€™s failure to appeal the circuit courtâ€™s finding that service of the notice of appeal was never perfected on the magistrate:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-30 (Supp. 2004); Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (holding an unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case).
2.Â  As to the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of his appeal from magistrateâ€™s court:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-3-30 (Supp. 2004); State v. Brown, 358 S.C. 382, 387, 596 S.E.2d 39, 41 (2004) (holding the failure of a party to comply with the procedural requirements for perfecting an appeal from magistrateâ€™s court deprives the circuit court of appellate jurisdiction over the case).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Dennis Harold Crowe, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-077
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 13, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina Theos Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â Dennis Harold Crowe, Jr. appeals his murder conviction.Â  He argues the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
At approximately 3 A.M. on June 20, 2003, Dennis Harold Crowe, Jr. sought emergency assistance for his girlfriend Roberta Flora Davis (Bertie).Â  He informed the 911 dispatcher that Bertie was not breathing, and he thought she was dead.Â  An ambulance and the police were dispatched to the residence which Crowe and Bertie shared at 111 Short Street in Salem.Â  
Upon arriving at the residence, the police found Bertie lying dead in her bed.Â  Crowe, who appeared to be inebriated, stated that she had fallen during the day.Â  The police noted that three other individuals, all of whom appeared inebriated, were present at the residence.Â  
The Oconee County Coroner (Coroner) arrived at the residence at approximately 4:03 A.M. and spoke with Crowe concerning Bertie.Â  As per Coronerâ€™s testimony, Crowe informed Coroner that he and Bertie had been drinking all day, and she fell.Â  Crowe told Coroner that he attempted to assist Bertie into the cab of a pick-up truck, but when this was unsuccessful, he placed her in the bed of the truck and drove her to their residence where she fell again.Â  Coroner further testified that Crowe stated that Bertie urinated and defecated on herself whereupon Crowe and another female bathed Bertie and put her to bed at 6:30 P.M.Â  Â 
Dr. Brett Woodard performed an autopsy on Bertie and determined her cause of death to be a subdural hematoma brought on by blunt force trauma to her head.Â  Dr. Woodard found there were twenty or twenty five definite blows sustained by Bertie and estimated that if overlapping blows were calculated, she was struck approximately forty times.Â  While he could not rule out that any single one of Bertieâ€™s injuries were caused by a fall, Dr. Woodard found her injuries to be inconsistent with a fall or multiple falls and consistent with being repeatedly struck during an attack.Â  Dr. Woodard testified that Bertie had defensive wounds on her hands, arms, legs and feet as though she were defending herself from an attack.Â  Further, Dr. Woodard determined to a reasonable degree of medical certainty that the subdural hematoma sustained by Bertie was caused by a blow to her head and not a fall.Â  Â Â Â 
There was evidence presented in the form of testimony from multiple witnesses that Crowe had previously been physically abusive to Bertie.Â  One witness testified that three days prior to Bertieâ€™s death, Crowe stated he should kill Bertie for lying to him concerning the fact that she had dated a black man thirty years prior to dating him.Â  
An Oconee County jury found Crowe guilty of murder, and the trial court sentenced him to forty-seven years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court will not reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding jury charges absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.Â  If any evidence exists to support a jury charge, the trial judge should grant the requested charge.Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999).Â  A refusal to grant a requested jury charge which states a sound principle of law applicable to the case at hand is an error of law.Â  Clark, 339 S.C. at 390, 529 S.E.2d at 539.Â Â  A court should only refuse to charge the jury on manslaughter if there is no evidence tending to reduce the crime from murder to manslaughter.Â  State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 S.E.2d 391, 394 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Crowe contends the trial court erred in denying his request to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter.Â  We disagree.

  Involuntary manslaughter is defined as either (1) the killing of another without malice and unintentionally, but while one is engaged in the commission of some unlawful act not amounting to a felony and not naturally tending to cause death or great bodily harm; or (2) the killing of another without malice and unintentionally, but while one is acting lawfully, with reckless disregard for the safety of others.

Knoten, 347 S.C. at 309, 555 S.E.2d at 398.Â  Involuntary manslaughter requires a finding of criminal negligence, which is statutorily defined as a reckless disregard of the safety of others.Â  State v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 52, 584 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2003); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-60 (Supp. 2006).Â  Accordingly, a defendant is entitled to an involuntary manslaughter charge only where the evidence establishes his reckless disregard for the safety of others.Â  
In this matter, the record fails to establish the necessary elements for a charge of involuntary manslaughter.Â  The first of the above definitions is immediately eliminated from our consideration because in Croweâ€™s account of the events leading to Bertieâ€™s death, there is no evidence that he was engaged in any unlawful act.Â  However, Crowe asserts he was entitled to an involuntary manslaughter charge under the second definition because his continuing to stand Bertie up just so she could fall down again constituted a reckless disregard for her safety.Â  However, there is no evidence in the record that this occurred.[2]Â  The only evidence regarding Croweâ€™s characterizations of his actions with Bertie illustrates an attempt to help her.Â  In fact, Croweâ€™s trial attorney stressed the fact that Crowe should receive a manslaughter charge because he â€œhelpedâ€ Bertie.Â  He stated that â€œbecause of the facts that were brought out as far as helpingâ€ including calling 911, Crowe was entitled to a manslaughter charge.Â  We fail to see how Croweâ€™s account of the events in which he attempted to help Bertie could constitute the reckless disregard for her safety necessary to entitle him to an involuntary manslaughter charge.Â  Because the record demonstrates as a matter of law the absence of a required element of involuntary manslaughter, the trial judge did not err in refusing to charge on that offense.
CONCLUSION
We find no error by the trial court in refusing to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter.Â  Based on the foregoing, Croweâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In Croweâ€™s request for an involuntary manslaughter charge, which was held outside the juryâ€™s presence, his attorney stated seeing Bertie fall down repeatedly and not helping would be reckless disregard for her safety.Â  There is no mention of standing her up just so that she could fall down again until it is noted in Croweâ€™s appeal brief.Â  In any event, neither of these assertions appears in the evidence in the record on appeal.Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Andre Terrance Auls, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-078
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 13, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant,
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Andre Terrance Auls appeals his convictions for resisting arrest with a deadly weapon, assault and battery with intent to kill (ABWIK),Â  and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent offense.Â  He argues the trial court erred in improperly commenting upon the facts of the case during its instructions to the jury.Â  We affirm.[1]Â Â Â Â Â  
FACTS
On July 31, 2002, four city police officers went to a residence to arrest Andre Terrance Auls.Â  When they arrived, one officer, Peppers, was sent to the back of the residence to ensure that Auls would not flee.Â  The other three officers approached the front porch of the residence and asked Auls to come off the porch and into the front yard to speak with them.Â  Auls complied, and the officers instructed him to put his hands on the hood of the police car.Â  Auls followed the instruction, but the officers testified that when he was told he was being arrested, he stood up, reached behind his back and pulled a gun from the waistband of his pants.Â  A struggle between Auls and the officers ensued, and Officer Atkins was shot in the hip.Â Â  
Officer Peppers responded from behind the house and called for backup.Â  With Officers Gray and Butler continuing to struggle with Auls, the backup officer (Pratt) arrived and pepper sprayed Auls, whereupon he was subdued.Â  The police arrested Auls and charged him with resisting arrest with a deadly weapon, assault and battery with intent to kill (ABWIK), and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent offense.Â Â Â  
A Greenwood County jury found Auls guilty of all charges.Â  The trial judge sentenced Auls to consecutive prison terms of five years for resisting arrest with a deadly weapon, sixteen years for assault and battery with intent to kill, and five years for possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent offense.[2]Â  This appeal followed. Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  An appellate court will not reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding jury charges absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.Â  Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Auls contends the trial court erred in its charge to the jury by improperly commenting on the facts of the case.Â  We disagree.
Article V, Â§ 21 of the South Carolina Constitution states:Â  â€œJudges shall not charge juries in respect to matters of fact, but shall declare the law.â€Â  South Carolina law dictates that a trial judge should refrain from any comment which tends to indicate to the jury his opinion on the credibility of the witnesses, the weight of the evidence, or the guilt of the accused.Â  State v. Jackson, 297 S.C. 523, 526, 377 S.E.2d 570, 572 (1989).Â  However, jury instructions must be considered in their entirety and, if in their entirety, they are free from error, then any potentially misleading portions do not constitute reversible error.Â  Id.Â  Â 
Auls objects to the charge to the jury regarding the definitions of â€œassaultâ€ and â€œbatteryâ€ and â€œinferred malice.â€Â  The trial court instructed the jury on the definition of â€œassaultâ€ and â€œbattery,â€ and then utilized the examples of being hit with a baseball bat or being shot with a gun.Â  The court stated:Â  â€œAssault, hit you with the bat, carrying through is the battery.Â  Assault pointing a gun, cocking it, shooting it, bullet enters your body, itâ€™s a battery.Â  Assault and battery.â€Â  The trial court went on to instruct the jury regarding â€œinferred maliceâ€ as follows:Â  

  What is inferred malice?Â  Thatâ€™s the implication of malice because of the existence or the possession of, for instance, a deadly weapon which is calculated to produce death or serious bodily harm.Â  You have already been told that a deadly weapon or instrument are [sic] weapons which are made or designed for offensive or defensive purposes or from which destruction of life or the infliction of injury may likely occur, one which in the manner used is calculated or likely to produce death or serious bodily injury.

Auls further notes that the trial court, in its earlier jury instruction regarding the definition of a deadly weapon, specifically noted a â€œfirearmâ€ as being a deadly weapon.Â  Auls believes these instructions are the result of the trial court impermissibly commenting of the facts of the case.
We conclude that the trial courtâ€™s remarks served only an explanatory function and did not offer an improper comment regarding the facts of the case.Â  The instruction to the jury included several examples of what constitutes both a deadly weapon and an assault and battery, and there was no mention of the specific facts of this case.Â  We find no error with the inferred malice instruction and we note the trial court immediately followed the above quoted inferred malice instruction by stating:

  If facts are proved beyond a reasonable doubt to your satisfaction sufficient to raise an inference of malice, this inference would simply be an evidentiary fact to be taken into consideration by you the jury, along with any other evidence in the case, and you may give it such weight as you determine it should receive.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â 

(emphasis added).Â  
Just as considering the instruction regarding â€œinferred maliceâ€ in its entirety lends credence to the propriety of the trial courtâ€™s instructions, so too does a consideration of the entire jury instruction.Â  Near the outset of the trial courtâ€™s charge to the jury, the court instructed:

  If you have drawn any inference from anything the court has done, said, or any ruling the court has made on any motion, movement or acts of the court in any way, then you should disabuse yourself of it.Â  The Court has no interest in the outcome of this trial.Â  The Court has tried to be and hopefully has succeeded in being fair to both parties in this trial.Â  Make nothing of the Courtâ€™s rulings on motions or anything you may have thought indicated the Courtâ€™s feeling about this case or the evidence in this case, completely disabuse yourself of it.Â  

The court went on to instruct the jurors that they were the sole finders of fact and the sole judges of credibility and that the court had no right to pass upon the facts of the case.Â  Subsequent to its instructions regarding assault and battery and inferred malice, the trial court again instructed the jury regarding this issue thusly â€œof course you are to draw no inference from the courtâ€™s remarks, as the court has instructed you.â€Â 
Further, this court must ascertain what a reasonable juror would have understood the charge to mean.Â  Jackson, 297 S.C. at 527, 377 S.E.2d at 572.Â  We find it unlikely that a reasonable juror could have singled out this portion of the charge and interpreted it as the courtâ€™s opinion on the facts of this case.
CONCLUSION
We find no error by the trial court in its charge to the jury.Â  Based on the foregoing, Aulsâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] These sentences are also consecutive to the sentence Auls was already serving pursuant to his previous guilty plea for armed robbery.Â  Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Tyrone Graddick, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-079
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 13, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III , Office of South Carolina Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tyrone Graddick appeals from an Alford plea to the charges of criminal sexual conduct in the first degree (CSC) and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Graddick argues the plea judge erred in informing him of his right to appeal as that impermissibly converted his Alford plea into a conditional plea, which is disallowed in South Carolina under State v. Truesdale  278 S.C. 368, 370, 296 S.E.2d 528, 529 (1982).Â  We disagree, and affirm.[1]Â  Informing a defendant of his right to appeal does not convert an otherwise unconditional plea into a conditional plea. 
I.
Graddick was indicted on the charges of CSC, burglary, kidnapping, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  He entered an Alford plea (acknowledging the State had enough evidence to convince a jury of his guilt beyond a reasonable doubt) to the CSC and possession of a firearm charges, in exchange for which the State dropped the kidnapping and burglary charges.Â  The trial court accepted the Alford plea.Â  During the plea colloquy, the trial court informed the defendant of his right to file an appeal from his plea.Â  
II.
On appeal, Graddick argues the judge erred by informing him of his right to appeal from his plea.Â  His argument is that the trial court, by informing him of his right appeal, converted his Alford plea into a conditional plea.Â  Conditional pleas are disallowed in South Carolina, under State v. Truesdale, 278 S.C. 38, 296 S.E. 2d 528 (1982).Â  Graddick therefore argues his plea was invalid and thus should be vacated.Â  
This argument fails.Â  It is true that conditional pleas are not valid in South Carolina. 

  [A] conditional plea . . . is a practice not recognized in South Carolina and a practice which we expressly disapprove.Â  Pleas of guilty are unconditional, and if an accused attempts to attach any condition or qualification thereto, the trial court should direct a plea of not guilty. 

    Truesdale,  278 S.C. at 370, 296 S.E.2d at 529 (citations omitted); see also State v. Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 145, 604 S.E.2d 377, 379 (2004) (citing State v. Peppers, 346 S.C. 502, 505, 552 S.E.2d 288, 290 (2001) (â€œIf the trial court accepts a conditional guilty plea, then the plea will be vacated on appeal.â€)); State v. Oâ€™Leary, 302 S.C. 17, 18, 393 S.E.2d 186, 187 (1990) (â€œGuilty pleas are unconditional and, if an accused attempts to attach any condition, the trial [c]ourt must direct a plea of not guilty.â€). 
There was no conditional plea here, however.Â  The court did not approve any specific conditions on the appeal, nor did the defendant attempt to reserve any specific right to appeal from any particular aspect of his plea.Â  Unlike the defendants in Oâ€™Leary and Peppers, Graddick did not propose to attach, and the plea court did not accept, any specific condition that would have been triggered by the plea courtâ€™s acceptance of the guilty plea.Â  The plea court merely informed Graddick of his general right to appeal. 
Â The mere fact that defendant was informed of his right to appeal does not convert this otherwise unconditional plea into a conditional one.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Vasquez Q. Hendon, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-080
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 14, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott and Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Vasquez Hendon was convicted of two counts of assault with intent to kill and sentenced to concurrent terms of imprisonment totaling eight years.Â  He appeals, arguing the trial court erred in charging the jury on the law of accomplice liability.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Around 1:00 a.m. on January 13, 2004, Lieutenant Charlie Watson encountered Hendon and Demetrius Jones walking down Seaboard Avenue in Mullins, South Carolina.Â  Lieutenant Watson spoke to the two men, and he noticed that Hendon was wearing a brown or tan light-colored jacket with a white toboggan/ski mask flipped up on his head like a hat.Â  A few hours later, two men entered the Huddle House restaurant in Mullins, a few blocks from Seaboard Avenue.Â  According to waitress Cynthia Benjamin, the two men ordered food and attempted to bring beer into the restaurant.Â  Benjamin noticed that the man with the lighter skin tone was wearing a white toboggan-type hat rolled up on his head and a brown jacket.Â  After eating their food, the two men left.
Between 5:00 a.m. and 5:30 a.m. on January 13, 2004, a man entered the Huddle House brandishing a gun, wearing a white ski mask pulled over his face, and wearing a brown jacket.Â  An accomplice stood in the foyer of the restaurant, apparently unarmed.Â  The masked gunman shot at Benjamin, who fled through the back of the restaurant.Â  While the gunman was focused on Benjamin, customer Doug Hooks attempted to escape through the front door.Â  Hooks knocked over and became entangled with the accomplice before running into the parking lot.Â  The gunman chased Hooks and starting shooting at him in the parking lot before the gunman and the accomplice decided to leave.Â  No one was shot in the incident, and it was captured on the Huddle Houseâ€™s video monitoring system.Â  According to Benjamin, the gunman was wearing the same clothes and white tobbaggan/ski mask and had the same build and skin tone as the man who had eaten with his friend at the Huddle House less than two hours earlier that morning.Â Â Â  
Police later questioned Hendon and Demetrius Jones.Â  Both admitted to being at the scene; however, both accused the other of being the shooter.Â  In Jonesâ€™ oral and written statements accusing Hendon of being the gunman, Jones informed police that Hendon suggested they return to the Huddle House, and Hendon had a gun and a mask over his face as they approached.Â  Jones orally informed police that he was knocked over by Hooks exiting the Huddle House before Jones could enter.Â Â Â Â  
Hendon was indicted for attempted armed robbery, two counts of assault with intent to kill, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Jones was not charged with any crime. Â Although Jones was a witness for the State at trial, he changed his testimony, saying he did not recall any of the events of that night or giving aÂ  statement to police.Â  Benjamin identified Hendon as the shooter at trial.Â  After all of the evidence, and over the objections of defense counsel, the trial court charged the jury with, among other things, the law of accomplice liability that the â€œhand of one is the hand of all.â€ Â Hendonâ€™s counsel renewed his objection to the accomplice liability charge after all the charges were given.Â Â  
The jury acquitted Hendon of attempted armed robbery but convicted him of two counts of assault with intent to kill and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  In light of the acquittal on the armed robbery charge, the circuit court directed a verdict of not guilty on the charge of possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Hendon was sentenced to two concurrent terms of eight years on each of the convictions for assault with intent to kill.Â  This appeal followed. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hendon argues the trial court erred in charging the jury on the law of accomplice liability because only one person was alleged to have been the shooter and there was no evidence that the non-shooter participated in the crimes.[2]Â  We disagree.
A trial court is required to instruct the jury on the current and correct law of the state.Â  State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 317, 577 S.E.2d 460, 463 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe evidence presented at trial determines the charged jury instruction.â€Â  State v. Blurton, 352 S.C. 203, 207, 573 S.E.2d 802, 804 (2002).Â  If any evidence exists to support a charge, then it should be given.Â  State v. Burris, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999).Â  Thus, in reviewing jury instructions for error, â€œwe must consider the courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.â€Â  Adkins, 353 S.C. at 318, 577 S.E.2d at 463.Â  If the charge, as a whole, is reasonably free from error, â€œany isolated portions which may be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  State v. Buckner, 341 S.C. 241, 246-47, 534 S.E.2d 15, 18 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Where a jury instruction does not fit the facts of the case, however, it may confuse the jury and may constitute error.Â  Blurton, 352 S.C. at 207-08, 573 S.E.2d at 804 (â€œThe purpose of a jury instruction is â€˜to enlighten the jury and to aid it in arriving at a correct verdict.Â  It is error to give instructions which are calculated to confuse or mislead the jury.â€™Â  If a jury instruction is provided to the jury that does not fit the facts of the case, it may confuse the jury.â€)(quoting State v. Leonard, 292 S.C. 133, 137, 355 S.E.2d 270, 273 (1987)).Â  
Under the theory of accomplice liability, or â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all,â€ one may be criminally liable for the criminal acts of a confederate.Â  To be liable under this theory, â€œa person must personally commit the crime or be present at the scene of the crime and intentionally, or through a common design, aid, abet, or assist in the commission of that crime through some overt act.â€Â  State v. Austin, 299 S.C. 456, 459, 385 S.E.2d 830, 832 (1989).Â  There need not be a formally expressed agreement to establish the conspiracy; the conspiracy may be shown by the conduct of the parties and circumstantial evidence.Â  State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 194, 562 S.E.2d 320, 325 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
In determining whether the accomplice liability charge was warranted in this case, our focus must be on whether there was any evidence that Hendon and Jones were acting together at the time of the shooting.Â  Jones informed police that after the two men decided to return to the Huddle House, Hendon approached the restaurant with his gun and wearing a mask over his face.Â  Hooks testified that the non-shooter was standing in the foyer of the Huddle House during the shooting.Â  Both Hendon and Jones admitted to being present at the crime scene.Â  Thus, the two were together before, during and after the shooting.Â  It can be inferred, from the conduct of the two men and the circumstances, that both men knew of the plan to rob the Huddle House and that the non-gunman, who was waiting in the foyer, would act as a lookout.Â  Although it is troubling that the accomplice liability charge was given when Jones was not charged in this crime, this fact does not control our analysis of whether there was evidence to support the accomplice liability charge.Â  Because there was circumstantial evidence to support the charge, we find no error with the trial courtâ€™s decision to give the charge.Â  
Further, even assuming it was error to give the accomplice liability charge, we find such error would be harmless.Â  Both Lieutenant Watson and Benjamin identified Hendon as wearing the same clothing and hat as the gunman on the morning of the shooting.Â  Benjamin also pointed to Hendon and positively identified him as the shooter at trial based on his clothing, skin tone, and build.Â  Despite the fact that he recanted at trial, Jones gave statements to police that Hendon was the shooter.Â  Because there was competent evidence that would support the guilty verdict against Hendon, we find an alleged error in instructing the jury on the law of accomplice liability is harmless.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1999) (holding that an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where â€œguilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reachedâ€).Â  
CONCLUSION
There was circumstantial evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s decision to give the accomplice liability charge.Â  Further, even assuming the trial court erred in giving the charge, that error was harmless in light of the evidence presented at trial.Â  Thus, Hendonâ€™s convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Hendon does not complain about the substance of the charge given.Â  Therefore, we will confine our analysis to whether there was evidence presented at trial that would support an accomplice liability charge.

title: Schneider v. Board of Directors for Bohicket Marina Village
text:
PREHEARING REPORT


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Kenneth G. Schneider, Jr., on behalf of himself and others similarly situated,
Appellant/Respondent,
v.
Board of Directors for the Bohicket Marina Village Council of Co-Owners, Inc., for the years 1990 to the present,
Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-081
Heard January 11, 2007 â€“ Filed February 15, 2007Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Jefferson Leath, Jr., of Charleston; and W.H. Bundy, Jr., of Mt. Pleasant; for Appellant/Respondent.
Eugene P. Corrigan, III, of Charleston; for Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM: The Board of Directors for the Bohicket Marina Village of Co-Owners, Inc. (â€œthe Boardâ€) and Kenneth G. Schneider, on behalf of himself and others similarly situated, cross-appeal a jury verdict in favor of Schneider on his class action suit against the Board for negligence and breach of fiduciary duty arising from its management of the Bohicket Marina Village Horizontal Property Regime.Â  We affirm.
I. The Boardâ€™s Appeal
We decline to address the Boardâ€™s contentions that the circuit court erred by: (1) refusing to dismiss Schneiderâ€™s suit for failure to comply with Rule 23(b)(1), SCRCP, and (2) qualifying Schneiderâ€™s expert on community associations, governments, and board responsibilities.Â  We hold that the Board did not present a sufficient record for appellate review on these issues.Â  Substantial portions of the proceedings belowâ€”especially portions related to the Boardâ€™s assignments of errorâ€”are not included in the record on appeal.Â  See Webb v. CSX Transp., Inc., 364 S.C. 639, 655, 615 S.E.2d 440, 449 (2005) (â€œIt is the
appellantâ€™s burden to present a sufficient record for appellate review.â€); Connolly v. Peopleâ€™s Life Ins. Co. of S.C., 299 S.C. 348, 352, 384 S.E.2d 738, 740 (1989) (recognizing an appellate court should not be left to â€œâ€˜grope in the dark,â€™ searching the entire record to ascertain the issue being raisedâ€); Hundley v. Rite Aid of S.C., Inc., 339 S.C. 285, 306-07, 529 S.E.2d 45, 57 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding appellants bear the burden of providing this court with a record sufficient to allow appellate review). 
We affirm the following remaining preserved issues raised by the Board.Â  First, we hold the trial judge did not abuse her discretion in refusing to either decertify the class or remove Schneider as the class representative.Â  â€œ[A] trial judgeâ€™s ruling on whether an action is properly maintainable as a class action is within his discretion.â€Â  Waller v. Seabrook Island Property Owners Assâ€™n, 300 S.C. 465, 468, 388 S.E.2d 799, 801 (1990).Â  Rule 23(a)(4), SCRCP, provides that â€œthe representative parties will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class[.]â€Â  Although a close question is presented, to the extent the record addresses this issue, we find no abuse of discretion. 
Second, the trial judge did not abuse her discretion in allowing expert testimony from Marshal Clarke, a forensic architect, concerning the increased repair costs to the Regime from 1994 to 2004.Â  See Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005) (â€œQualification of an expert and the admission or exclusion of his testimony is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€); Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 406, 570 S.E.2d 176, 183 (2002) (â€œA trial courtâ€™s ruling to exclude or admit expert testimony will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of discretion.â€).Â  An expert witness may state an opinion based on facts not within his first-hand knowledge, and may base his opinion on information, whether or not admissible, made available to him before the hearing if the information is of the type reasonably relied upon in the field.Â  Rule 703, SCRE.Â  Defects in an expert witnessâ€™s education and experience go to the weight, rather than the admissibility, of the expertâ€™s testimony.Â  Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 253, 487 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1997).Â  Furthermore, we find any error by the trial judge would be harmless because Clarkeâ€™s testimony concerning costs estimates was cumulative to the same evidence that was earlier admitted without objection.Â  See Guffey v. Columbia/Colleton Regâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 364 S.C. 158, 170, 612 S.E.2d 695, 701 (2005) (explaining appellate court should review error in admission or exclusion of evidence to determine if it is harmless because equivalent or cumulative evidence was admitted).Â  
Third, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to direct a verdict based on the statute of limitations defense.Â  Conflicting evidence was presented to the jury, and the trial court properly presented the matter to the jury by way of a special interrogatory.Â  See Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 563, 633 S.E.2d 505, 509 (2006) (â€œIf the evidence as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the [directed verdict] motion should have been denied.â€); see also Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002) (â€œIn ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions.â€).

    II. Schneiderâ€™s Appeal
Schneider presented two claimsâ€”negligence and breach of fiduciary dutyâ€”to the jury.Â  The jury was instructed to â€œdecide each cause of action on the evidence and the law applicable to it, uninfluenced by your decision as to the other cause of action.â€Â  The charge further informed the jury: â€œyou will be asked to write a verdict for each cause of action.â€Â  There was no exception taken to the jury charge and the parties agree that the courtâ€™s instruction required the jury to consider each cause of action separately in terms of liability and damages.Â  The jury returned verdicts in favor of Schneider on each cause of action, and each verdict form reflected $1,250,000 in damages.Â  Upon receipt of the verdict, but prior to discharge of the jury, Schneider moved the trial court to have the jury â€œclarifyâ€ whether it determined total damages to be $1,250,000 or $2,500,000.Â  Because the jury was instructed to decide each cause of action separately and â€œuninfluencedâ€ by the juryâ€™s consideration of the other cause of action, the trial court accepted the facially valid verdict forms and discharged the jury.
The Board moved to require Schneider to make an election of remedies.Â  Schneider opposed the motion to elect remedies and submitted the affidavits of five jurors.[1]Â  Each juror affidavit asserts that â€œ[i]t was definitely my intent for Plaintiff and Class to receive a total award of $2,500,000â€ and that â€œI believed it was necessary to divide in half the award.â€Â  The trial court declined to consider the juror affidavits and required Schneider to make an election of remedies.Â  Judgment was entered for Schneider for $1,250,000.Â  On appeal, Schneider claims error in the election of remedies and asks us to make a finding that the juryâ€”all twelve jurorsâ€”intended to award total damages of $2,500,000 and that judgment be entered in favor of Schneider for $2,500,000.Â  Schneider does not seek a new trial.
While we are sympathetic with Schneiderâ€™s predicament, we are unable to grant the relief he requests.Â  This matter could have been easily and quickly resolved had the trial court permitted the jury to clarify its verdict. The trial court certainly had the authority to seek clarification from the jury as to its intent concerning damages.Â  The record reveals that when this very issue was anticipated by Schneider prior to jury deliberations, the trial court apparently acquiesced in Schneiderâ€™s counselâ€™s suggestion that â€œif [the jury] come[s] back with a verdict, we can send a question in, I guess, and clear it up then.â€Â  When the time came to remove any uncertainty with the juryâ€™s verdict, the trial court discharged the jury.Â  Yet we are certainly in no position to make a finding as to the juryâ€™s intent consistent with the view advocated by Schneider.Â  Even assuming we were to accept at face value the affidavits of the five jurors (which the Board did not have an opportunity to challenge), we do not know the intent of the other seven jurors.Â  
In rejecting Schneiderâ€™s challenge, we are mindful that the verdict forms are facially valid.Â  More to the point, the jury was instructed to reach a verdict as to each cause of action separately.Â  We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to consider the juror affidavits.Â  The position of the trial court is supported by Rule 606(b), SCRE, and case law.Â  State v. Hunter, 320 S.C. 85, 88, 463 S.E.2d 314, 316 (1995) (â€œAs a general rule, juror testimony may not be the basis for impeaching a jury verdict.â€); Barsh v. Chrysler Corp., 262 S.C. 129, 135, 203 S.E.2d 107, 109 (1974) (â€œSince litigation must be finalized, the courts have, as a policy matter, adopted the rule of refusing to allow the testimony of a juror to impeach the verdict.â€).Â  Rule 606(b) does not permit a juror to â€œtestify as to any matter or statement occurring during the course of the juryâ€™s deliberations.â€Â  Rule 606(b) does permit a juror to â€œtestify on the question whether extraneous prejudicial information was improperly brought to the juryâ€™s attention or whether any outside influence was improperly brought to bear upon any juror,â€ but there is no such allegation here.Â  In light of Schneiderâ€™s request that we make a finding as to the juryâ€™s intent concerning the amount of damages based the affidavits of the five jurors, we find no error in the entry of judgment in accordance with the juryâ€™s facially valid verdict. 
We also find no error in the ruling of the circuit court requiring an election of remedies.Â  Again, Schneider seeks to avoid the facially valid verdict of the jury.Â  The above discussion concerning the charge to the jury and the form of the verdict applies to this related assignment of error.Â  Moreover, we note that Schneiderâ€™s claims against the Board arise from the same set of factsâ€”the Boardâ€™s administration and maintenance of the Regime property.Â  The trial court properly required an election of remedies in this case where two causes of action went to the jury on an identical set of facts. Â See Tomlinson v. Mixon, 367 S.C. 467, 470, 626 S.E.2d 43, 44-45 (Ct. App. 2006) (holding the purpose of the doctrine of election of remedies â€œis to prevent double redress for a single wrong.â€); see also Inman v. Imperial Chrysler-Plymouth, Inc., 303 S.C. 10, 15, 397 S.E.2d 774, 777 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œ[T]he trial judge should on his own motion require election if he lets both causes of action go to the jury.â€). Â Â 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, J.J., concur.

[1] The record does not indicate if the remaining seven jurors were contacted.
