title: Sochko v. Sochko
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lisa Sochko Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Jeffrey Sochko Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-082
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 15, 2007 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
George W. Speedy, of Camden, for Appellant- Respondent.
Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action, Lisa Sochko (Wife) appeals the order of the family court distributing $120,000 she and Jeffrey Sochko (Husband) received when they settled a claim for stucco damage to their home.Â  Husband also appeals the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On November 23, 1999, after fourteen years of marriage, Wife instituted this action for divorce.Â  Wife sought custody of the partiesâ€™ three children, child support, equitable apportionment of the marital property, and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. Â Husband answered, seeking alimony, custody, equitable apportionment and divorce based upon Wifeâ€™s adultery.[2] Â Â Â 
On December 13, 1999, the family court issued a temporary order awarding joint custody to both parents, with Wife as the primary custodian.Â  Husband was ordered to pay $444 per month in child support.Â  Shortly thereafter, Husband filed a motion seeking to transfer custody to him, which the family court denied.Â  On September 22, 2000, Wife filed a rule to show cause against Husband for failure to pay child support. Â By the time of the hearing, Husband had paid close to $800 and made provisions to pay the past arrearages.Â  
Thereafter, numerous motions were filed, including a motion by Wife, which was granted by the family court, to have the guardian ad litem removed.Â  In 2001, with trial only days away, Husband replaced his attorney and received a continuance.Â  
By the time the case was set for trial, in February of 2002, the parties had settled many of the issues, including the issue of custody, which had been the primary source of the partiesâ€™ disagreement.Â  The parties agreed to joint custody with Wife being the primary custodian.Â  After trial, the family court issued the parties a divorce based upon the ground of one years separation.Â  Further, the family court ordered Husband to pay child support and denied his request for alimony. Â The court found neither party was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
Both parties filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to have the family court reconsider its divorce decree.Â  Specifically, Wife argued the judge had failed to consider Husbandâ€™s actions in prolonging the litigation.Â  By order dated August 5, 2002, the family court awarded Wife attorneyâ€™s fees; however, the court denied Husbandâ€™s motion.Â  
Although the record is somewhat unclear, it appears the divorce was bifurcated, leaving the issue of the marital home to be decided later due to ongoing litigation involving stucco damage to the home.Â  The parties eventually settled their stucco claim for $120,000.Â  
At the September 11, 2003 hearing, the parties agreed that the equity in the marital home would be divided in half, with Wife receiving ownership of the house.Â  Therefore, the only issues left to determine were the outstanding liens on the home and the apportionment of the stucco settlement.Â  During the hearing, Wife attempted to introduce Charles Burns, Jr., the contractor who performed the stucco repairs, as a witness.Â  Husband objected based on the ground Wife did not list Burns as a witness.Â  The family court sustained the objection.Â  Additionally, the court allowed Wife to argue that $14,000 the parties received from her father for down payment for their home was a loan, and thus marital debt subject to equitable apportionment.Â  Husband maintained the money was a gift.Â  
On November 11, 2003, the family court issued its final order, finding the cost of the stucco repairs amounted to $40,150.Â  After assessing the equity in the home, the mortgage indebtedness, the repairs performed on the home, and the remaining stucco settlement, the judge found Wife was required to pay Husband $3,696.85 as his share of apportionment of the house.Â  In reaching this figure, the family court considered that Husband already had possession of $38,613.39, which amounted to his share of the stucco settlement after attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
Husband filed a Rule 59(e) motion, arguing the family court erred in assessing the value of the marital home and stucco settlement.Â  Husband argued the equity in the home and the stucco settlement should be apportioned separately and the family court agreed.Â  In its amended final order, the family court, cognizant that under the new order Wife owed a substantially larger amount than under the previous order, found Husband was entitled to $42,310 for his share of the equity in the house and stucco settlement.Â  Both parties appeal.Â  Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002); Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 215, 612 S.E.2d 456, 458 (Ct. App. 2005); Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005); Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992)).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, and we remain mindful of the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the parties, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981); Holler v. Holler, 364 S.C. 256, 261, 612 S.E.2d 469, 472 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity to directly observe the witnesses, it should accord great deference to the
family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Wifeâ€™s Appeal
A. Judicial Estoppel 
Wife argues the family court erred in assessing only $40,150, the amount the parties paid to repair the stucco damage to the house, as the stucco damage.Â  Wife maintains even though the amount to repair the damage was $40,150, under the doctrine of judicial estoppel, Husband is estopped from claiming the stucco damage to the house was less than $120,000, the amount the parties received as the settlement of the stucco claim.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note the argument relating to judicial estoppel is not preserved for our review.Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the family court.Â 
Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 104-05, 627 S.E.2d 765, 775 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€)); Jones v. Daley, 363 S.C. 310, 315, 609 S.E.2d 597, 599 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Wife did not raise this argument to the family court.Â  Additionally, Wife did not raise this issue in her rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved.Â Â  See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (holding when an appellant neither raises an issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to amend, the issue is not properly presented to an appellate court for review); Hailey v. Hailey, 357 S.C. 18, 24, 590 S.E.2d 495, 498 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding Wife did not raise argument that Husband was judicially estopped from raising issue of decrease of alimony to family court and thus, issue was not preserved for appellate review).
Even if the issue was preserved, we find judicial estoppel inapplicable under the facts of this case. Under the doctrine of judicial estoppel, Wife contends Husband maintained two inconsistent positions.Â  During the stucco litigation, Husband maintained the damage to the house was $120,000, and in the current action he maintains the damage was only $40,150.Â  The doctrine of judicial estoppel â€œis an equitable concept that prevents a litigant from asserting a position inconsistent with, or in conflict with, one the litigant has previously asserted in the same or related proceeding.â€Â Â  Cothran v. Brown, 357 S.C. 210, 215, 592 S.E.2d 629, 631 (2004) (citing Colleton Reg. Hosp. v. MRS Med. Rev. Systs., 866 F.Supp. 896, 900 (D.S.C. 1994)). The purpose of judicial estoppel is â€œâ€˜to protect the integrity of the courts rather than to protect litigants from allegedly improper or deceitful conduct by their adversaries.â€™â€Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, 353 S.C. 31, 42, 577 S.E.2d 202, 208 (2003) (quoting Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 251, 489 S.E.2d 472, 477 (1997)). Â 
Further, â€œ[b]ecause judicial estoppel is an equitable concept, depending upon the facts and circumstances of each
individual case, application of the doctrine is discretionary.â€ Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 83-84, 552 S.E.2d 767, 772 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, 342 S.C. 352, 368, 536 S.E.2d 698, 706 (Ct. App, 2000)); see also Allen v. Zurich Ins. Co., 667 F.2d 1162, 1167 (4th Cir. 1982) (â€œobserving
judicial estoppel should be applied with cautionâ€); 28 Am. Jur. 2d Estoppel & Waiver Â§ 75 (2000) (â€œnoting
judicial estoppel is an equitable concept that must be applied with caution and in the narrowest of circumstances at the discretion of the trial courtâ€)).Â  In order for judicial estoppel to apply in a given case, the following elements must be met:

  (1) two inconsistent positions taken by the same party or parties in privity with one another; (2) the positions must
be taken in the same or related proceedings involving the same party or parties in privity with each other; (3) the party taking the position must have been successful in maintaining that position and have received some benefit; (4) the inconsistency must be part of an intentional effort to mislead the court; and (5) the two positions must be totally inconsistent. 

Cothran, 357 S.C. at 216, 592 S.E.2d at 631 (citing Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 83, 552 S.E.2d 767, 772 (Ct. App. 2001)).
During the stucco litigation, Husband and Wife both claimed the damage to the house was over $120,000, and the parties agreed to settle for that amount.Â  Subsequently, Wife made $69,800 worth of repairs to the home, $40,150 of which were found to be repairs to the house due to stucco damage. 
We find the family court properly concluded the cost to repair the stucco damage was the correct way to assess the damage to the house.Â  Therefore, the court properly divided the remaining portion of the settlement between the parties.Â  If we were to adopt the approach urged by Wife and allow her to receive the entire stucco settlement despite the fact that the repairs were significantly less, then she would receive a windfall and Husband would be denied his rightful share of the settlement.Â  
Moreover, we find judicial estoppel does not apply to the facts of this case.Â  The theory of judicial estoppel is premised upon the notion that allowing a party to enter a court of law asserting a factual position inconsistent with a position taken earlier in a related action demeans the entire judicial process.Â  In this case, we can discern no threat to the integrity of the court by allowing Husband to receive his share of the benefit that the cost to repair the stucco was less then the settlement amount.Â  In fact, we find a substantial injustice would occur if Wife were allowed to retain the remaining settlement amount when the house itself was marital property, and therefore subject to equitable distribution.Â  See Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 84, 552 S.E.2d 767, 772 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe discretionary nature of
judicial estoppel is such that it should not be applied if doing so would work â€œan injustice against the party being estopped while simultaneously subverting the
judicial process.â€).Â  Accordingly, we decline to apply judicial estoppel to this action and find the family court properly assessed the stucco damages.
B. Marital Home

 Wife argues the family court erred in its valuation of the marital home.Â  Wife contends the family court erroneously failed to consider the stucco damage in assessing the homeâ€™s value.Â  We disagree.
When making an equitable distribution of marital property, the
family court must identify marital property and determine the fair market value of the property. Cannon v. Cannon, 321 S.C. 44, 48, 467 S.E.2d 132, 134 (Ct. App. 1996); Noll v. Noll, 297 S.C. 190, 192, 375 S.E.2d 338, 340 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The
family court is entitled to â€œbroad discretion in valuing the marital property.â€ Pirri v. Pirri, 631 S.E.2d 279, 283 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Roe v. Roe, 311 S.C. 471, 478, 429 S.E.2d 830, 835 (Ct. App. 1993)).Â  The valuation of the family court â€œwill
be affirmed on appeal if the valuation is within the range of values presented by the parties.â€Â Â  Avery v. Avery,  370 S.C. 304, 314, 634 S.E.2d 668, 673 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Woodward v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987) (affirming the valuation of property in the range of evidence presented)).
The final order provides, â€œThe value of the house for purposes of the division as of the date of filing is $251,000, a figure which assumes all repairs to any existing stucco damage.â€Â  In determining the value of the house, the family court had three different appraisals to choose from.Â  All of the expertsâ€™ appraisals of the house included a value which assumed the stucco was fully repaired and the appraisals ranged from $251,000 to $275,000.Â  The family court chose the lowest appraisal, which actually benefited Wife because the parties agreed she would receive the house, and, therefore, the amount she had to pay to Husband as equity was less than it would have been had the family court used a higher appraisal.Â  Further, the final order clearly states it considered the stucco damage in assessing the value of the house.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in valuing the marital home.Â  
Next, Wife argues the family court erred in assessing the equity in the marital home.Â  Wife maintains the family court failed to consider the stucco damage was $120,000, and, therefore, erroneously found the equity in the home to be $129,595.22 rather than $9,595.22.Â  Because we find the family court properly assessed the stucco damage, we find no error in the courtâ€™s assessment of the equity in the home.[3]Â  
C.Â  Stucco Settlement 
Wife argues the family court erred in its division of the stucco settlement.Â  We disagree. 
In the final order, the family court appraised the house after the stucco repairs at $251,000 and then subtracted $121,404.78, the amount of mortgage indebtedness, and $40,150, the cost of the stucco repairs.Â  The family court also subtracted $4,825.22 for litigation costs Wife had advanced.Â  After all of the deductions, the family court arrived at $84,620, divided that amount by two and found each party was entitled to $42,310.Â  Because Husband and Wife had previously split $38,613.39 of the stucco settlement, Wife was only required to pay Husband $3,696.85 as his share of the division of the marital house and settlement.Â  
In the amended final order, the family court assessed the equity in the house and the stucco settlement separately.Â  The family court subtracted the mortgage indebtedness from the houseâ€™s value in order to establish the equity in the house, which was $129,595.22, with each party entitled to $64,797.61.Â  The family court then took the stucco settlement and subtracted attorneyâ€™s fees to arrive at $77,226.28.Â  The family court then subtracted $40,150 for the repairs to the stucco and $4,825.22 for litigation costs advanced by Wife for a total of $32,251.06, with each party entitled to $16,125.53.Â  The family court then added each partyâ€™s share of the house equity and the left over settlement amount and established that each party was entitled to $80,923.14.Â  The family court reasoned that because Husband had already received $38,613.14[4] from the stucco settlement, it subtracted that amount from the $80,923.14 Husband was entitled.Â  Thus, the family court concluded Wife was required to pay Husband an additional $42,310. 
We can perceive of no error in the mathematical formula utilized by the family court in the amended final order.Â  In the final order, the court utilized a formula for division of the stucco settlement that, in essence, awarded the entire settlement to Wife for use in repairing the house and then subtracted the amount received by Husband from the settlement from what would have been his share of the equity in the house.Â  The formula used in the final order fails to consider the fact the stucco settlement was substantially larger than the cost to repair the stucco damage.Â  By assessing the equity in the house and stucco settlement separately, the court ensured that each party was awarded their fair share of both.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court properly divided the stucco settlement.Â  
D.     Exclusion of Testimony 
Wife alleges the family court erred in excluding the testimony of Charles Burns, Jr., the contractor who repaired the stucco damage to the home, as a witness.Â  By excluding the testimony, Wife maintains she was unable to establish how much of the $68,800 worth of repairs she made to the home were related to the stucco damage.Â  For the reasons set forth below, we decline to reach this issue. 
During the hearing, Wife introduced Burns as a witness and Husband objected on the ground that he was not aware Burns was going to testify.Â  Further, Husband complained the repairs were done without his permission and he was not given an opportunity to have an expert assess the damage to the house.Â  The family court sustained the objection, finding Burns was not listed to testify and excluded him as a witness.Â  After the family court dismissed Burns, Wife did not make a follow-up proffer of the testimony. Â Without an adequate proffer, there is nothing before us to review.Â  See McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 349, 479 S.E.2d 67, 78 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding that absent a proffer of the excluded testimony, there is nothing before the court to review); Vaughn v. City of Anderson, 300 S.C. 55, 59-60, 386 S.E.2d 297, 300 (Ct. App. 1989) (â€œThere was no proffer of the testimony. Without the proffer of the testimony there is nothing for this court to review.â€).Â  
The record before us is devoid of any showing of what the excluded testimony would have been, and, therefore, we cannot determine any prejudice Wife suffered.Â  Accordingly, even if the family court did err in excluding the testimony, Wife has failed to show any prejudice she suffered because all the record reveals is that Burns performed the repairs.Â  See Vaughn, 300 S.C. at 58, 386 S.E.2d at 299 (Ct. App. 1989) (â€œA ruling on the admission of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion and a showing of prejudice.â€) (citing Manning v. City of Columbia, 297 S.C. 451, 377 S.E.2d 335 (1989)).
E. Loan from Wifeâ€™s Father
Wife alleges the family court erred in finding the parties were not obligated to pay Wifeâ€™s father $14,000 that he loaned to the parties to purchase their home.Â  Wife contends the family court erroneously concluded the $14,000 was not marital debt subject to equitable apportionment.Â  We disagree. Â 
When the parties purchased their home, Wifeâ€™s father gave them $42,500, which Wife maintains is a loan and Husband maintains is a gift.Â  Wife and Husband still had to finance the rest of the purchase price.Â  Towards that end, Wifeâ€™s father wrote a letter to First Federal Bank which provided:

I am writing you to inform you that I am giving my daughter Lisa Dietz Sochko and her family a gift of $42,500.00 to purchase a new home . . . . I am pleased to be in a position to help my daughter and I am not expecting her to re-pay me.Â  This is not a loan but instead a gift!Â  Her house is presently on the market for sale.Â  If it does not sell by the time of the final closing on the new construction, I will make all mortgage payments for her until it is sold.

Shortly thereafter, Wife wrote a letter to her dad, dated May 10, 1999, signed by her and Husband which stated:

Jeff and I will pay you the full amount that you lend [sic] us for the house $42,500.Â  We will also be totally responsible for making our other mortgage payment in case it doesnâ€™t sell.Â  Thank you so much for this loan. Â We appreciate it more then we can tell you.

When the partiesâ€™ house sold, they returned $28,500 to Wifeâ€™s father, leaving an alleged $14,000 balance.Â  
The family court found the two letters were contradictory, because the official statement made to the lender characterized the money as a gift, while the unofficial letter characterized the transfer of funds as a loan.Â  The court concluded that the contradictory nature of the letters allowed the parties to characterize the transfer of funds in anyway which suited their purpose.Â  The court refused to â€œindulge the parties in this exercise.â€Â  Further, the judge found the money had not been repaid in ten years nor was there any evidence of any repayment schedule.Â  Accordingly, he declined to find the money was marital debt.Â  
We find the family court properly found the money was not a loan, and therefore, not subject to equitable apportionment as marital debt.Â  Wifeâ€™s father wrote an official letter to a lending institution claiming the money was a gift.Â  If the money was in fact a loan, then all of the parties involved defrauded the lender.Â  In light of the conflicting evidence on the subject, this court will not be involved in characterizing the transfer of funds in anyway that is different than what Wifeâ€™s father presented officially to the lending institution.Â  In our view, a party cannot engage in chicanery in order to obtain financing and then later claim, in a court of law, a position contrary to the one officially taken.Â  Therefore, we find no error by the family court on this point. 
F.Â  Wifeâ€™s Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife argues that if she is successful on appeal, this court should reverse the family courtâ€™s order finding she was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees for the September 11, 2003 hearing.Â  She concedes that if she is unsuccessful, then the family court correctly decided the issue.Â  Because we affirm the order of the family court, we find the family court properly found Wife was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees for the September hearing.Â  Â 
II. Â Â Â Â  Husbandâ€™s Appeal

 Husband alleges the family court erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees for the trial on February 4, 5, and 6, 2002.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-3-120 of the South Carolina Code (1985) authorizes the family court to order payment of suit money, including attorneyâ€™s fees, to either party in an action for divorce.Â  The family court is awarded broad discretion in deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees and its decision will not be overturned on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 553, 559 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004); Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 478 (1989); Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988).
South Carolina case law and court rules make clear that when a statute permits an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court must make specific findings of fact on the record
for each of the required factors to be considered.Â 
Griffith v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 646, 506 S.E.2d 526, 534-35 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting Rule 26(a), SCRFC) (â€œAn order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of law to support the courtâ€™s decision.â€).Â  In general, where a family court order fails to comply with Rule 26(a), an appellate court â€œshould reverse and remand so the Family Court may make specific findings of fact.â€Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202-03, 522 S.E.2d 835, 839 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 427 S.E.2d 659 (1993)). â€œHowever, when an order from the family court is issued in violation of Rule 26(a), SCRFC, the
appellate court â€˜may remand the matter to the [family] court or, where the record is sufficient, make its own findings of fact in accordance with the preponderance of the evidence.â€™â€Â  Griffith, 332 S.C. at 646-47, 506 S.E.2d at 535 (citation omitted).Â  
Additionally, in Glasscock v. Glasscock, the South Carolina Supreme Court clarified the six factors used to determine whether attorneyâ€™s fees are warranted in a given case:

(1) nature, extent, and difficulty of the case;
(2) time necessarily devoted to the case;
(3) professional standing of counsel;
(4) contingency of compensation
(5) beneficial results obtained;
(6) customary legal fees for similar services

304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).Â  Â 
In the present case, the family court initially found Wife was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  After Wife filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to reconsider, the family court awarded her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court found Wife was entitled to the fees she incurred for Husbandâ€™s failure to pay child support after the initial temporary hearing, for issues relating to the removal of the first guardian ad litem, and for issues relating to the valuation of property.Â  Additionally, the court found Wife was entitled to fees incurred because of the delays Husband caused by having three different attorneys throughout the course of the litigation. 
The family court noted Husbandâ€™s last change of attorneys occurred within days of the scheduled trial, after Wifeâ€™s attorney had already prepared for trial and had issued service of subpoenas for witnesses.Â  The judge found Husband prolonged the litigation and created unnecessary costs for Wife.Â  The judge stated that although Wife had no greater ability to pay fees than Husband, the failure to award her fees and costs would have the effect of significantly reducing the value of her equitable division through no fault of her own and of rewarding Husband for his actions. Â The court therefore found Wife was entitled to fees and, accordingly, awarded her a â€œreasonable sumâ€ of $10,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees based upon seventy hours at the rate of $150 per hour.
Despite the fact the family court did not specifically refer to Glasscock and that we believe the courtâ€™s order to be weak, we nonetheless find it sufficient to sustain the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  The family court considered many of the factors, and focused primarily on the fact Husbandâ€™s activities, including his failure to pay child support and hiring a new attorney days before trial was set to commence, caused Wife to incur unnecessary expenses.Â  Therefore, we hold the record is sufficient to affirm the family courtâ€™s order.Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
We find Wifeâ€™s argument regarding judicial estoppel is not preserved for appeal.Â  Even if the argument had been preserved, judicial estoppel is not applicable to the facts of this case.Â  Moreover, the family court did not err in its valuation of the marital home or in its distribution of the stucco settlement.Â  We also find due to Wifeâ€™s failure to proffer the expert testimony, we cannot review whether the family court erred in excluding the testimony.Â  Additionally, we find the court correctly characterized the loan from Wifeâ€™s father as a gift.Â  Finally, we find the judge did not err in requiring Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The record is somewhat meager of facts relating to the events leading up to the divorce.Â  Further, the parties did not include the complaint and answer in the record.Â  
[3] The equity in the house and its division are more fully discussed below.Â  
[4] The final order provides Husband already received 38,613.14, instead of $38,613.39, no reason is given for this small discrepancy.

title: Rapid Industries v. Wingate
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Rapid Industries, Inc., Respondent,
v.
Industrial Service Works, Inc., and William Benjamin Streett and Charles R. Wingate, Jr., Defendants, Of whom Charles R. Wingate, Jr. is
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Eugene P. Warr, Jr., Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-083
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 15, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert D. McKissick, of Florence, for Appellant.
D. Kenneth Baker, of Darlington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action for breach of a commercial lease, Charles R. Wingate, Jr. appeals the special refereeâ€™s award of damages to Rapid Industries, Inc. (Landlord).Â  Wingate argues the special referee erred in finding Landlord mitigated its damages and summarily awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On June 26, 2000, Landlord entered into a lease agreement with Industrial Service Works, Inc. (Tenant).Â  Tenant agreed to lease from Landlord certain land with an office, warehouse, and truck scale.Â  The lease sets rent at $1,000 a month and covers three years, from June 1, 2000 to May 31, 2003.Â  In addition, Landlord is authorized to collect a 15% late fee and attorneyâ€™s fees in the event Tenant defaults.Â  Wingate and William Benjamin Streett guaranteed the lease.[2]Â Â Â  
Tenant made two lease payments and subsequently defaulted.Â  On December 16, 2002, Landlord filed a complaint against Tenant, Wingate, and Streett.Â  Wingate answered and asserted affirmative defenses, including an allegation that Landlord failed to mitigate its damages.Â  The case was referred to a special referee.Â  At the hearing, Robert B. Pace, Landlordâ€™s president and sole shareholder, testified about his attempts to mitigate Landlordâ€™s damages.Â Â Â  
The special referee found Pace made minimal efforts to mitigate Landlordâ€™s damages.Â  However, he noted Pace did make some effort to lease or sell the property, and the propertyâ€™s character made it one which would be difficult to lease or sell.Â  As a result, the special referee awarded Landlord damages in the amount of $12,000, representing one year of rent payments.Â  In addition, he ordered Wingate to pay the 15% late fee due on this amount and attorneyâ€™s fees totaling $3,000.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for breach of contract seeking damages is one at law. Â Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992).Â  In an
action at law, the appellate court will correct any error of law, but it must affirm the special
refereeâ€™s factual findings unless no evidence reasonably supports those findings.Â  Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 483, 486 S.E.2d 771, 773 (Ct. App. 1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Mitigation
Wingate contends no evidence supports the special refereeâ€™s conclusion with respect to the mitigation of damages issue.Â  We disagree.
â€œA party injured by the acts of another is required to do those things a person of ordinary prudence would do under the circumstances to mitigate damages; however, the law does not require unreasonable exertion or substantial expense for this to be accomplished.â€Â  Genovese v. Bergeron, 327 S.C. 567, 572, 490 S.E.2d 608, 611 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œA failure to attempt to mitigate damages will not bar plaintiff entirely from a recovery, but will only prevent the recovery of such damages as might have been avoided by reasonable efforts on his or her part.â€Â  25 C.J.S. Damages Â§47 (Supp. 2006) (emphasis added).
The party asserting the defense of mitigation bears the burden of establishing a lack of due diligence in minimizing damages.Â  Perry v. Green, 313 S.C. 250, 255, 437 S.E.2d 150, 153 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Whether a party acted reasonably to mitigate damages is ordinarily a question of fact.Â  Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 285, 573 S.E.2d 830, 838 (Ct. App. 2002).
In this case, Pace testified he â€œcontacted everybody [he] could think of [to ask] if they wanted to rent [the property].â€Â  He negotiated with a railroad and a local steel company, both of which decided not to lease the property.Â  During this time, approximately twelve people contacted Pace to inquire about the property.Â  After these efforts failed, Pace contacted a real estate agent and put the property up for sale sometime in 2003.[3]Â  Pace testified the nature of the property deterred potential lessees, specifically the local steel company.Â  In addition, despite the use of a real estate agent after 2003, the property had not been sold or leased at the time of the hearing, in October 2005.Â  
The special referee found â€œ[p]rior to listing the property for sale with an agent in 2003, [Landlord] made minimal efforts to lease or sell the property.â€Â  He further noted, â€œPace . . . did not try very hard during the lease period to sell or lease the subject property.â€Â  However, the special referee also noted the special nature of the property made it difficult to find a willing lessee or purchaser.Â  Therefore, even if Landlord failed to mitigate damages as a matter of law, evidence supports the special refereeâ€™s conclusion this failure would not entirely bar Landlordâ€™s recovery.
II. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wingate maintains the special referee erred in the method with which it awarded attorneyâ€™s fees to Landlord.Â  We find Wingate failed to preserve this issue for our review.
In the present case, Pace listed the damages Landlord claimed as a result of Tenantâ€™s breach of the lease, including $15,218.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wingateâ€™s counsel informed the special referee: â€œ[W]ith regard to attorney[â€™]s fees, Iâ€”I guess I would just simply require them to produce an agreement between [Landlord and his attorney], just for the record.â€Â Â Â  Landlordâ€™s counsel produced his written agreement with Landlord and entered it into the record.Â  
In his November 16, 2005 order, the special referee awarded $3,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The special referee simply noted this amount represented 25% of the rent award.Â  We make no comment on the appropriateness of this award because it is not preserved for our review.Â  Wingate did not raise this issue to the special referee or make a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion to attempt to correct this error.Â  See Grant v. S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 356, 461 S.E.2d 388, 392 (1995) (holding alleged errors in a trial courtâ€™s order must be raised in a Rule 59 motion to be preserved for appellate review).Â  Although the general issue of attorneyâ€™s fees was raised to and ruled upon by the special referee, an objection as to the methods used to calculate the award as it was presented in the order was never raised.Â  Therefore, since the special referee was never presented with this issue, we hold Wingate failed to preserve this issue for our review.
CONCLUSION
We hold evidence supports the special refereeâ€™s findings with respect to mitigation of damages.Â  Furthermore, Wingate failed to preserve for appellate
review his challenge to the special refereeâ€™s method of awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, the special refereeâ€™s decision is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Streett later declared bankruptcy.Â  He is not a party to this appeal.
[3] Paceâ€™s efforts to sell the property occurred after the lease term would have expired.

title: Sovereign Group v. Surfmaster Owners Association
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The Sovereign Group, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Surfmaster Owners Association, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â J. C. Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-084
Heard December 8, 2006 â€“ Filed February 15, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen G. Morrison and Paul T. Collins, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Arthur E. Justice, Jr. and J. Jakob Kennedy, both of Florence; and R. Hawthorne Barrett, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this action for negligence, breach of contract, and breach of fiduciary duty, the Sovereign Group, Inc., appeals the trial judgeâ€™s denial of its motion for a new trial on the facts or, in the alternative, a new trial nisi additur.Â  In addition, Sovereign appeals the trial judgeâ€™s denial of its motion to amend to add a cause of action for civil conspiracy.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Edith Ann Charping is the sole shareholder of Sovereign.Â  In 1986, Sovereign acquired title to Penthouse H in the Surfmaster B uilding, a condominium complex.Â  In 1989, Charping and her husband, William P. Charping, moved into Penthouse H. Â William P. Charping is the president of an entity partnered with the developer of the Surfmaster Building.Â  
As early as 1987, certain units in the building began experiencing water leaks.Â  In 1993, the Surfmaster Owners Association, Inc. (the Association), hired a consultant to study the leaks.Â  The study revealed the leaks came from many places, including the patios above each unit.Â  As a result, the consulting firm recommended waterproofing each patio to prevent the leaks.Â  
The Association also hired water infiltration engineers to study the problem.Â  According to Dave Brannon, a board member for the Association from 1987 to the trial of this case, these engineers concluded waterproofing the patios would only temporarily solve the problem.Â  The engineers told the Association â€œthe external finish of the building was loose.â€ Â Because of this opinion, the Association filed suit against the buildingâ€™s developer for defective design and construction.Â  
In 1996, the parties settled the lawsuit for an amount between two and four million dollars.Â  To begin fixing the leaks, the Association hired Marshall Clarke, an architect, to oversee and prioritize repairs.Â  In addition, because the settlement money was not enough to complete the repairs, the Association levied a special assessment of $425,000.Â  However, the Association never collected this assessment.[1]Â  During the ensuing years, the Association allowed individual owners to pay for repairs and seek refunds.Â  Clarke oversaw these repairs and approved of the expenditures.
In 1994, the Charpings vacated Penthouse H.Â  Both Charpings later testified they spent $110,000 to renovate Penthouse H and intended to use it as rental property.Â  After the renovation was completed in the summer of 1996, they discovered leaks from an adjoining stairwell.Â  More leaks came from the drainpipes running from the patio on Penthouse G, the penthouse immediately above Penthouse H.Â  
The Charpings both testified they could not rent out Penthouse H because of the extensive damage.Â  They also could not repair the leaks because the stairwell and patio were common or limited common areas that only the Association or the owner of Penthouse G could fix.Â  They informed the Association of the leaks in September 1996, but received no response.Â  
Because the Charpings could not prevail upon the Association to fix the leaks, they stopped paying their assessments, and soon thereafter, the Association filed a lien for unpaid assessments.Â  Approximately one year later, the Charpings visited Penthouse H and found the locks had been changed.Â  When they entered later that day, they discovered the ceiling had fallen, the carpet had been torn up, and certain fixtures had been removed.Â  
The Charpingsâ€™ attorney, Michael Montgomery, wrote the Association, informing it of the destruction and requesting a new key to Penthouse H.Â  The Association refused to provide a key and filed a foreclosure action against Sovereign.Â  
The water leaks and destruction inside Penthouse H worsened through 2002.Â  Clarke had given one of the contractors a key to use Penthouse H as a construction staging area.Â  In November 2002, the Charpings hired Charles Lindsey, a specialty contractor, to clean up the mess.Â  Lindsey charged $6,000.Â  
Sovereign answered the Associationâ€™s foreclosure action and counterclaimed for negligence and breach of contract.Â  The case was referred to a master-in-equity, who severed the foreclosure action from the counterclaims before the case went to circuit court for trial.Â  
Before opening arguments, Sovereign made an oral motion to amend its answer and counterclaim to include causes of action for breach of fiduciary duty, outrage, and civil conspiracy.Â  The trial judge allowed the breach of fiduciary duty and outrage amendments, but denied the civil conspiracy amendment.Â  
At trial, Sovereignâ€™s expert in remodeling and construction work testified the cost to restore Penthouse H to its 1996 condition was $104,000.Â  Moreover, Thomas L. Watts, Jr., an appraiser, testified the lost rental value of Penthouse H from January 1997 to December 2004 was $692,000.Â  
The trial judge granted the Associationâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on Sovereignâ€™s outrage claim and submitted three causes of action to the jury: negligence, breach of fiduciary duty, and breach of contract.Â  The trial judge instructed the jury on damages, without objection from Sovereign. In fact, trial counsel for Sovereign stated that the charge â€œwas perfectly clearâ€ on damages and that he was â€œhappyâ€ with it.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Sovereign on all three causes of action, awarding $104,000 on the negligence claim, $6,000 on the breach of fiduciary duty claim, and $126,000 on the breach of contract claim.Â  In a special interrogatory, the jury found Sovereign had not been comparatively negligent.Â  
Sovereign agreed it would need to elect its remedy, and the trial judge gave the parties ten days to make post-trial motions.Â  Sovereign moved for a new trial based on the facts or, in the alternative, for a new trial nisi additur.Â  Specifically, Sovereign argued the jury failed to award damages for lost rental value.Â  The trial judge denied the motions.Â  Sovereign elected to recover based on its breach of contract claim.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. New Trial Motion
Sovereign argues the trial judge should have granted its motion for a new trial based on the thirteenth juror doctrine or, in the alternative, a new trial nisi additur.Â  Specifically, Sovereign maintains the trial judge should have granted these motions because the jury was confused about the proper method to allocate damages and the jury did not compensate Sovereign for the lost rental value of Penthouse H.Â  We disagree.
The thirteenth juror doctrine is a vehicle by which the circuit court may grant a new trial absolute when it finds the evidence does not justify the verdict.Â  Trivelas v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 357 S.C. 545, 553, 593 S.E.2d 504, 508 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Under this doctrine, the
judge may grant a new trial if the verdict is inconsistent and reflects the juryâ€™s confusion.Â  Sorin Equip. Co., Inc. v. The Firm, Inc., 323 S.C. 359, 363-64, 474 S.E.2d 819, 822 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
A trial judgeâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial upon the thirteenth juror doctrine will not be
disturbed unless the decision is wholly unsupported by the evidence, or the conclusion
reached was controlled by an error of law.Â  Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 403, 477 S.E.2d 715, 722 (Ct. App. 1996). â€œTo reverse the denial of a new trial motion under this doctrine we must, in essence, conclude that the moving party was entitled to a directed verdict at trial.â€Â  Haselden v. Davis, 341 S.C. 486, 506, 534 S.E.2d 295, 306 (Ct. App. 2000); Parker v. Evening Post Pub. Co., 317 S.C. 236, 247, 452 S.E.2d 640, 646 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  
The trial judge also has the authority to grant a new trial nisi additur, which is vehicle by which the plaintiff is granted a new trial unless the defendant agrees to pay an additional amount.Â  Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 401, 321 S.E.2d 40, 45 (1984).Â  On appeal, the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding a motion for new trial nisi additur will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  Green v. Fritz, 356 S.C. 566, 570, 590 S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
Initially, we note that to the extent Sovereign attributes any jury confusion to the jury charge, this argument is not preserved for review.Â  Sovereign expressly approved the instruction and lodged no objection to it.Â  Because Sovereign failed to raise any issue regarding the jury instruction to the trial judge, the argument is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
Sovereign also argues the verdict itself shows the jury was confused regarding election of remedies.Â  Specifically, Sovereign points out that the $104,000 awarded for the negligence claim corresponds with the amount it would cost to restore Penthouse H to its 1996 condition, the $6,000 awarded for the breach of fiduciary duty claim corresponds to the cost of cleaning up the penthouse after it was used as a construction staging area, and the $126,000 awarded for the breach of contract was intended to reimburse Sovereign for its loss of use.Â  We disagree and find the verdict valid on its face.Â  
Differing damage awards for each cause of action does not create a necessary implication that the jury mistakenly split the total damages among the three claims; rather, the elements of each claim and the nature of duty breached controls the types of damages that could have resulted therefrom. See Steinke v. S.C. Dept. of Labor, 336 S.C. 373, 387, 520 S.E.2d 142, 149 (1999)(stating plaintiff must show defendantâ€™s breach of duty proximately caused plaintiffâ€™s injury in a negligence case); Fuller v. Eastern Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 240 S.C. 75, 89, 124 S.E.2d 602, 610 (1962) (â€œThe general rule is that for a breach of contract the defendant is liable for whatever damages follow as a natural consequence and a proximate result of such breach.â€)(emphasis added);Â  Moore v. Moore, 360 S.C. 241, 253, 599 S.E.2d 467, 473 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œDamages in an action for breach of a fiduciary duty are those proximately resulting from the wrongful conduct of the defendant.â€)(emphasis added).
Furthermore, the amount awarded for breach of contract does not correspond with the $692,000 Sovereign claimed it was entitled to for its loss of use.Â  Rather than reflecting Sovereignâ€™s loss of use, the juryâ€™s award of $126,000 for breach of contract might include $104,000 to restore Penthouse H to its 1996 condition, along with the $6,000 to reimburse Sovereign for cleanup costs, and an additional $16,000 in loss of use. While $16,000 for loss of use is significantly less than what Sovereign anticipated, the jury was free to award this lower figure.Â  There is substantial evidence in the record that indicates the Sovereignâ€™s loss of use was nowhere near $692,000.Â  Norman Fortson, a member of the Associationâ€™s board, testified the water damage to Penthouse H was only minor.Â  This testimony supports an inference that the leaks did not prevent Sovereign from using or renting Penthouse H.Â  Thus the jury may have found the only loss of use suffered by Sovereign occurred during the period when the Charpings were refused a key.Â  The jury might have reasonably determined this short-term loss of use amounted to only $16,000.
While the jury may have come to some other conclusion, we think the above-cited evidence reasonably supports the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in failing to grant Sovereignâ€™s motion for a new trial on the facts or a new trial nisi additur.
II. Motion to Amend
Sovereign argues the trial judge erred in refusing to amend its answer and counterclaims to include a cause of action for civil conspiracy.Â  We disagree.
Sovereign made its motion pursuant to Rule 15(a), SCRCP.Â  Rule 15(a) reads, in relevant part, â€œ[A] party may amend his pleading only by leave of court . . . ; and leave shall be given when justice so requires and does not prejudice any other party.â€Â  Therefore, a motion to amend is addressed to the trial judgeâ€™s discretion, and the party opposing the motion has the burden of establishing prejudice.Â  Collins Entmâ€™t, Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 562, 611 S.E.2d 262, 270 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The prejudice envisioned by this rule is a lack of notice that the new issue is to be tried and a lack of opportunity to refute it.Â 
Stanley v. Kirkpatrick, 357 S.C. 169, 174, 592 S.E.2d 296, 298 (2004).
In this case, Sovereign moved to amend its answer and counterclaim on the first day of trial.Â  It alleged the record contained evidence supporting a civil conspiracy between the members of the Associationâ€™s board, in their individual capacities, and Clarke.Â  A
civil conspiracy is a combination of two or more parties joined for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff, thereby causing him special damages.Â  Angus v. Burroughs & Chapin Co., 368 S.C. 167, 170, 628 S.E.2d 261, 262 (2006).Â  
The trial judge clearly placed the burden of showing prejudice on the Association.Â  When the trial judge asked the Association why it would be prejudiced, its attorney explained he had not conducted any discovery on the issue and he would need time to locate and depose members of the Associationâ€™s board during the alleged conspiracy.Â  We find the lack of opportunity to locate and depose possible defense witnesses, as well as the inability to call favorable witnesses to testify, would have prejudiced the Associationâ€™s ability to defend itself.Â  Therefore, we hold the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Sovereignâ€™s motion to amend.
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Sovereignâ€™s motion for a new trial on the facts or, in the alternative, a new trial nisi additur.Â  Additionally, we find the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in refusing to allow Sovereign to amend its answer and counterclaim to allege a civil conspiracy.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s decision is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C. J., and BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Brannon testified the Association determined it should wait before collecting the assessment because of the temporary nature of the waterproofing solution.Â

title: State v. Robinson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Allen Robinson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-085
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 15, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Sr. Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia, Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  Allen Robinson appeals his conviction for possession of cocaine.Â  He asserts the circuit court judge erred in refusing to suppress the drug evidence that was seized during a search of his vehicle at a driverâ€™s license checkpoint.[1]Â  We reverse.[2]
FACTS
Prior to Robinsonâ€™s trial for possession with intent to distribute cocaine, Robinsonâ€™s counsel moved to suppress the evidence of the cocaine.Â  Specifically, he contended the cocaine was found pursuant to an illegal search and seizure.Â  Based on this motion, the trial judge held a suppression hearing during which Trooper Steven Branham testified regarding the search.Â  
On July 5, 2002, Trooper Steven Branham was working at a driverâ€™s license checkpoint in Aiken County. Â At approximately 2:30 p.m., Branham observed a vehicle â€œslowing downâ€ and â€œspeeding upâ€ as it approached the checkpoint.Â  While he was watching the vehicle, Branham noticed that Robinson, the driver, and his two passengers were â€œrummagingâ€ and acting â€œfrantic.â€ Â He further testified â€œthey were frantically moving, throwing arms around.â€ Â Branham admitted that he initially observed this behavior at a distance of â€œ[a]nywhere from 75 to 100 yards.â€Â  Based on his experience, Branham believed the occupants of the vehicle were â€œhiding something.â€ Â According to Branham the vehicle stopped just before the checkpoint.Â  As he approached the vehicle, Branham became suspicious because the occupants appeared very nervous.Â  Branham questioned them as to whether they were hiding anything.Â  Branham testified the occupants responded in a â€œnervous toneâ€ that they were â€œnot hiding anything at all.â€Â  
Branham then looked inside the vehicle and saw a brown paper bag containing a can, which he described as â€œa 22 oz. beer can or larger can.â€ Â Although Branham testified that he believed the can contained an alcoholic beverage, he could not immediately tell that it was a beer can or that the can was open. Â The testimony reveals the can was concealed in the paper bag and was pointing away from Branham when he looked in the window of the vehicle.Â  In fact, Branham stated, â€œ[i]t was not in an open situation.Â  A brown bag goes up to the tip of the rim of the can.Â  It wasnâ€™t like an open and look.Â  This is a bag that was molded or formed, you know, like it had been used.â€ Â Branham stated his observation of the can further raised his â€œsuspicionâ€ of the occupants. Â After instructing Robinson to pull over to the side of the road, Branham then ordered the occupants to exit the vehicle.Â  Branham asked Robinson if he was the owner of the vehicle and if there was anything illegal in the vehicle.Â  Robinson acknowledged he owned the vehicle and further responded to the question, â€œI donâ€™t know; there shouldnâ€™t be anything illegal in the car.â€Â Â Â  
At that point, Branham proceeded to search the vehicle to see â€œif there [were] any other beer cans or other illegal contraband in the vehicle.â€Â  Branham discovered the can in the brown paper bag was in fact an open beer can. Â During the course of his search, Branham found a plastic bag containing 1.22 grams of cocaine located underneath the driverâ€™s seat.Â Â Â  
On cross-examination, Branham admitted he did not ask Robinson for his consent to search the vehicle. Â Branham further acknowledged that Robinson and his passengers denied ownership of the drugs. Â Branham also did not issue a ticket for an open container violation.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
At the conclusion of Branhamâ€™s testimony, the judge heard arguments from counsel regarding the motion to suppress. Â Although Robinsonâ€™s counsel did not challenge the legitimacy of the license checkpoint, he asserted Robinsonâ€™s and his passengersâ€™ behavior at the checkpoint did not â€œrise to the level of probable cause or even reasonable suspicion that criminal activityâ€ was happening.Â  Additionally, counsel argued Branhamâ€™s testimony did not give rise to the automobile exception to the warrant requirement. Â He contended Branham could not have seen the beer can as an open container because it was not in plain view, but instead, was facing away from him when he looked through the window of the vehicle.Â  Because Robinson did not receive a ticket for the open container violation, counsel pointed out that the search could not be considered incident to arrest. 
In response, the solicitor argued that Branham, under the totality of the circumstances, had probable cause to search the vehicle based on the following:Â  (1) Robinson approached the checkpoint in a suspicious manner; (2) the occupants of the vehicle were frantically moving around as if they were hiding something; (3) Robinson stopped the vehicle several yards before the checkpoint; (4) the occupants of the vehicle gave nervous, vague answers to Branham when he questioned them; and (5) the twenty-two ounce can wrapped in a brown paper bag appeared to be an open beer container.Â Â Â  
In reply, Robinsonâ€™s counsel stated the nervous behavior of the occupants of the vehicle might have been sufficient for Branham to ask them to exit the vehicle and conduct a Terry pat-down for weapons.Â  However, she asserted it was not sufficient to conduct a search of the vehicle.Â  Furthermore, counsel contended the existence of a beer can in the back seat of the vehicle did not give rise to probable cause because Branham could not tell by â€œplain viewâ€ that the can was open.Â  
After hearing arguments from counsel, the trial judge ultimately denied Robinsonâ€™s motion to suppress.Â  The judge found Branham had probable cause to conduct the search based on the following:Â  (1) Robinson and his passengers appeared to be reaching downward as they approached the checkpoint; (2) Robinson drove slowly up to the checkpoint and stopped some distance before the checkpoint; and (3) the open container in the back seat of the vehicle.
The trial proceeded with Branham recounting the incident in the presence of the jury.Â  Robinson, the defenseâ€™s only witness, then testified.Â  Robinson testified that at the time of the incident he was driving back from Augusta with his brother and his brotherâ€™s friend after picking up fish for a family reunion on the July 4th weekend.Â  He explained that as he approached the checkpoint he slowed down in order to allow his brother time to fasten his seatbelt. Â When Branham found the cocaine, Robinson denied that it belonged to him.Â  He further testified that he did not know anything about the cocaine.Â  Additionally, Robinson claimed he had no idea there was an open beer can in his car at the time he was stopped at the checkpoint.Â Â  
The jury convicted Robinson of the lesser-included offense of possession of cocaine.Â  The judge sentenced Robinson to eighteen months imprisonment suspended on eight months probation.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
Robinson argues the circuit court judge erred in denying his motion to suppress.Â  He contends there was insufficient probable cause for Branham to believe a crime was being committed.Â  In support of this contention, Robinson asserts â€œ[t]he beer can was contained in a paper bag and its nature was not immediately apparent to [Branham].Â  Furthermore, [Branham] admitted that he did not normally ticket for a violation of the â€˜open containerâ€™ law.â€Â  Additionally, Robinson relies on Branhamâ€™s testimony that â€œhe uses the â€˜open containerâ€™ law as a tool to â€˜go further into something.â€™â€Â  As will be more fully discussed, we agree with Robinson.
The Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution guarantees â€œ[t]he right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV. Evidence obtained as a result of an unlawful search constitutes a violation of the Fourth Amendment and is inadmissible at trial. State v. Nelson, 336 S.C. 186, 192 n.3, 519 S.E.2d 786, 789 n.3 (1999).Â  â€œThe admission of such evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge whose ruling will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â 
State v. Brannon, 347 S.C. 85, 89, 552 S.E.2d 773, 775 (Ct. App. 2001).
â€œOn appeal from a suppression hearing, this court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence supports the findings.â€ State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004). Â â€œIn an appeal from a motion to suppress evidence based on Fourth Amendment grounds,
an appellate court may conduct its own review of the record to determine whether the evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  Id. at 349-50, 592 S.E.2d at 347.
â€œGenerally, a warrantless search is per se unreasonable and thus violative of the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.â€ State v. Bultron, 318 S.C. 323, 331, 457 S.E.2d 616, 621 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œHowever, a warrantless search will withstand constitutional scrutiny where the search falls within one of a few specifically established and well delineated exceptions to the Fourth Amendment exclusionary rule.â€ Id. at 331-32, 457 S.E.2d at 621.Â  These exceptions include: Â (1) search incident to a lawful arrest; (2) â€œhot pursuit;â€ (3) stop and frisk; (4) automobile exception; (5) â€œplain viewâ€ doctrine; (6) consent; and (7) abandonment. State v. Dupree, 319 S.C. 454, 456-57, 462 S.E.2d 279, 281 (1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1131 (1996).Â  â€œThe burden of establishing probable cause as well as the existence of circumstances constituting an exception to the general prohibition against warrantless searches and seizures is upon the prosecution.â€ Bultron, 318 S.C. at 332, 457 S.E.2d at 621.Â 

â€œThe two bases for the [automobile] exception are:Â  (1) the ready mobility of automobiles and the potential that evidence may be lost before a warrant is obtained; and (2) the lessened expectation of privacy in motor vehicles which are subject to government regulation.â€ State v. Cox, 290 S.C. 489, 491, 351 S.E.2d 570, 571 (1986).Â  â€œ[U]nder the automobile exception, probable cause alone is sufficient to justify a warrantless search.â€Â 
Id. at 492, 351 S.E.2d at 571-72.
â€œThe standard for probable cause to conduct a warrantless search is the same as that for a search with a warrant.â€Â  Bultron, 318 S.C. at 332, 457 S.E.2d at 621.Â  This requires, â€œa justifiable determination, based upon the totality of the circumstances and in view of all the evidence available to law enforcement officials at the time of the search, that there exists a practical, nontechnical probability that a crime is being committed or has been committed and incriminating evidence is involved.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œ[U]nder the automobile exception, if probable cause exists to justify the warrantless search of a lawfully stopped vehicle, it justifies the search of every part of the vehicle and its content that may conceal the object of the search.â€Â  Id. at 332, 457 S.E.2d at 621.
In analyzing the Fourth Amendment implications of a routine traffic stop, this court has explained:

A routine stop constitutes a Fourth Amendment seizure so that when the purpose justifying the stop is exceeded, the detention becomes illegal unless a reasonable suspicion of some other crime exists.Â  United States v. Sullivan, 138 F.3d 126 (4th Cir. 1998); see State v. Robinson, 306 S.C. 399, 402, 412 S.E.2d 411, 413 (1991)(â€œTo justify a brief stop [or] detention, the police officer must have a reasonable suspicion that the person has been involved in criminal activity.â€). Â The term â€œreasonable suspicionâ€ requires a particularized and objective basis that would lead one to suspect another of criminal activity.Â 
United States v. Cortez, 449 U.S. 411, 101 S.Ct. 690, 66 L.Ed. 621 (1981); State v. Woodruff, 344 S.C. 537, 544 S.E.2d 290 (Ct. App. 2001). Â In determining whether reasonable suspicion exists, the whole picture must be considered. United States v. Sokolow, 490 U.S. 1, 109 S.Ct. 1581, 104 L.Ed.2d 1 (1989). Â The burden is on the State to articulate facts sufficient to support reasonable suspicion. State v. Butler, 343 S.C. 198, 539 S.E.2d 414 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

State v. Pichardo, 367 S.C. 84, 104, 623 S.E.2d 840, 851 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
Initially, we note that Robinson does not challenge the legality of the driverâ€™s license checkpoint.Â  Therefore, our analysis is confined to a determination of whether the circuit court judgeâ€™s denial of Robinsonâ€™s motion to suppress based on Branhamâ€™s actions at the checkpoint was supported by any evidence.Â  Although we are cognizant of this limited standard of review, we find there is no evidence to support the judgeâ€™s decision.
Based upon the totality of the circumstances and in view of all the evidence available to Branham at the time of the search, we believe the warrantless search was not justified.Â  We find the State failed to meet its burden to articulate facts sufficient to support a reasonable suspicion that Robinson was involved in criminal activity.
In analyzing this issue, we review the facts submitted by the State during the suppression hearing. Â Essentially, Branham reached his decision to search Robinsonâ€™s vehicle based on the following observations:Â  1). the â€œsuspiciousâ€ behavior of Robinson and his passengers as they approached the checkpoint; 2). the â€œnervousâ€ behavior of Robinson and his passengers once the vehicle stopped at the checkpoint; and 3). the presence of a large can wrapped in a paper bag in Robinsonâ€™s vehicle.Â  Specifically, Branham described Robinsonâ€™s and his passengersâ€™ behavior as they approached the checkpoint as â€œfrantically moving, throwing [their] arms around.â€Â  He found â€œ[t]his was a very suspicious stopping, starting, frantic people inside; very nervous acting people.â€Â  At the checkpoint, Branham claimed the occupants of the vehicle appeared very nervous as if they were hiding something. Â In addition to this behavior, Branham stated his decision to conduct the search was based on his observation of what he believed was a twenty-two ounce can of beer wrapped in a paper bag in the backseat of the vehicle. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Under these circumstances, we believe Branham lacked a particularized and objective basis which would have lead him to suspect Robinson of criminal activity.Â  In terms of the â€œsuspiciousâ€ behavior of Robinson and his passengers, it is significant to note that Branham admitted that he initially observed this behavior at a distance of â€œ[a]nywhere from 75 to 100 yards.â€Â  Furthermore, even if Robinson and his passengers exhibited nervous behavior at the checkpoint, these actions were not necessarily indicative of criminal behavior.Â  See Taylor v. Commonwealth, 369 S.E.2d 423, 425 (Va. Ct. App. 1988)(â€œAlthough in some contexts nervous behavior may be relevant, the mere observation that a traveler is nervous is not indicative of criminal behavior.â€ (citing United States v. Gooding, 695 F.2d 78, 84 (4th Cir. 1982))).Â  It is also interesting that despite the purpose of the license checkpoint, Branham did not immediately ask Robinson for his license, registration, and proof of insurance.Â  Instead, he questioned the occupants as to whether they were hiding something and then visually searched the interior of the vehicle.Â  Although Branham testified that he believed the can which he saw to be an alcoholic beverage, he could not immediately tell that the can was open.[3]Â  The testimony reveals the can was concealed in the paper bag and was pointing away from Branham when he looked in the window of the vehicle.Â  In fact, Branham stated, â€œ[i]t was not in an open situation.Â  A brown bag goes up to the tip of the rim of the can.Â  It wasnâ€™t like an open and look.Â  This is a bag that was molded or formed, you know, like it had been used.â€ From this testimony, it is clear that whether or not the can was an open container of alcohol was not immediately apparent to Branham.Â  See State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 302, 317, 513 S.E.2d 606, 613 (1999) (stating the plain view exception to the search warrant requirement requires that: Â (1) the initial intrusion which afforded the authorities the plain view was lawful; (2) the discovery of the evidence was inadvertent; and (3) the incriminating nature of the evidence was
immediately apparent to the seizing authorities)(emphasis added). Branham also admitted that he did not normally issue a citation for a violation of the open container law.[4]Â  Rather, he testified that he uses the open container law as a tool â€œto go further into something.â€
Taken together, these circumstances indicate that Branhamâ€™s decision to search was not based on a reasonable suspicion, but rather, a mere hunch of the likelihood of criminal activity.Â  See United States v. Arvizu, 534 U.S. 266, 274 (2002)(â€œAlthough an officerâ€™s reliance on a mere â€˜hunchâ€™ is insufficient to justify a stop, the likelihood of criminal activity need not rise to the level required for probable cause, and it falls considerably short of satisfying a preponderance of the evidence standard.â€) (citations omitted). Â Because Branham was not justified in extending the purpose of the license checkpoint into a warrantless search of Robinsonâ€™s vehicle, we hold the trial judge erred in failing to suppress the cocaine found as result of the illegal search.
Furthermore, we reject any contention that Robinson waived his right to challenge this issue on appeal when he testified, in response to Branhamâ€™s questions, that he told Branham â€œit was okayâ€ to check the vehicle. Â Robinson gave this testimony after the suppression hearing during which Branham admitted that he did not ask Robinson for his consent to search.Â  As a result, the trial judge did not use the testimony as a basis for his decision. Â Robinsonâ€™s counsel also continued to object to the admission of the evidence during the trial.Â  
Our decision should in no way be construed as limiting the authority of officers to search a vehicle stopped as part of a checkpoint or other traffic stop.Â  We emphasize that if Trooper Branham had testified that he observed in plain view an open container of alcohol in Robinsonâ€™s vehicle, he would have been justified in conducting a search of the vehicle.Â  Cf. State v. Morris, 312 S.C. 116, 118, 439 S.E.2d 291, 292 (Ct. App. 1993) (stating open beer Â container observed in plain view by officer at a traffic stop gave officer probable cause to arrest defendant and conduct inventory search of the vehicle which revealed crack cocaine).Â  Under the specific facts of this case, we hold the search of Robinsonâ€™s vehicle constituted a Fourth Amendment violation and, thus, the trial judge erred in denying Robinsonâ€™s motion to suppress.
Accordingly, Robinsonâ€™s conviction and sentence are
 REVERSED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Robinsonâ€™s appellate counsel initially filed a brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  After conducting the requisite Anders review, this court ordered re-briefing on the suppression issue.Â  This issue is now our sole appellate consideration.
[2] Â Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]  Section 61-4-110 of the South Carolina Code prohibits a person from having an open container of alcohol in his motor vehicle.Â  This section provides:Â Â  

It is unlawful for a person to have in his possession, except in the trunk or luggage compartment, beer or wine in an open container in a motor vehicle of any kind while located upon the public highways or highway rights of way of this State. Â This section must not be construed to prohibit the transporting of beer or wine in a closed container, and this section does not apply to vehicles parked in legal parking places during functions such as sporting events where law enforcement officers are on duty to perform traffic control duties. Â A person who violates the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, must be fined not more than one hundred dollars or imprisoned not more than thirty days.

 For purposes of this section, beer or wine means any beer or wine containing one-half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-110 (Supp. 2006).
[4] Â We note that Branhamâ€™s decision not to issue a citation for an open container violation is inconsequential to our analysis.Â  See State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 133, 620 S.E.2d 737, 741 (2005), cert. denied, 126 S. Ct. 2287 (2006) (holding fact that officer did not arrest defendant for offense which precipitated his seizure and search did â€œnot vitiate the reasonableness of the underlying searchâ€).Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Minyard Lee Woody, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Â Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-086
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 15, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  State v. Johnston, 333 S.C. 459, 462, 510 S.E.2d 423, 425 (1999) (â€œ[T]his Court has consistently held that a challenge to sentencing must be raised at trial, or the issue will not be preserved for appellate review.â€); State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 120-121, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
