title: Sundown Operating Company v. Intedge Industries
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Sundown Operating Company, Inc., a South Carolina corporation; Sunrise Coin Company, Inc., a South Carolina corporation; and High Noon Properties, Inc., a South Carolina corporation;
Respondents/Appellants,
v.
Intedge Industries, Inc., a New Jersey corporation; Quickie Food Stores of North Myrtle Beach, Inc., d/b/a Hardwick's Bar & Restaurant Supplies, a South Carolina corporation; BFPE International, Inc., f/k/a Atlantic Fire Systems, Inc., a Maryland corporation; Wormald Fire Systems, Inc., f/k/a Ansul Fire Systems, Inc., a Delaware corporation; and Ansul Incorporated, a Delaware corporation,
Defendants,
of whom BFPE International, Inc., f/k/a Atlantic Fire Systems, Inc., a Maryland corporation is
Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-091
Heard December 8, 2006 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, and Carmen V. Ganjehsani, of Columbia; Michael S. Hopewell, of Florence; for Appellant-Respondent.Â  
Daniel Francis Blanchard, III, and Susan Corner Rosen, of Charleston; Peter Fredrick Asmer, Jr., of Charlotte; for Respondent-Appellants.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  On cross-appeals from a default judgment, Sundown Operating Company, Sunrise Coin Company, and High Noon Properties, Inc. (collectively Sundown) contend the master-in-equity erred in (1) failing to award prejudgment interest, (2) invalidating the August 28, 2001 service of the summons and complaint, and (3) finding BFPE International, Inc. f/k/a Atlantic Fire Systems, Inc.â€™s motion complied with Rules 6(d) and 7(b)(1) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  BFPE contends the master erred in failing to find that the October 2, 2001 entry of default should be voided as a matter of law and the master erred in failing to set aside the default judgment.Â Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
On September 16, 1998, a fire destroyed a restaurant and pub owned and operated by Sundown.Â  It is alleged that the fire was caused when a heating element in an electric fryer â€œfailed in an area that was submerged in frying oil causing the frying oil to ignite and burn.â€Â  According to Sundown, the electric fryer was missing a high limit safety thermostat, which was supposed to automatically shut off the power to the heating unit once the frying oil temperature exceeded the safety thermostatâ€™s high temperature set point and would have allowed the frying oil to cool instead of igniting.Â  Sundown also alleges that it had a service contract with BFPE to install, maintain, inspect and service Sundownâ€™s fire equipment, including range hood fire extinguishing systems and fire suppression systems. Â 
On August 24, 2001, Sundown filed a Summons and Complaint against five defendants, including BFPE. Â In its complaint, Sundown asserted causes of action for negligence and breach of contract against BFPE, alleging BFPE failed to properly inspect and maintain the fire suppression system.Â  Sundown further alleged that the fire suppression system failed to operate properly, causing the fire to spread. Â Sundown sought actual and punitive damages and â€œinterest as provided by lawâ€ against all defendants, including BFPE.Â  
BFPE is incorporated in Maryland and has nine business locations throughout Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and South Carolina.Â  Because BFPE does not have a registered agent listed with the South Carolina Secretary of State, Sundown attempted to serve Donald R. Leonard, who was BFPEâ€™s registered agent in Maryland and North Carolina.Â  On August 27, 2001, Sundown sent two copies of its Summons and Complaint to Leonard, at two separate addresses, Myrtle Beach, SC and Rocky Mount, NC.Â  On August 28, 2001, service was accepted at the Myrtle Beach address. Â However, service was not accepted by Leonard, but rather by Randy Adams who signed Leonardâ€™s name.Â  Apparently, Adams asked the postal carrier if he could sign for Leonard who advised him that he could.Â  
The second set of the Summons and Complaint was received and signed for by Leonard on September 4, 2001.Â  On or about September 5, 2001, Leonard gave the Summons and Complaint to David McGlynn, BFPEâ€™s general manager in Clayton, North Carolina. Â Glynn forwarded the papers to BFPEâ€™s Vice President, George Hill, in Hanover, Maryland. Â According to Hill, on September 14, 2001, he then forwarded a letter with copies of the Summons and Complaint to John Doetzer of Consolidated Insurance Carrier, BFPEâ€™s insurance agent. Â Â There is a dispute, however, over when Doetzer received the documents.Â  Doetzer stated that the Summons and Complaint were not enclosed with the September 14, 2001 letter and were not forwarded to him until October 1, 2001.Â  
On October 2, 2001, Doetzer telephoned Sundownâ€™s counsel to inquire about an extension of time to file an Answer. Â Sundownâ€™s counsel informed Doetzer that an entry of default had already been forwarded to the clerk of court and that an extension would most likely not be granted. Â Default was entered on the same day based upon Sundownâ€™s Affidavit of Service by Certified Mail filed on September 17, 2001.Â  On October 15, 2001, suit papers were sent by BFPEâ€™s insurance carrier, CNA Insurance Company, to the assigned defense counsel for BFPE.Â  
On October 18, 2001, BFPE filed a Notice of Motion and Motion to Set Aside Default and to Permit Enlargement of Time. Â On October 29, 2001, Sundown filed a Motion for Judgment by Default against BFPE based on the August 28, 2001 service date and entry of default on October 2, 2001.Â  Sundown then filed another Affidavit of Counsel in Support of Entry of Default based on the September 4, 2001 service date.Â  A second entry of default based on the September 4, 2001 service of process was entered on December 10, 2001.Â  
A hearing was set for March 18, 2002 to hear BFPEâ€™s Motion to Set Aside Entry of Default.Â  On March 12 and 14, 2002, BFPE filed seven affidavits in support of its motion.Â  At the hearing, the circuit court allowed BFPE to file an Answer, based partly on the holding in Pilgrim v. Miller, 2002 WL 44112 (S.C. Ct. App. Jan. 14, 2002).Â  However, upon learning that this court had granted a Petition for Rehearing in the Pilgrim case, the circuit court decided to delay issuing its opinion.Â  On June 17, 2002, this court reversed the earlier opinion, affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion to set aside the default in that case.Â  See Pilgrim v. Miller, 305 S.C. 637, 567 S.E.2d 52 (Ct. App. 2002).[1]Â  On July 18, 2002, the circuit court held a second hearing on BFPEâ€™s motion to set aside the default and denied BFPEâ€™s motion.Â Â  
On September 28, 2004, an Order of Reference was issued referring the case to the master for a hearing to assess damages against BFPE and for the issuance of a final order.Â  After the damages hearing, the master entered separate judgments in favor of Sundown as follows:Â  (1) an award of $273,336.00 in actual damages to Sunrise; (2) an award of $394,848.38 in actual damages to Sundown Operating Company; and (3) an award of $524,800.70 in actual damages to High Noon. Â The master denied Sundownâ€™s request for prejudgment interest.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Prejudgment Interest
Sundown contends the master erred in failing to award prejudgment interest.Â  We disagree.Â  
An award of prejudgment interest is within the discretion of the fact-finder and will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See Knight v. Sullivan Power Co., 140 S.C. 296, 304, 138 S.E. 818, 820-21 (1927) (stating that in exercising its discretion, a jury â€œmight assess interest as a part of the damagesâ€).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when an order is controlled by an error of law or when the order is without evidentiary support. Â Thompson v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 900, 902-903 (1989).Â  
Initially, we address BFPEâ€™s argument that Sundown failed to specifically plead for the recovery of prejudgment interest in its complaint as required by South Carolina law.Â  It has been well established under South Carolina law that parties must plead for prejudgment interest in order for it to be recovered.Â  See McMillan v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Agric., 364 S.C. 60, 74, 611 S.E.2d 323, 330 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œPrejudgment interest must be specifically pled in order to be recovered.â€)Â  â€œIf no request for prejudgment interest is made in the pleadings, it cannot be recovered on appeal.â€Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 375, 585 S.E.2d 292, 299 (2003) (citation omitted).Â  
In its complaint, Sundown makes only a general request for â€œinterest as provided by law.â€Â  This request is too general and vague to meet the strict requirement that a demand for prejudgment interest must be specifically pled.Â  Sundown offers numerous cases for the proposition that a pleading such as its is sufficient.Â  However, all of the cases cited are outside this jurisdiction, and South Carolina case law is controlling. Â Accordingly, Sundown did not sufficiently plead prejudgment interest and thus should not be awarded such.Â  
However, even if this court were to find Sundown sufficiently pled prejudgment interest, the master was correct in refusing the award.Â  Sundown argues it is entitled to an award of prejudgment interest under two theories.Â  First, Sundown argues it should be awarded prejudgment interest as an element of damages.Â  
Sundown cites to the cases of Knight v. Sullivan Power Co., 140 S.C. 296, 138 S.E. 818 (1927) and Wilson & Co. v. Atlanta & Charlotte Airline Ry., 16 S.C. 587 (1882) for the proposition that prejudgment interest can be recovered in tort claims.Â  However, in both of these cases it was recognized that a plaintiff could not recover interest as a matter of right or interest eo nominee, which means â€œunder that name,â€Â  and that it would have been possible error for a jury to have specifically awarded interest eo nominee.Â  Knight at 304, 138 S.E. at 820-21; Wilson 16 S.C. 587. Â In each case, the jury merely awarded lump sum damages, and it was impossible for the appellate court to have determined whether the jury did in fact include interest in the verdicts.Â  
More recent South Carolina cases dealing with prejudgment interest state that, as a general rule, prejudgment interest is not recoverable on an unliquidated claim in the absence of agreement or statute.Â  See Builders Transp., Inc. v. S.C. Prop. & Cas. Ins. Guar. Assoc., 307 S.C. 398, 406, 415 S.E.2d 419, 424 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œA claim is liquidated if the sum claimed is certain or capable of being reduced to a certainty.â€Â  Id.Â  Unliquidated claims that are capable of being reduced to certainty by a simple mathematical calculation can be considered liquidated for the purpose of awarding prejudgment interest under South Carolina law. Â Id.Â  Liquidated damages â€œare damages the amount of which has been made certain and fixed either by the act and agreement of the parties or by operation of law to a sum which cannot be changed by the proof.â€Â  22 Am. Jur. 2d Damages Â§ 489 (2003).
The facts of this case demonstrate that Sundownâ€™s claim was not capable of being reduced to a certainty. Â Sundownâ€™s damages are simply not of the type that can be made certain or cannot be changed by proof.Â  In order to determine the damages to be awarded, the master had to consider the testimony of fact witnesses, expert witnesses and exhibits admitted into evidence.Â  There was no fixed formula used for determining the amount of Sundownâ€™s damages.Â Â  At the time the claim arose, the date of the fire, conditions were not fixed for determining the amount of Sundownâ€™s damages to a sum certain.Â  The testimony of Sundownâ€™s fact witnesses and the exhibits presented by Sundown demonstrate the measure of recovery was not fixed on the date of the fire.Â  Furthermore, many of Sundownâ€™s damages did not even arise until after the date of the fire, such as the lost profits and revenues, loan and interest charges, legal and permit fees, storage charges, and rental income.Â  Accordingly, Sundownâ€™s damages were not liquidated, and therefore, Sundown was not entitled to prejudgment interest as an element of damages.Â  
As its second argument, Sundown argues it should be awarded prejudgment interest pursuant to section 34-31-20(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), which provides:Â  

In all cases of accounts stated and in all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due, shall draw interest according to law, the legal interest shall be at the rate of eight and three-fourths percent per annum.Â  

While all parties agree that the instant case does not involve an account stated, Sundown contends it involves damages that are readily ascertainable and capable of being reduced to a sum certain.Â  Based on the reasoning stated above, this argument fails, and Sundown is not entitled to an award of prejudgment interest.Â  
Service of Process Issues
BFPE contends the October 2, 2001 entry of default should be voided because it was based on a service of process that was later found to be insufficient.Â  BFPE argues that if this court voids the October 2, 2001 entry of default, the masterâ€™s order should also be voided because it was based on the October 2, 2001 entry of default.Â  We disagree.Â  Furthermore, as an additional sustaining ground Sundown contends the October 2, 2001 entry of default should not be voided because the circuit court erred in invalidating the August 28, 2001 service.Â  We agree.Â  
Questions of fact arising on a motion to quash service of process for lack of jurisdiction over the defendant are to be determined by the court. Lawson v. Jeter, 243 S.C. 103, 106, 132 S.E.2d 276, 277 (1963). Appellate courts are bound by the circuit courtâ€™s finding on such issues unless they are â€œwholly unsupported by the evidence or manifestly influenced or controlled by error of law.â€ Â Id.Â  The plaintiff has the burden to establish that the court has personal jurisdiction over the defendant. Jensen v. Doe, 292 S.C. 592, 594, 358 S.E.2d 148, 149 (Ct. App. 1987). The plaintiff need only show compliance with the rules. Â Roche v. Young Bros., Inc., 318 S.C. 207, 211, 456 S.E.2d 897, 900 (1995). â€œWhen the civil rules on service are followed, there is a presumption of proper service.â€ Â Id. (citing 62B Am Jur 2d Process Â§ 111 (1990)). 
Sundown is correct in arguing that the circuit court erred in voiding the August 28, 2001 service of process.Â Â  BFPE has failed to show that Adams was unauthorized to accept service of process for BFPE.Â  See Roche, 318 S.C. at 211, 456 S.E.2d at 900 (stating that under Rule 4(d)(8), the defendant, not the plaintiff, must prove that the receipt was signed by an unauthorized person, and the plaintiff need only show compliance with the rules).Â  The procedural rules governing service upon a corporation state in pertinent part that personal service shall be made as follows:Â Â Â  

(3) Corporations and Partnerships. Upon a corporation or upon a partnership or other unincorporated association which is subject to suit under a common name, by delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to an officer, a managing or general agent, or to any other agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process and if the agent is one authorized by statute to receive service and the statute so requires, by also mailing a copy to the defendant.
(8) Service by Certified Mail. Service of a summons and complaint upon a defendant of any class referred to in paragraph (1) or (3) of this subdivision of this rule may be made by the plaintiff or by any person authorized to serve process pursuant to Rule 4(c), including a sheriff or his deputy, by registered
or certified mail, return receipt requested and delivery restricted to the addressee. Service is effective upon the date of delivery as shown on the return receipt. Service pursuant to this paragraph shall not be the basis for the entry of a default or a judgment by default unless the record contains a return receipt showing the acceptance by the defendant. Any such default or judgment by default shall be set aside pursuant to Rule 55(c) or Rule 60(b) if the defendant demonstrates to the court that the return receipt was signed by an unauthorized person. If delivery of the process is refused or is returned undelivered, service shall be made as otherwise provided by these rules.

Rule 4(d)(3), (8), SCRCP.Â  Under Rule 4(d), service may be effected upon a â€œmanaging or general agentâ€ of a corporation â€œeven though the managing or general agent was not specifically authorized by the corporation to accept service.â€Â  62B Am. Jur. 2d Process Â§ 272 (1990).Â  In Adamsâ€™ affidavit, he states that he is the â€œmanagerâ€ of BFPEâ€™s location in Wilmington, North Carolina, and was working at BFPEâ€™s locations in Myrtle Beach on August 28, 2001.Â  
Furthermore, in Schenk v. National Health Care, Inc., 322 S.C. 316, 319-20, 471 S.E.2d 736, 737-8 (Ct. App. 1996), this court held that service was proper on a corporate defendant when the summons and complaint were delivered to the an office manager who told the process server that she would pass the papers along to headquarters.Â Â Â  Sundown has shown compliance with the rules for service, and BFPE has failed to show Adams was not authorized to accept service.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court erred in finding the August 28, 2001 service of process invalid.Â  Additionally, because the August 28, 2001 service of process was valid, the October 2, 2001 entry of default was valid as well.Â  
Motion to Set Aside Entry of Default
BFPE argues the circuit court erred in failing to set aside the October 2, 2001, entry of default.Â  We disagree.Â  
The decision of whether to set aside an entry of default or a default judgment lies solely within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and such a decision will not be reversed absent an abuse of that discretion. Â Thompson v. Hammond, 299 S.C. 116, 119, 382 S.E.2d 900, 902-03 (1989).
An abuse of discretion occurs when the order was controlled by an error of law or when the order is without evidentiary support. Â Id.
As a preliminary matter, BFPE contends the circuit court erred in employing the wrong standard in its order denying the motion to set aside default.Â  In matters concerning a default judgment, Rule 55, SCRCP, states default may be entered when a party â€œagainst whom a judgment for affirmative relief is sought has failed to plead or otherwise defend as provided by these rules and that fact is made to appear by affidavit or otherwise.â€Â  An entry of default may be set aside â€œ[f]or good cause shownâ€ and, if a â€œjudgment by default has been entered, [the court] may likewise set it aside in accordance with Rule 60(b).â€Â  See Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP, states that relief from judgment or order may be given based on the following:Â  

(b) Mistakes; Inadvertence; Excusable Neglect; Newly Discovered Evidence; Fraud, etc. On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:
    
  (1) mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect;

  (2) newly discovered evidence which by due diligence could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b);

  (3) fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party;

  (4) the judgment is void;

  (5) the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, or a prior judgment upon which it is based has been reversed or otherwise vacated, or it is no longer equitable that the judgment should have prospective application.

The circuit court clearly used the correct standard in upholding the entry of default.Â  In its order, the circuit court specifically stated that â€œin order to have an entry of default set aside, a defaulting party must show that there is â€˜good causeâ€™ for doing so.â€Â  The circuit court went on to say that â€œas a practical matter, the criteria for obtaining relief from a judgment under SCRCP 60(b) â€“ mistake, inadvertence, excusable neglect, surprise, newly discovered evidence, fraud, misrepresentation â€“ are also relevant in determining whether good cause has been shown under SCRCP 55(c), although the factors are applied with greater liberality within the context of Rule 55(c) vis-Ã -vis Rule 60(b).â€Â Â  The circuit court was correct in this assessment.Â  See Hill v. Dotts, 345 S.C. 304, 310, 547 S.E.2d 894, 897 (Ct. App. 2001).Â Â  The circuit court went on to correctly apply these factors in finding that no basis for setting aside the entry of default existed.Â  
Next, BFPE contends the circuit court erred in failing to set aside the entry of default because it satisfied the factors as laid out in the case of Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros., Inc., 298 S.C. 462, 381 S.E.2d 499 (Ct.Â  App. 1989), and because there was good cause.Â  Wham lists three factors to be used when deciding to set aside an entry of default under Rule 55(c).Â Â  These are
(1) the timing of the motion for relief; (2) whether there is a meritorious defense; and (3) the degree of prejudice if relief is granted.Â  Id. at 465, 381 S.E.2d at 501-2.Â  BFPE filed its motion to set aside the entry of default on October 18, 2001, and did not file its memoranda supporting this motion until March 18, 2002.Â  Though BFPE asserts it has a meritorious defense as required by Wham, the timing of the motion, the prejudice that would ensue, coupled with the standard of review this court must follow in setting aside an entry of default prevents this court from finding the circuit court erred in failing to set aside the entry of default.Â  
Additionally, BFPE contends there was good cause to set aside the entry of default because the circuit court partially relied on the case of Pilgrim v. Miller, 350 S.C. 637, 567 S.E.2d 527 (Ct. App. 2002) for its finding that a party did not demonstrate good cause for setting aside the entry of default when her insurer had negligently failed to answer a complaint filed against her despite the fact that the party had promptly delivered the suit papers to her insurer well within the time allotted for answering.Â  In Pilgrim, this court held that the insurerâ€™s â€œfailure to answer the complaint is imputed toâ€ the defaulting party.Â  Id. At 642, 567 S.E.2d 529.Â  BFPE contends the trial court erred in relying on Pilgrim because the case was later vacated on April 25, 2003, almost a year after the trial court issued its opinion.Â Â Â  
However, the case law the Pilgrim court based its decision on is still good law.Â  The courts of this state have consistently held that the negligence of an attorney or insurance company is imputable to a defaulting litigant.
Â See Roberts v. Peterson, 292 S.C. 149, 151, 355 S.E.2d 280, 281 (Ct. App. 1987) (noting, in a case involving the failure of a school official to answer a complaint on behalf of a school employee, that â€œthe negligence in the failure to act was more excusable, we think, than the cases involving attorneys or insurance companiesâ€); see also Ledford v. Pa. Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 671, 677, 230 S.E.2d 900, 903 (1976) (holding, on appeal of an order vacating a default judgment, that an insurance company attorneyâ€™s failure to answer the complaint was not such mistake or excusable neglect as to warrant vacation of the default judgment).Â Â  Accordingly, the circuit court based its denial of the motion to set aside entry of default on theories that are still sound in todayâ€™s case law. Â Â Â 
BFPE argues that the conflicting case of Ricks v. Weinrauch, 293 S.C. 372, 373-75, 360 S.E.2d 535, 536-37 (Ct. App. 1987) (relying on Sears, Roebuck & Co. v. Ramey, 318 S.E.2d 740, 742 (Ga. Ct. App. 1984)) should be controlling.Â  In the Ricks case, this court concluded that a defendantâ€™s belief that her insurance company was defending a complaint filed against her was sufficient for a showing of good cause to set aside an entry of default.Â  Id. at 373-5, 360 S.E.2d 536-7.Â  However, notwithstanding the Ricks case, the case law that the circuit court based its decision on is still good law and has not been overturned.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in refusing the set aside the entry of default.[2]Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  The second Pilgrim opinion was later vacated after the parties settled. Â 
[2]  Because we affirm on the previous issue, we need not reach the additional issue of whether BFPEâ€™s Motion to Set Aside Entry of Default complied with Rules 6(d) and 7(b)(1) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  See 
Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (â€œ[A]n appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive.â€).

title: Mary Black Health System v. Watterson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Mary Black Health System, LLC d/b/a Mary Black Memorial Hospital,
Respondent,
v.
Phillip Watterson, M.D., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-092
Heard September 14, 2006 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Matthew A. Henderson and Joshua M. Henderson, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
Julie Jeffords Moose, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Philip Watterson appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Mary Black Health System, LLC, d/b/a Mary Black Memorial Hospital (Mary Black).Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
In November 1998, Watterson and Mary Black entered into a contract entitled Physician Relocation Agreement (Agreement) in which Watterson agreed to relocate to the Spartanburg, South Carolina area in order to practice medicine in the field of Obstetrics and Gynecology (OB-GYN).Â  In the agreement Mary Black specifically stated that â€œ[Watterson] was recruited by [Mary Black] to fulfill a community need relating to the shortage of physicians in [Wattersonâ€™s] specialty in the community.â€Â Â Â  
Pursuant to the terms of the Agreement, Mary Black guaranteed that the cash collections for Wattersonâ€™s practice would be no less than $30,000.00 per month (the â€œGuarantee Amountâ€) during his first year of practice (the â€œGuarantee Periodâ€).Â  Mary Black was required to advance Watterson the Guarantee Amount for the initial month and continue advancing payments on or before the last day of each calendar month for one year. Â The amount of each payment was to be reduced by the total cash collections for the immediately proceeding month.Â  Watterson was obligated to pay back the advanced money after that first year.Â  However, the agreement also provided that at the end of the Guarantee Period, Mary Black would forgive and cancel one twenty-fourth of all amounts owed by Watterson for each calendar month he remained in the full-time practice of medicine in the Spartanburg area beyond the Guarantee Period.Â  Thus, if Watterson were to maintain his practice in the Spartanburg area for two years after the end of the Guarantee Period, the debt would be forgiven.Â Â Â  
After moving to South Carolina, Watterson entered into practice with Dr. John Herbert in Spartanburg.Â  In the Guarantee Period, Watterson received $292,606.87 in cash collection guarantee payments from Mary Black and a loan intended to help him set up his practice.Â  During the same time period, Mary Black added five additional OB-GYNâ€™s to its list of physicians and began construction of a new building to be attached to Mary Black for the purpose of housing two groups of OB-GYNâ€™s.Â  Mary Black also purchased many of the family practice groups in the area from which Watterson had hoped to receive referrals.Â  Furthermore, Mary Black failed to list Wattersonâ€™s practice in the telephone directory for 1998-99 allegedly causing Watterson to lose out on potential clients.Â  
Following the end of the first year of practice, Wattersonâ€™s partner decided to move his practice to a less expensive space.Â  Watterson was diagnosed with prostate cancer soon thereafter and was forced to resign.Â  Watterson terminated his Spartanburg practice in October of 1999.Â  After recovery, Watterson, contacted Mary Black, but was told no employment opportunities existed.Â  Watterson then moved from the Spartanburg area.Â Â Â  
Mary Black brought this action alleging it was owed the sum of $279,633.70 plus interest and attorneyâ€™s fees for the repayment of the cash collections guarantee and loan extended to Watterson.Â  Watterson filed his Answer and Set-Off/Counterclaim, alleging affirmative defenses of estoppel and waiver.Â  Mary Black filed its motion for summary judgment, which was decided without oral argument by order dated April 9, 2004.Â  The circuit court granted Mary Blackâ€™s motion for summary judgment and entered judgment against Watterson for $348,550.41.Â  Watterson made a motion to reconsider, which was subsequently denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate courts apply the same standard that governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, which states that summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005). â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€ Helms Realty, Inc., 363 S.C. at 340, 611 S.E.2d at 488.Â  Â â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â  Summary judgment should be granted when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ.Â  Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Summary Judgment 
Watterson argues the circuit court erred in granting Mary Black summary judgment because its claims are barred by estoppel or waiver. Â 
Initially, Mary Black asserts Watterson has failed to preserve these issues for our review.Â  Mary Black contends that although Watterson pled the affirmative defenses of waiver and estoppel in his Answer, he failed to present such defenses to the circuit court and the circuit court did not rule on these issues.Â  Â Â 
Watterson raised the issues of estoppel and waiver in his answer. Â Thus, the issues were presented to the circuit court. While the circuit court did not specifically rule on these issues in its initial order, as Mary Blackâ€™s counsel acknowledged at oral argument, Watterson presented the issue of estoppel to the court in the Rule 59(e), SCRCP proceedings.Â  At the hearing for the Rule 59(e) motion, Watterson specifically argued the elements of estoppel and specifically mentioned estoppel giving Mary Black the opportunity to respond to the arguments.Â  We find the issue of estoppel is preserved for our review. See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (stating when an issue presented to the trial court is not explicitly ruled on in the final order, the issue must be raised by an appropriate post-trial motion to be preserved for appeal).
On the other hand, Watterson failed to preserve the issue of waiver.Â  Watterson failed to argue waiver in both the application and the hearing for his Rule 59(e) motion.Â  In addition, though he raises the issue of waiver in his appellate brief, he fails to make a meaningful argument concerning this issue.Â  An issue which is not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and precludes consideration on appeal. Â Fields v. Fields, 342 S.C. 182, 191 n.8, 536 S.E.2d 684, 689 n.8 (Ct. App. 2000) (stating that appellate court cannot reach issue where the appellant included issue in statement of issues on appeal but failed to argue issue in body of brief).Â  We find the issue of waiver is not properly before this court.Â  
On the merits, Watterson argues Mary Black should be estopped from collecting under the relocation agreement based on the representations they made at the time the agreement was signed.Â 
â€œEstoppel arises when a party, relying upon what another has said or done, changes his position to his detriment.â€ Â Gibbs v. Kimbrell, 311 S.C. 261, 268, 428 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 1993). Â A claim of
estoppel includes elements for the party asserting estoppel and the party estopped. Â Provident Life & Accident Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 477, 451 S.E.2d 924, 928 (Ct. App. 1994).
The essential elements of equitable estoppel as related to the party estopped are: (1) conduct amounting to a false representation or concealment of material facts, or, at least, which is calculated to convey the impression that the facts are otherwise than, and inconsistent with, those which the party subsequently attempts to assert; (2) intention, or at least expectation, that such conduct shall be acted upon by the other party; and (3) knowledge, actual or constructive, of the real facts. Â S. Dev. Land & Golf Co. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Auth., 311 S.C. 29, 33, 426 S.E.2d 748, 750 (1993).Â  As related to the party claiming the
estoppel, they are: (1) lack of knowledge and of the means of knowledge of the truth as to the facts in question; (2) reliance on the conduct of the party estopped; and (3) a prejudicial change in position. Â Id.
We find no evidence in the record to support the first element of equitable estoppel as to the party estopped.Â  Watterson asserts Mary Black represented to him, in the Agreement and otherwise, that the Spartanburg community was â€œunderservedâ€ in the area of OB-GYN, that there was a â€œshortageâ€ of OB-GYN physicians and that there was a â€œcommunity needâ€ for Wattersonâ€™s services.Â Â  The record simply contains no evidence that any of these representations were false.Â  In addition, Watterson complains Mary Black concealed from him that it would be adding five new OB-GYN physicians and adding a new facility for these physicians and others. â€œEstoppel by silence arises where a person owing another a duty to speak refrains from doing so and thereby leads the other to believe in the existence of an erroneous state of facts.â€ Â S. Dev. Land & Golf Co., 311 S.C. at 33, 426 S.E.2d at 751.Â  The duty to speak may arise from:Â  (1) a preexisting fiduciary relationship; (2) where in the particular transaction in question one party expressly reposes a trust and confidence in the other or where from the circumstances of the case, the nature of their dealings, or their position towards each other, such a trust and confidence in the particular case is necessarily implied; and â€œ(3) where the very contract or transaction itself, in its essential nature, is intrinsically fiduciary and necessarily calls for perfect good faith and full disclosure without regard to any particular intention of the parties.â€ Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340, 361, 559 S.E.2d 327, 339 (Ct. App. 2001).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
We find no duty on the part of Mary Black to disclose this information to Watterson.Â  There was no fiduciary duty between the parties and the Agreement did not create one.Â  The Agreement did not contain any type of exclusivity clause.Â  Mary Black did not make any representations to Watterson that it would not hire additional physicians or that it would inform him if it did hire others.Â Â  
As Watterson failed to establish an essential element of equitable estoppel, we hold the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment to Mary Black.Â  
II.  Calculation of Payments 
Watterson contends the circuit court erred in calculating the payments due under the physician relocation agreement. As he failed to raise this inaccuracy in the calculation to the trial court in his Rule 59, SCRCP, motion, the issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Padgett v. Mercado, 341 S.C. 229, 233, 533 S.E.2d 339, 341 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œAny argument alleging an inaccuracy or inconsistency in an order must be raised by a post-trial motion.â€).Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, CJ., and HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â

title: Walsh v. Walsh
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Erik C. Walsh, Respondent,
v.
Jodie Walsh, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-093
Heard January 10, 2007 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Rebecca R. West, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Pamela Michele Pearson, of Rock Hill; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jodie Walsh (Mother) appeals a family court order resulting from an emergency custody hearing brought by Erik Walsh (Father). Â The family court ordered her not to remove the children from South Carolina pending resolution of custody issues.Â  Mother argues the family court lacked jurisdiction because the divorce took place in New York, and Mother and children had lived in South Carolina for approximately four months. Â We dismiss the appeal.
FACTS
Father and Mother married on July 6, 1991, and separated in April 1998.Â  The couple was divorced on November 17, 2002, by a New York court order.Â  The marriage produced three children, all of whom are minors.Â  New York orders dated July 18, 1998, and July 20, 1999, awarded Father and Mother joint custody, with Mother having physical custody.Â  
On October 21, 2005, Father filed a â€œComplaint For Setting Expedited Hearingâ€ seeking â€œemergency temporary custody of the minor children,â€
Â alleging that Mother left the minor children unattended on a regular basis and that he could provide a stable home for the children.Â  Father also stated the parties had relocated to South Carolina in July of 2005, and that Mother had told him she planned to move back to New York with the children on October 28, 2005.Â Â  Â 
Following a hearing, the family court issued an Â order, dated November 27, 2005, assuming jurisdiction of the matter on the grounds that Father resided in North Carolina, Mother resided in South Carolina, and becauseÂ  Â substantial evidence no longer existed in New York regarding the children. Â The court ordered that the children should remain in Motherâ€™s custody and could not leave South Carolina except when visiting Father in North Carolina.Â  The family court also appointed a guardian ad litem to represent the interests of the children and granted the parties the right to engage in discovery.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother argues the family court erred in assuming jurisdiction of this case under both the South Carolinaâ€™s Uniform Child Custody Act and under the federal Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act.Â  We decline to address these issues because we hold the underlying order is interlocutory and hence not immediately
appealable.
Absent some specialized statute, the immediate appealability of an interlocutory or intermediate order depends on whether the order falls within section 14-3-330 of the South Carolina Code.Â  SeeÂ  Baldwin Construction Co., Inc. v. Graham, 357 S.C. 227, 230, 593 S.E.2d 146, 147 (2004).Â  Interlocutory orders affecting a substantial right may be immediately appealed if they discontinue an action, prevent an appeal, grant or refuse a new trial, or strike out an action or defense.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(2) (1976); Edwards v. Suncom, 369 S.C. 91, 94, 631 S.E.2d 529, 531 (2006).Â  
By its very terms, the order under appeal is not final.Â  Indeed, the family court judge stated at the hearing that she was acting on â€œan expedited emergency basis.â€Â  The judge specifically invited the parties to â€œfile for a temporary action (sic) and get all these other issues settled but right now the children are not leaving the this state and a guardian will be appointed.â€
Mother argues this court recently held that â€œ[m]atters involving the custody of oneâ€™s child certainly constitute a â€˜substantial right.â€™â€Â  Widdicombe v. P. Tucker-Cales, 366 S.C 75, 85, 620 S.E.2d 333, 338 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  This case is unlike Widdicombe, a case limited to its peculiar facts and procedural posture.[1]Â  Nothing makes the family courtâ€™s order in this case effectively final.Â  South Carolina law clearly holds that an order denying a challenge to the trial courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction is interlocutory and not immediately appealable.Â  Deskins v. Boltin, 319 S.C. 356, 357 461 S.E.2d 395, 396 (1995).Â  Therefore this order is not presently appealable under section 14-3-330 of the South Carolina Code (1976).
For the reasons stated above, we find the family courtâ€™s order is not appealable, and therefore decline to address Motherâ€™s jurisdiction arguments.Â  
APPEAL DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] In Widdicombe, a temporary order reversing custody had been stricken from the active roster for over three years, and the appellantâ€™s motion for relief from judgment in the family court had been denied as interlocutory and past the statute of limitations, but the family court had reaffirmed its subject matter jurisdiction.Â  The Court of Appeals found the family courtâ€™s orders thus had the practical effect of a final order affecting the appellantâ€™s substantial rights.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Joanne B. Whitlock, Appellant,
        v.
        John W. Whitlock, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â A. E. â€œGeneâ€ Morehead, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-095
Submitted January 9, 2007 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jan L. Warner, of Columbia; for Appellant.
        John S. Nichols, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Joann B. Whitlock (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding John W. Whitlock (Husband) did not violate the terms of the Pendente Lite Consent Order, the Final Order, and the Decree of Divorce.Â Â  Wife contends the family court erred in: Â (1) modifying the orders as it lacked jurisdiction to do so; (2) finding the previous family court had not addressed issues of taxation in the Final Decree; (3) failing to hold Husband in contempt; (4) delegating to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) the power to determine the deductibility of court-ordered alimony; and (5) failing to award attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and accountant fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â  
FACTS
The parties were married on February 9, 1964, in the state of Georgia.Â Â  The couple had two children.Â  In June 1999, Husband became involved in an adulterous relationship which resulted in the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  On June 24, 1999, Wife filed for divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  Husband filed an Answer and Counterclaim on August 17, 1999. Â Wife filed an Amended Reply to the Answer and Counterclaim on October 27, 1999.Â  Â Â 
The family court (Judge Riddle) entered a Pendente Lite Consent Order on July 9, 1999. Â In pertinent part, the Pendente Lite Consent Order provided:Â  

  Defendant-Husband shall pay directly to Plaintiff-Wife the sum of $1,858.65 per month as temporary alimony commencing and effective July 1, 1999 pending further agreement or order.Â  From that alimony, and with her own earnings from her employment, Plaintiff-Wife shall pay the expenses detailed on her Financial Declaration Budget Form (copy attached), except the health insurance which shall be provided and paid for by Defendant-Husband.Â  If extraordinary expenses arise, they shall be dealt with by supplemental agreement or order.Â  The payment of this pendente lite alimony is without prejudice on the merits and shall have no tax consequences to Plaintiff-Wife, pendente lite.Â  The trial judge may, however, reallocate tax consequences at the final hearing.Â  

(Emphasis added).Â Â Â  
A final hearing was held before the family court (Judge Edwards) on March 19 and 20, 2001, and April 23, 2001.Â  Judge Edwards issued a Final Order and Decree of Divorce on December 5, 2001.Â  The Final Order provided that the Pendente Lite Consent Order should remain in effect through and including December 2001.Â  The terms of the Final Order awarded Wife $2,200.00 permanent periodic alimony, taxable to Wife and deductible to Husband for tax purposes, commencing the date of the order.Â  Â Â Neither party moved for reconsideration of the Final Order, nor did either party appeal from the Final Order. Â 
In the first year after the parties separated, they filed joint tax returns.Â Â Â  In the years after, the parties filed separately.Â  Some time in 2003, Wife was contacted by the IRS concerning her tax liability for the year 2000.Â  She was told she owed the IRS $4,887.06 based on the temporary alimony paid to her by Husband.Â  Wife immediately contacted Husband about the letter and he told her he would contact the IRS to â€œask their advice.â€Â  Wife hired an accountant to advise her in the matter.Â  
On August 1, 2004, Wife moved for an Order and Rule to Show Cause why Husband should not be held in contempt for failing to comply with the Pendente Lite Consent Order by refusing to abide by the taxation allocation thereunder for the 2000 tax year.Â  On October 13, 2004, Husband offered to settle the case by paying the $4,887.06 owed by Wife to the IRS.Â  On October 14, 2004, the family court (Judge Morehead) held a hearing and on March 14, 2005, issued an order.Â  Judge Morehead ruled Husband was not in willful contempt and denied Wifeâ€™s claim for relief.Â  Specifically, he found the following:Â  

  I find [Husband] to be a credible person, and [he] has not willfully violated the court order.Â  I further find this court cannot require [Husband] to pay the amount [Wife] paid to the IRS or the CPA fees she incurred or the legal fees and costs she has incurred.Â  Judge Edwardâ€™s [sic] order did not address the pendente lite deductibility or non-deductibility of the temporary alimony.Â  Judge Edwardâ€™s [sic] order required that permanent periodic alimony would begin on January, 2002 and be taxable to [Wife] and deductible to [Husband], but the order is silent as to the Pendente Lite Consent Order as it relates to the treatment of the temporary alimony.Â  The Pendente Lite Consent Order states that the pendente lite alimony may be reallocated at the final hearing.Â  Judge Edwards determined the deductibility and taxability of the permanent periodic alimony, but the court did not address the prior Pendente Lite Consent Order of the parties as it dealt with temporary alimony.Â  

Wife timely moved pursuant to Rules 52, 59, and 60, SCRCP, and Rule 2(a), SCRFC, for reconsideration of the order.Â  Wife filed this appeal after Judge Morehead denied her motion. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302, 307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant of her burden to convince this court that the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
DISCUSSION
I.
Wife contends Judge Morehead erroneously modified Judge Riddleâ€™s unappealed Pendente Lite Consent Order and Judge Edwardsâ€™ Final Order entered in this case.Â  Specifically, Wife asserts Judge Moreheadâ€™s authority was limited to enforcement of these orders and, thus, he was without jurisdiction to modify them.Â  We disagree.Â  Â Â 
We believe Wifeâ€™s arguments mischaracterize Judge Moreheadâ€™s rulings.Â  Judge Morehead did not change the terms of the prior orders.Â  Instead, he properly exercised his authority when he read the language of the orders in question, took testimony on the issues, and ultimately employed rules of construction to interpret the language of the two prior family court orders.Â  See Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 214, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601-02 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating agreement which becomes part of family courtâ€™s order is â€œfully subject to the family courtâ€™s authority to interpret and enforce its own decreesâ€); see also Covington v. Covington, 306 S.C. 473, 475, 412 S.E.2d 455, 456 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding judgments are to be construed like other written instruments).Â  Accordingly, we find no merit to Wifeâ€™s argument that Judge Morehead improperly modified the orders at issue in this case.
II.
Wife argues Judge Morehead erred in finding that Judge Edwards failed to address the temporary alimony taxation issues in the Final Order.Â  We agree.Â  
In his order, Judge Morehead found that â€œJudge Edwardâ€™s [sic] order did not address the pendente lite deductibility or non-deductibility of the temporary alimony.â€Â  However, this finding was in error as the Final Order clearly provided that â€œThe Pendente Lite Consent Order issued on July 7, 1999 shall remain in effect through and including the calendar month in which this decree is issued.â€Â  Although the Pendente Lite Consent Order stated that â€œ[t]he trial judge may, however, reallocate tax consequences at the final hearing,â€ the family court failed to do so.Â  The Pendente Lite Consent Order provided that â€œ[t]he payment of this pendente lite alimony is without prejudice on the merits and shall have no tax consequences to Plaintiff-Wife, pendente lite.â€Â  Â Â 
The orders at issue were clear and unambiguous.Â  If the language employed is plain and unambiguous, there is no room for construction or interpretation, and the effect thereof must be declared in the light of the literal meaning of the language used.Â  Stanaland v. Jamison, 275 S.C. 50, 53, 263 S.E.2d 578, 579 (1980) (noting family court has the duty â€œto construe a contract which is subject to more than one interpretation, but when the terms of a contract are clear, there is no room for interpretation and the parties must live with the agreement which was madeâ€); In re White, 299 S.C. 406, 412, 385 S.E.2d 211, 215 (Ct. App. 1989) (recognizing in family court action involving child support that judgments are to be construed like other written instruments).Â  Therefore, the orders are to be read in the light of their literal meaning.Â  
Because the Final Order did nothing but continue the tax consequences outlined for the temporary alimony in the Pendente Lite Consent Order, the Pendente Lite Consent Order was still controlling and the temporary alimony should have had no tax consequences for Wife.Â  Construing the orders in this way, Husband violated the Pendente Lite Consent Order when he filed his taxes for the year 2000 which resulted in tax consequences for Wife.Â  Thus, Judge Morehead erroneously interpreted the Final Order in stating that the order did not address the temporary alimony tax issues.Â  In light of our decision, we hold Wife is entitled to reimbursement in the amount of $4,887.06, for her payment to the IRS pertaining to the temporary alimony payments.Â  
III.
Wife asserts Judge Morehead erred in failing to hold Husband in contempt for violating the terms of the Pendente Lite Consent Order, the Final Order, and the Decree of Divorce. Â We disagree.
â€œThe power to punish for contempt is inherent in all courts and is essential to preservation of order in judicial proceedings.â€ Â In re Brown, 333 S.C. 414, 420, 511 S.E.2d 351, 355 (1998).Â  Contempt results from a partyâ€™s willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Â Smith v. Smith, 359 S.C. 393, 396, 597 S.E.2d 188, 189 (Ct. App. 2004); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2006) (A party may be found in contempt of court for the willful violation of a lawful court order.). Â â€œA willful act is one which is â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€ Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 119, 557 S.E.2d 693, 705 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)). â€œ[B]efore a court may find a person in contempt, the record must clearly and specifically reflect the contemptuous conduct.â€ Widman, 348 S.C. at 119, 557 S.E.2d at 705.
â€œIn a proceeding for contempt for violation of a court order, the moving party must show the existence of a court order and the facts establishing the respondentâ€™s noncompliance with the order.â€Â  Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 501, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œOnce the moving party has made out a prima facie case, the burden then shifts to the respondent to establish his or her defense and inability to comply with the order.â€Â  Widman, 348 S.C. at 120, 557 S.E.2d at 705.Â  Furthermore, â€œ[i]t is generally recognized that where a contemnor is unable, without fault on his part, to obey an order of the court, he is not to be held in contempt.â€Â  Hicks v. Hicks, 280 S.C. 378, 381, 312 S.E.2d 598, 599 (Ct. App. 1984). 
A finding of contempt rests within the sound discretion of the court and results from willful disobedience of a court order.Â  Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 125, 129 (1989).Â  â€œA trial courtâ€™s determination regarding contempt is subject to reversal where it is based on findings that are without evidentiary support or where there has been an abuse of discretion.â€ Henderson v. Puckett, 316 S.C. 171, 173, 447 S.E.2d 871, 872 (Ct. App. 1994). â€œEven though a party is found to have violated a court order, the question of whether or not to impose sanctions remains a matter for the courtâ€™s discretion.â€ Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 503, 597 S.E.2d 897, 900 (Ct. App. 2004). â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€ Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).
Here, Husbandâ€™s actions were not done with the requisite willfulness which requires the act be â€œâ€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€ Widman, 348 S.C. at 119, 557 S.E.2d at 705 (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)).Â  Regardless of the fact that we have interpreted the orders to be construed in a manner against Husband, there is still no evidence of contempt on his part.Â  Therefore, we hold Judge Morehead did not abuse his discretion in declining to find Husband in contempt for violating the terms of the Pendente Lite Consent Order, the Final Order, and the Decree of Divorce.
IV.
Wife claims Judge Morehead erred in finding the IRS, not the family court, should make the determination of the deductibility of the court-ordered alimony as the family court lacked jurisdiction to delegate the issue of payments to the IRS.Â  We disagree.Â  
In his order, Judge Morehead stated: 

  I find the issue of tax consequences on the pendente lite alimony is an issue between Plaintiff and the IRS.Â  I further find Defendant is not required to pay the taxes on the pendente lite alimony and is not required to pay the CPA fees of Plaintiff or attorney fees and costs of Plaintiff.Â  

A clear reading of this order shows that this finding was based on Judge Moreheadâ€™s earlier finding in the same order that Husband was not liable to Wife for the payment of taxes.Â  This did not, as Wife claims, give the IRS the power to adjudicate this issue.Â  Rather, Judge Morehead was merely stating that Wifeâ€™s only avenue for recovery would now be through the IRS.Â  Accordingly, we find Judge Morehead did not improperly delegate its powers to the IRS.Â  
V.
Wife argues Judge Morehead erred in declining to award her attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and accountant fees based on Husbandâ€™s violation of the court orders and refusal to correct the error.Â  We agree in part.Â  
â€œAn award of attorneysâ€™ fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€ Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748 (1989).Â  In determining whether attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded, the court should consider the following factors:Â  the partyâ€™s ability to pay his/her own attorneyâ€™s fees; beneficial results obtained by the attorney; the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M, 307 S.C. 471, 477-78, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In determining the reasonable amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the family court should consider the nature, extent and difficulty of the services rendered, the time necessarily devoted to the case, counselâ€™s professional standing, the contingency of compensation, the beneficial results obtained, and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991). Â â€œThe same considerations that apply to awarding attorneyâ€™s fees apply to awarding litigation expenses.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).
Based on our finding that Judge Edwards addressed the temporary alimony tax at issue in the Final Order and Wife is entitled to a reimbursement of the $4,887.06 paid to the IRS, we hold Wife is also entitled to an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and accountant fees.Â  Because Husband tried to settle the case on October 13, 2004, by offering to pay $4,887.06 to Wife for the tax liability, we hold Wifeâ€™s recovery of these fees is limited only to those incurred up to the date of the hearing, October 14, 2004.Â  Â Â Additionally, this only includes attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and accountant fees accrued in the course of Wife pursuing the payment of the pendente lite taxes at issue in this case.Â  In the Final Order and Decree of Divorce Wife was awarded $25,000.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Nothing in this opinion should be construed as changing that ruling.Â  We emphasize that Wife is only to receive attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and accountant fees associated with the issues discussed in the instant case up to the date of the hearing.Â  Accordingly, we remand to the family court for a determination of the amount to be awarded.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the family court improperly held that the temporary alimony tax issue was not addressed in the Final Order and found Husband was not liable for the tax liability for that alimony.Â  We also hold Wife is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and accountant fees incurred up until the date of the hearing, October 14, 2004.Â  We remand to the family court to determine an amount of attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and accountant fees to be awarded consistent with the holding of this opinion.Â  All other issues are affirmed.Â  For the reasons stated herein, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Brighton Woods Homeownerâ€™s Association, Incorporated, Appellant,
        v.
        Four Seventeen, Incorporated and The Ryland Group, Incorporated, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-096
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        William Duncan Fore, of Greenville, for Appellant.Â  
        Shane W. Rogers and Kristin Burnett Barber, both of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Brighton Woods Homeownerâ€™s Association, Inc. appeals the grant of summary judgment to The Ryland Group.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]
FACTS
In 1997, Four Seventeen, Inc. began development of the residential subdivision Brighton Woods.Â  Four Seventeen drafted a set of covenants and restrictions to govern the use of property in the subdivision and to control the operation of the Brighton Woods Homeownerâ€™s Association, which was created by the documents.Â  Amended covenants[2] were filed with the register of deeds in October of 1997. Â The board of directors was responsible for setting the annual assessments.Â  Until 2000, Four Seventeen acted as the de facto board of directors for the association.Â  
Thereafter, The Ryland Group entered into an agreement to purchase a number of lots in the subdivision and began constructing houses thereon.Â  By agreement, Four Seventeen did not levy assessments against Ryland.Â  In 2000, property owners in the subdivision took control of the association.Â  The association levied assessments against Ryland, and Ryland refused to pay claiming that it was not required to pay such fees under its agreement with Four Seventeen.Â  The association sued Ryland and Four Seventeen for back due assessments.Â  The trial court granted Rylandâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the ground that the covenants required a meeting of all property owners to set the annual assessments and since such a meeting was not conducted, the assessments were improperly made.Â  Consequently, Ryland could not be held liable for them.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate when there are no genuine issues of material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005).Â  
ANALYSIS
A reading of the covenants leads us to disagree with the trial courtâ€™s interpretation of its provisions.Â  Article III, Section 3 provides:

  
    a.
    [T]he maximum annual assessment may be increased each year not more than ten (10%) percent above the maximum assessment for the previous year without a vote of the membership.
  
  
    b.
    [T]he maximum annual assessment may be increased above ten (10%) percent by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of each class of members who are voting in person or by proxy, at a meeting duly called for this purpose.
  
  
    c. 
    The Board of Directors may fix the annual assessment at an amount not in excess of the maximum.  
  

Section 4 of Article III allows the board to levy a special assessment â€œprovided that any such assessment shall have the consent of two-thirds (2/3) of the votes of each class of members who are voting in person or by proxy at a meeting duly called for this purpose.â€Â  These provisions clearly indicate a vote of the membership is required for increases of more than 10% or for â€œspecial assessments.â€Â  
Article III, Section 5 is entitled â€œNotice and Quorum for Any Action Authorized Under Sections 3 and 4.â€Â  It states:Â  â€œWritten notice of any meeting called for the purpose of taking any action authorized under Section 3 or 4 shall be sent to all members not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days in advance of the meeting.â€ Â Section 7 provides that the board of directors â€œshall fix the amount of the annual assessment against each Lot at least thirty (30) days in advance of each annual assessment period,â€ and â€œ[w]ritten notice of that annual assessment shall be sent to every Owner subject thereto.â€Â  The trial court concluded that when Article III, Section 3 is read in conjunction with Article III, Sections 5 and 7, the covenants require a meeting of the membership to approve any assessment.Â  We disagree.Â  
Even though Section 5 references â€œany action authorized under sections 3 and 4,â€ the only actions authorized under Sections 3 and 4 that require meetings of the membership are special assessments and increases greater than 10%.Â  Section 5 provides the framework by which a meeting must be noticed and conducted, and Section 7 prescribes how and when members are to be notified of the annual assessment.Â  There appears to be a distinction between acts that require a meeting of the board and acts that require a meeting of the associationâ€™s membership. Â Although Article III could have been written more clearly, a plain reading of all the provisions does not lead to the conclusion that the determination of all annual assessments requires a meeting of the membership.
 After examining the record, there appears to be a genuine issue of material fact regarding whether the association complied with the mandates set forth in Article III, Section 7 of the covenants.Â  From the record before us, we cannot ascertain with certainty the amount of the annual assessment, whether the board set that amount by meeting or otherwise, or if Ryland received the required notice in the prescribed time period.Â  
Because we disagree with the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that the provisions of the covenants require a meeting of the members of the association to set the assessments, we reverse that portion of the order.Â  However, having concluded that a genuine issue of material fact exists regarding the associationâ€™s compliance with Article III, Section 7 of the covenants, we remand for further proceedings.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] â€œFirst Amendment to Declaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions for a Residential Subdivision Known as Brighton Woods.â€Â
