THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Charleston County Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Mother, Pamela N., Chris R., Telly L., and Jacob J.,[1] Defendants,
        Of whom Mother isAppellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â F.P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-097
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
        George E. Counts and Kelvin M. Huger, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Frampton Durban, of North Charleston, for Respondent.
        Nancy Chiles, of Charleston, Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Mother appeals the family courtâ€™s permanency planning order, which instructed the Charleston County Department of Social Services (DSS) to institute the termination of parental rights (TPR) with respect to one of her minor children and to award custody of two of her other minor children to their respective fathers.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Mother has four biological children: (1) Tevin M., born August 5, 1992; (2) J.T., born February 16, 1995; (3) D.M., born September 10, 1998; and (4) Trevon M., born January 9, 2002.Â  Until 2003, when Mother gave custody of J.T. to his father, she was the sole custodial parent and caregiver to all four children.Â  
On November 5, 2003, Mother spanked then five-year-old D.M., leaving marks and bruises on her back and legs.Â  As a result, DSS removed the children from Motherâ€™s custody.Â  D.M. has consistently maintained that Mother spanked her with the cord of an electric iron.Â  Mother has maintained she spanked D.M. with a belt but has admitted she struck her too hard.Â  Dr. Sarah Schuh, an expert in child abuse, testified that D.M.â€™s injuries were consistent with being struck by an electric power cord rather than by a belt.
In November 2003, DSS placed the children with Motherâ€™s sister, Pamela N., with instructions that the children not be allowed any contact with Mother.Â  In April 2004, DSS removed the children from Pamela N.â€™s care and took them into custody because according to DSS, Pamela N. allowed Mother to see the children on a regular basis and talk on the telephone with them once a week.Â  
On June 17, 2004, the family court held a merits hearing. Â At the hearing, Mother consented to a finding that she abused the children. Â The family court ordered D.M. and Trevon M. to remain in the custody of Charleston County DSS.Â  The family court further ordered that Charleston County DSS would have temporary legal custody of Tevin M., but Chris R., Tevin M.â€™s father, would have temporary physical custody.Â  Additionally, the family court ordered Mother to participate in family therapy with D.M. and Tevin M. and to follow the therapistâ€™s recommendations.Â  
As required by the June 2004 order, the family court held a judicial review hearing on July 29, 2004.Â  The family court ordered Jacob J., Trevon M.â€™s father, to undergo a substance abuse evaluation.Â  It further ordered Mother to continue attending counseling and to complete abuse clarification with the children.Â  
In June 2004, Tevin M. relocated to Kentucky with his father.Â  The guardian ad litem (GAL) received reports from Kentucky on Tevin M.â€™s placement and spoke to Chris R. about how Tevin M. was doing in his care.Â  In addition, the GAL learned that Trevon M. and his father did not have a close relationship and that Jacob J. had a substance abuse problem. Â Further, Jacob J. failed to follow the court ordered treatment plan.Â  
D.M. did not learn the true identity of her biological father until December 2004 when DSS identified Telly L. as D.M.â€™s father. Â Telly L. was absent since D.M.â€™s infancy; however, Telly L. and D.M. underwent counseling to help reestablish their parent-child relationship. Â The GAL conducted home visits with Telly L. and observed him with D.M. in therapy sessions.Â  The GAL found Telly L. to be committed to D.M.Â  Both the GAL and the DSS caseworker recommended that he receive custody.
The family court held another judicial review hearing regarding the childrenâ€™s placement on December 16, 2004. Â The family court determined that legal and physical custody of D.M. and Trevon M. should remain with DSS and temporary legal and physical custody of Tevin M. should remain with Chris R.Â  The family court ordered: (1) Jacob J. to successfully complete a drug and alcohol treatment program; (2) Mother to successfully complete parent effectiveness training and family counseling with D.M. and Trevon M. and to cooperate with Tevin M.â€™s therapist; and (3) Telly L. to successfully complete family counseling with D.M.Â  The family court ordered a permanency planning hearing to be scheduled for February 17, 2005.Â  
By agreement between the parties, Mother paid child support to Jevelous T. for J.T.Â  Mother fell behind in her support payments.Â  She was found in contempt of court and was placed in jail for one day.Â  Upon her release on December 14, 2005, Mother called Jevelous T. and left him a message saying in part, â€œI am going to get you.Â  You better believe that.â€Â  Mother testified that she was angry with him, but she did not actually intend to harm him.Â  
On January 10, 2006, Mother mistakenly believed she had a therapy session with her therapist, Joyce Ewell.Â  Because Ewell was with another client, Ewell could not see Mother. Â The receptionist had to call Ewell to the front desk because Mother became increasingly upset. Â Mother testified she was upset because she saw D.M. only at therapy sessions; however, Mother eventually left Ewellâ€™s office. 
The family court held the permanency planning hearing on January 19-20 and March 10, 2006.Â  The court awarded Telly L. legal and physical custody of D.M. and awarded Chris R. legal and physical custody of Tevin M.Â  The family court instructed DSS to initiate a TPR action for Trevon M. who was to remain in the custody of DSS.Â  Further, the family court ordered Mother and D.M. to continue and successfully complete family counseling and for Mother to have visitation with D.M., if approved by D.M.â€™s therapist, DSS, and the GAL.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  However, the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, and consequently, we give its findings broad discretion.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  This degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of a minor child.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006). Â When the evidence is conflicting and susceptible of different inferences, the family court has the duty of determining not only the law of the case, but the facts as well, because it had the benefit of observing the witnesses and determining how much credence to give each oneâ€™s testimony.Â  Anders v. Anders, 285 S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985); see also Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996) (holding when evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the family courtâ€™s findings).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Change of Custody and Initiation of TPR
Mother argues the family court erred when it ordered a change in custody for D.M. and Tevin M. and permitted DSS to commence TPR with respect to Trevon M. because Mother was making solid progress towards reunification with her children.Â  We disagree.
When a child is placed in foster care, the family court is required to conduct a permanency planning hearing within a year of the childâ€™s placement in foster care. Â S.C. Code Ann Â§ 20-7-766(A) (Supp. 2005). Â At this hearing, the family court must approve a placement plan for the child, which typically entails three options: reunification with the parents, custody or guardianship with a fit and willing relative, or termination of parental rights.Â  See Â§ 20-7-766(C).Â  If the family court approves a different plan, it must find compelling reasons to do so, and the plan must be in the childâ€™s best interests.Â  Id.Â  
Generally, if the court determines the child should not be returned to the childâ€™s parents, DSS must file a petition to terminate parental rights within sixty days of the family courtâ€™s order.Â  Â§ 20-7-766(E).Â  However, if the child is not returned to the parents, but termination of parental rights is not in the childâ€™s best interests, the family court â€œmay award custody or legal guardianship, or both, to a suitable, fit, and willing relative or nonrelative.â€ Â Â§Â§ 20-7-766(E), 20-7-766(G).Â  Consequently, DSS is not required to file a petition to terminate parental rights at that time.Â  Id.
Additionally, if the family court cannot safely return the child to the childâ€™s parents, but there is a possibility the child may be safely returned within a reasonable time, not to exceed eighteen months, the family court can order an extension of the placement plan or may modify the plan.Â  See Â§ 20-7-766(F). Â However, â€œ[b]efore continuing foster care for this purpose, the court must find that, at the time of the hearing, initiation of termination of parental rights is not in the best interests of the child and that the best interests of the child will be served by the extended or modified plan.â€Â  Id.Â  
As set forth in section 20-7-766(C), the family court had only one viable option for D.M. and Tevin M. as well as only one available option for Trevon M.Â  Reuniting the children with Mother was not an alternative because Mother still had not resolved her anger problems that led to the removal of her children.Â  The next possible placement for the children was with their respective fathers if they were fit.Â  For D.M. and Tevin M., their fathers were available and found to be fit and suitable parents.Â  Trevon M.â€™s father was determined not to be an appropriate placement because of substance abuse problems.Â  
The family court considered other relatives for placement of Trevon M.Â  Motherâ€™s sister, Pamela N., was unsuitable because the children had already been removed from her care.Â  Another of Motherâ€™s sisters, Carolyn M., and her husband, Curtis, failed to comply with earlier family court orders relating to the supervision, safety, and well-being of J.T.Â  The couple was to supervise Mother with J.T. during his court ordered visitation, but they allowed Mother to be alone with him.Â  Therefore, based on the circumstances, the family courtâ€™s only remaining option for Trevon M. was to begin TPR.Â  
The State argues that according to section 20-7-766(F), a child cannot be returned to the childâ€™s parents if the child has been in foster care for over eighteen months. Â Because the permanency planning hearing occurred after Trevon M. was in foster care for twenty-two months, DSS was required by law to institute a termination of parental rights action. Â Here, the letter of the law was satisfied once Trevon M. remained in foster care greater than eighteen months.[2]Â  
Although, â€œ[t]he public policy of this [S]tate in child custody matters is to reunite parents and children,â€ we have long decided all matters involving the custody or care of children in â€œlight of the fundamental principle that the controlling consideration is the best interests of the child.â€Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 295-96, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999) (internal quotations omitted). Â In recent years, the Legislature has placed an increasing emphasis on the best interests of the child in abuse and neglect cases.Â  Id. at 295, 513 S.E.2d at 366.Â  
Even if we disregarded section 20-7-766(F), the childrenâ€™s best interests would not be served by returning them to Mother because she still has not resolved her anger management problems.Â  Although Mother is following the treatment plan, she has not completed it.Â  D.M.â€™s and Tevin M.â€™s best interests are served by giving their respective fathers custody.Â  The family court found that both fathers were fit parents and were capable of providing suitable homes.Â  Returning Trevon M. to his father would not be in his best interests because of his fatherâ€™s substance abuse problem, and no other relatives were found to be suitable.Â  Therefore, TPR is the appropriate plan and in Trevon M.â€™s best interests.
II. The GALâ€™s Recommendation 
Next, Mother contends the GALâ€™s recommendation was flawed.Â  She maintains the recommendation was biased and based on an incomplete investigation of the case.Â  We disagree. 
Section 20-7-122 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides the responsibilities and duties for a GAL appointed in abuse and neglect cases: 

  
    (1) represent the best interests of the child;
  (2) advocate for the welfare and rights of a child involved in an abuse or neglect proceeding;
  (3) conduct an independent assessment of the facts, the needs of the child, and the available resources within the family and community to meet those needs;
  (4) maintain accurate, written case records;
  (5) provide the family court with a written report, consistent with the rules of evidence and the rules of the court, which includes without limitation evaluation and assessment of the issues brought before the court and recommendations for the case plan, the wishes of the child, if appropriate, and subsequent disposition of the case;
  (6) monitor compliance with the orders of the family court and to make the motions necessary to enforce the orders of the court or seek judicial review;
  (7) protect and promote the best interests of the child until formally relieved of the responsibility by the family court.

In an abuse situation, the GAL is to serve as the childâ€™s advocate and to do what is in the best interests of the child.Â  In both situations, the GALâ€™s primary concern is the best interests of the children.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-122(1), 20-7-1549(A)(1) (Supp. 2005).Â  
In the present case, the GAL followed her statutory responsibilities and duties.Â  She did not have any statutory duty to perform a home visit with Mother simply because she performed visits with one of the fathers.Â  Because the children had never lived with their fathers, it was important to observe the fathersâ€™ living situations to assess if they were suitable guardians.Â  The GALâ€™s opinion that Mother was not a suitable parent arose out of Motherâ€™s unresolved anger problems, not the physical condition of the home.Â  Because she had not resolved those problems, a home visit would not have assuaged the GALâ€™s concerns.Â  The GAL properly observed Mother with the children during therapy sessions.Â  Therefore, the GALâ€™s report was not biased or incomplete.
Further, the family court did not rely solely on the GALâ€™s report. Â It considered the testimony, the case record, the supplemental report submitted by DSS, and the recommendations of the GAL in determining the permanency plan for Trevon M.Â  Therefore, even if the report was biased, we discern no prejudice because the record contains other ample evidence to support the findings of the family court.
III. Family Courtâ€™s Reliance on Incidents Before Hearing
Finally, Mother maintains the family court erred by placing too much emphasis on two incidents occurring shortly before the hearing, namely the answering machine message and the incident at the therapistâ€™s office.Â  Mother contends the GALâ€™s recommendation changed after the two incidents, proving the family court relied too heavily on the incidents.Â  We disagree.
The family court considered the testimony, case record, the supplemental report submitted by DSS, and the recommendations of the GAL in determining the permanency plan for Trevon M.Â  Even if we excluded these two incidents, based on our own review of the evidence, we find Mother has not resolved her anger management issues, which contributed to causing serious injury to one of the children and led to the childrenâ€™s removal. Â Thus, returning the children to Mother at this time would be inappropriate.
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.[3]
HUFF, BEATTY, AND WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The names of the minor children and the respective defendants have been changed to protect the minorsâ€™ identities.
[2] Â We note that although the letter of the law was satisfied in the present case, some instances exist when this statutory ground would not support termination of parental rights despite the childâ€™s presence in foster care for eighteen months. Cf. Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 102 n. 8, 627 S.E.2d 765, 773 n.8 (Ct. App. 2006) (holding that although TPR was statutorily permissible because child had remained in foster care greater than fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months, it was not in childâ€™s best interests to terminate the fatherâ€™s rights).Â  Here, the hearings were rescheduled and delayed several times, which prolonged Trevon M.â€™s stay in foster care.Â  Furthermore, not all of these delays were attributable to the acts of Mother.Â  We agree with Justice Pleicones when he stated: â€œI am not willing to sever the parent-child relationship solely on the basis that [the statutory grounds for TPR have been met] where the [parent] presented substantial evidence that much of the delay in the processing of this case is attributable to the acts of others.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 356 S.C. 413, 420, 589 S.E.2d 753, 756 (2003) (Pleicones, J., concurring).Â  Despite these delays, we believe the family court was correct in allowing DSS to proceed given the specific facts and circumstances surrounding this case.Â  
[3]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        James H. Dickey, Individually, and as Personal Representative for the Estate of Ruth S. Dickey, Deceased, Plaintiff,
        Of Whom James H. Dickey, Individually is Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Clarke Nursing Home, Cooke Associates of Florence, Inc., Carolinas Hospital System, and Does A-Z, Defendants,
        Of Whom Carolinas Hospital System is the Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

  Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-098
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James H. Dickey, of Charlotte, Pro Se.
        Marian W. Scalise, Charles E. Carpenter, Jr. and Carmen V. Ganjehsani, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  James Dickey appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on his wrongful death, negligence, and breach of contract causes of action.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
From April 2001 to June 2002, Dickeyâ€™s diabetic mother resided at Clarke Nursing Home (the Nursing Home).Â  In April and May 2002, his mother was repeatedly admitted to Carolinas Hospital System (the Hospital).Â  From May 31, 2002 until she was discharged on June 24, 2002, the Hospital treated Dickeyâ€™s mother for foot sores.Â  Prior to her discharge, the Hospital called Dickey and requested his permission to amputate her feet, which he granted.Â  Dickeyâ€™s mother died in June 2003.[1]Â  
On June 30, 2005, Dickey, both in his individual capacity and as personal representative (PR) of his motherâ€™s estate, filed a complaint against the Nursing Home, Cooke Associates of Florence, Inc.,[2] the Hospital, and DOES A-Z.[3]Â  Dickey alleged: (1) professional and medical negligence; (2) gross professional and medical negligence; (3) wrongful death; and (4) breach of contract.[4] Â 
In his complaint, Dickey maintained the Nursing Home, despite knowing his mother was diabetic, transported her in a wheelchair without foot guards or footwear protection.Â  Dickey alleged that because of this practice, she developed ulcers on her feet and heels.Â  These ulcers became infected and resulted in her untimely death. Â 
Dickey also asserted the Hospital failed to conduct a timely and adequate medical assessment, evaluation, and treatment of his mother.Â  He further alleged the Hospital failed to provide an accurate report of her medical condition.Â  Dickey contended the Hospitalâ€™s inaction resulted in delayed diagnosis and improper medical evaluation and treatment, all of which contributed to the rapid decline of his motherâ€™s health and ultimately her death.Â  Further, Dickey asserted the Hospital intentionally covered up facts, which if revealed, would prove the Nursing Home negligently treated his mother.Â  
On July 13, 2005, the Hospital answered and filed a motion for summary judgment, claiming the statute of limitations barred the claims.Â  The Hospital asserted Dickeyâ€™s mother last received medical care at its facility on June 24, 2002, but Dickey commenced the suit over three years later on June 30, 2005.Â  
On September 20, 2005, the trial court held a hearing on the Hospitalâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial court found the date that the Hospital informed Dickey his mother needed an amputation was the date that a reasonable person would be on notice that a potential claim existed.Â  Dickey could not recall the exact date that the Hospital informed him his mother needed an amputation.Â  Therefore, the trial court set the date beginning the statute of limitations no later than June 24, 2002, the date of her last discharge.Â  Accordingly, the statute of limitations expired no later than June 24, 2005, six days before Dickey filed the complaint.Â  
On September 27, 2005, after the summary judgment hearing, the South Carolina Bar placed Dickey on interim suspension for an unrelated matter.[5] Â On November 7, 2005, Dickey filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration regarding the summary judgment motion.Â  In ruling on the motion for reconsideration, the trial court found Dickey was authorized to file the complaint in his individual capacity, but he was not authorized to file it on behalf of the estate due to his suspension.Â  See Brown v. Coe, 365 S.C. 137, 142, 616 S.E.2d 705, 708 (2005) (holding because an estate is a separate legal entity from the individual named as PR, a PR who is not a lawyer cannot represent an estate in court).Â  Because his license was suspended, his attempt to file the motion on behalf of his motherâ€™s estate was tantamount to the unauthorized practice of law. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-5-310 (Supp. 2005).Â  Therefore, the trial court considered the order only as to Dickey in his individual capacity and denied the motion.Â  In his individual capacity, Dickey appealed the trial courtâ€™s decision. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases not requiring the services of a fact finder.  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).  When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this Court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Under this rule, summary judgment is proper when no genuine issue as to any material fact exists, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).  
In determining whether a triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.  Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).  If evidentiary facts are not disputed, but the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them are disputed, summary judgment should be denied. Â Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C. 412, 415, 401 S.E.2d 169, 171 (1991).  Summary judgment is not appropriate when further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of law.  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Dickey assigns several points of error to the trial courtâ€™s grant of the Hospitalâ€™s motion for summary judgment based on the statute of limitations.Â  In response, the Hospital contends that Dickey, in his individual capacity, cannot pursue these causes of action.Â  We agree with the Hospital.Â  
At the trial level, Dickey asserted claims for wrongful death, negligence, gross negligence, and breach of contract.Â  We address each claim in turn. 
I. Wrongful Death
The wrongful death statute provides a remedy for the spouse, child, parent, or heir of an injured party when a person commits a wrongful or negligent act causing the injured partyâ€™s death.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-51-10, 15-51-20 (Supp. 2005).Â  Any recovery directly benefits the individual rather than the decedentâ€™s general estate.Â  Lester v. McFaddon, 415 F.2d 1101, 1103 (4th Cir. 1969).Â  However, any recovery under this cause of action constitutes the individualâ€™s complete remedy.Â  See Banks v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 314 S.C. 376, 380, 444 S.E.2d 519, 521 (1994) (holding that if a mother brings a claim in her individual capacity for her decedent child, the wrongful death statute is her exclusive remedy); Green v. S. Ry. Co., 319 F. Supp. 919, 919-20 (D.S.C. 1970) (holding recovery under the wrongful death statute is the exclusive remedy for an individual). Â Therefore, Dickeyâ€™s only vehicle to recover for his motherâ€™s death is under the wrongful death statute.Â  
Although the wrongful death statute is the only avenue of recovery for Dickey as an individual, such an action inheres only in the PR, and the statutory beneficiaries cannot proceed in their individual capacity. Â Lester, 415 F.2d at 1103.Â  Under the statute, â€œthe right of action for wrongful death is purely statutory and . . . may be brought only by the executor or administrator of such deceased person.â€Â  Glenn v. E. I. DuPont De Nemours & Co., 254 S.C. 128, 133, 174 S.E.2d 155, 157 (1970) (citing Lilly v. Charlotte, C. & A. R. Co., 32 S.C. 142, 10 S.E. 932 (1890)); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-51-20 (Supp. 2005) (â€œEvery [wrongful death] action shall be brought by or in the name of the executor or administrator of such person.â€).Â  
While a non-lawyer PR may administer the affairs of an estate and maintain an action on the estateâ€™s behalf, a PR must be a lawyer if the PR intends to represent the estate in court.Â  Brown, 365 S.C. at 141, 616 S.E.2d at 708.Â  Because the estate is a separate legal entity, only a lawyer can represent the interests of the estate and its beneficiaries in court.Â  Id. at 142, 616 S.E.2d at 708 (holding â€œthe filing of a notice of appeal on behalf of the estate and preparation of briefs . . . clearly constitutes the practice of lawâ€).Â  
Consequently, Dickeyâ€™s appeal on the wrongful death claim in his individual capacity cannot succeed. Â If an action for wrongful death is instituted by one other than the PR of a decedent, the trial court should dismiss the action.Â  Glenn, 254 S.C. at 134, 174 S.E.2d at 158.Â  Although Dickey could have potentially recovered as an individual under the wrongful death statute if he, as PR, brought the action and a licensed lawyer represented the estate in court, he failed to do so. Â Therefore, the trial court properly dismissed this claim. 
II.Â  Negligence and Gross Negligence
Dickeyâ€™s claims for negligence and gross negligence arise out of the same alleged malfeasance as that alleged for wrongful death.Â  As explained above, wrongful death is the only remedy for an individual.Â  While as PR he may have had a potential claim for negligence under the survival statute, Dickey has appealed only in his individual capacity.Â  See Banks, 314 S.C. at 381 n.5, 444 S.E.2d at 522 n.5 (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-90 (2005)) (â€œAlthough . . . wrongful death is [decedentâ€™s motherâ€™s] exclusive remedy [in her individual capacity], the battery cause of action may be maintained by [the mother] in her representative capacity for [decedent] under the survival statute.â€). Â Consequently, the trial court did not err when it dismissed these claims.
III. Breach of Contract
Dickeyâ€™s appeal is unclear as to whether the breach of contract cause of action pertains to the Hospital.Â  Upon review of the complaint, the alleged breach of contract seems aimed only at the Nursing Home, and the appeal before this Court concerns only the Hospital.Â  
Even if the breach of contract claim pertains to the Hospital, Dickey has appealed only in his individual capacity.Â  Dickey does not specifically assert that he had a contract with the Hospital nor does he provide such a contract.Â  Generally, a third person not in privity of contract with the contracting parties does not have a right to enforce the contract.Â  Wogan v. Kunze, 366 S.C. 583, 604, 623 S.E.2d 107, 118 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  While his mother may have had a contract with the Hospital, Dickey in his individual capacity cannot enforce such a contract, and thus, he has no cause of action for breach of contract.Â  
On appeal, the Hospital primarily argues that this Court should affirm the trial court based on the expiration of the statute of limitations.Â  The Hospital further supports its position by arguing that Dickey, in his personal capacity, is not entitled to maintain the current action.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 419, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (â€œ[A] respondent . . . may raise . . . any additional reasons the appellate court should affirm the lower courtâ€™s ruling, regardless of whether those reasons have been presented to or ruled on by the lower court.â€).Â  Because this Court has the discretion to affirm on any ground in the record, we decline to address Dickeyâ€™s arguments regarding the statute of limitations. See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive); see also Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).
CONCLUSION
The wrongful death statute provides an individualâ€™s only avenue of recovery for wrongful or negligent acts which cause anotherâ€™s death.Â  Further, a duly appointed PR must institute a wrongful death action on behalf of the estate, and a licensed lawyer must represent the estate in court.Â  Since Dickey appealed the trial courtâ€™s decision only in his individual capacity, he cannot maintain this appeal.Â  Â Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[6]Â  
HUFF, BEATTY, AND WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Neither the Record on Appeal nor the briefs contain the exact date or cause of death.
[2] Dickey asserts that Cooke Associates of Florence, Inc. is another name for the Nursing Home.Â  
[3] In his complaint, Dickey explained that he did not know the identity of some defendants in this matter, and thus, he gave the unknown defendants the name DOES A-Z.Â  Dickey stated he would make a motion to amend his complaint â€œwhen the true capacity, identity, or names of these [d]efendants has been ascertained.â€Â  
[4] Dickey was a licensed South Carolina attorney at the time of the filing and represented himself and the estate.Â  
[5] In re Dickey, 366 S.C. 18, 620 S.E.2d 332 (2005).Â  
[6] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Wanda J. Haithcock, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-099
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka; Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Wanda Haithcock, was convicted of the murder of Kenneth Wayne Coates, Sr.Â  The trial court sentenced Haithcock to thirty years imprisonment. Â Haithcock appeals, asserting the trial court erred in denying her motion for a directed verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the afternoon of January 24, 2001, two women discovered the body of Kenneth Wayne Coates, Sr. in an abandoned house on Dongola Highway in Horry County.Â  Two spent bullet casings from a .25 semi automatic round were found at the scene:Â  one at the foot of Mr. Coates and the other just above the head.Â  An autopsy revealed Mr. Coates had been shot in the back of the neck and in the left forehead.Â  The shot to the forehead was qualified as the cause of death.Â  An expert in crime scene investigation testified it was his opinion Mr. Coates was shot in the back of the neck while in an upright position, collapsed to the ground, and received the second shot while he was lying on the floor in the abandoned home.Â  The forensic pathologist who performed an autopsy on Mr. Coates on January 25, 2001 testified she estimated at the time of the autopsy that Mr. Coates had been dead greater than four days.Â  However, given the cooler temperatures that occurred that January, she stated Mr. Coates could have been dead for three weeks, and could have possibly died on January 6, 2001.Â  It is undisputed that Mr. Coates was murdered.Â  
Mike Owens testified Mr. Coates had worked for his company since 1966.Â  The last day he worked was Friday, January 5, 2001.Â  Mr. Coates left work that evening around 5:00.Â  Owens testified Mr. Coatesâ€™ usual habit was to work on Saturday mornings.Â  However, he did not show up for work that next morning.Â  They did not look for him, though, and only became concerned when Mr. Coates failed to show up for work on Monday.Â  Although Owens stated there was a time several years back where Mr. Coates, without explanation, failed to show for work for approximately three or four days, he testified this was not typical behavior of Mr. Coates, who usually called in if he was going to be off somewhere.Â  Mr. Coates never came back to work after that Friday, and Owens had not seen him since then. 
Phil Whittaker also testified regarding the last contact he had with Mr. Coates.Â  Whittaker stated he was a close friend to Mr. Coates and usually saw him four, five or six times a week, often playing golf on the weekends and shooting pool.Â  On the evening of Friday, January 5, Whittaker and Mr. Coates met for a cocktail.Â  They went to another establishment to play pool and sing Karaoke, went back to the first meeting place, then on to a restaurant.Â  They left the restaurant around 2:30 a.m. that Saturday.Â  Mr. Coates headed toward his home in his white Ford Explorer.Â  Whittaker called Mr. Coates in the morning, attempting to contact him through his cell phone, his home phone and his pager without success.Â  Whittaker testified Mr. Coates usually went to work on Saturday mornings, and if he was busy at work, he may not return his call right away, but would call about an hour later.Â  On this occasion, Mr. Coates never called him back.Â  Whittaker never saw Mr. Coates after that night. 
The State presented evidence from several witnesses who saw a female and a white Ford Explorer on January 6, 2001 near the abandoned home where Mr. Coatesâ€™ body was found.Â  Wade Lawrimore testified that on that day, he had been working at his shop and needed to pick up a gas can from his home.Â  After picking up the can, he drove by the abandoned home that belonged to his mother and observed a white Ford Explorer parked by a pile of dirt that he had placed in the area to keep people from driving behind the house.Â  He stopped to check on the situation and talked with a woman sitting in the driverâ€™s seat of the Explorer.Â  Also present was a person in the passengerâ€™s seat, looking straight ahead.Â  Wade asked what they were doing there, and the woman told him they had run out of gas.Â  Wade offered to go get some gas for them, but the woman declined, stating that her boyfriend had already caught a ride and was headed toward Waccamaw Grocery to retrieve some gas.Â  Wade stated he could see the woman because she leaned out of the window, but he never got a clear sight of the person sitting in the passenger seat.Â  He saw a silhouette of the passenger, who he assumed was a man.Â  The passenger never spoke.Â  From the silhouette he could tell the head of this person rested on a headrest, and constantly looked forward.Â  Wade got an uneasy feeling from the situation with the unmoving passenger, and thought the two people may have been in an argument.Â  Because it was the middle of the day, Wade then drove off to the store to get some lunch.Â  As he drove down the road, he did not see anyone walking with a gas can. Â Thereafter, Wade was shown a photographic array and picked Wanda Haithcockâ€™s picture out as the woman he had observed at the abandoned home at the time in question.Â  
Wadeâ€™s nephew, Steven Lawrimore, and Stevenâ€™s wife, Ginger Lawrimore, also testified to seeing a woman and a white Ford Explorer in the area of the abandoned home on January 6, 2001.Â  Steven testified that it was after dark on that date when he and his wife were driving on Dongola Highway and noticed a white Explorer at his grandmotherâ€™s old house.Â  When they stopped to see why it was there, they saw a woman standing on the porch of the home of his deceased uncle, approximately 150 to 200 yards away.Â  Steven asked the woman if she needed help, and she stated she was trying to use a phone.Â  The woman said she had run out of gas, and someone had picked up her boyfriend to go retrieve some.Â  Steven told the woman that no one lived at the residence and that he could take her to a telephone.Â  The woman, who seemed to be nervous, then got in the vehicle with Steven and Ginger.Â  They drove approximately 100 yards to the home of Stevensâ€™ parents.Â  Steven took the woman inside and handed her a cordless phone. Â Steven heard beeps, as if the woman dialed a number, then muffled conversation.Â  After she made the phone call, Steven and Ginger drove her back to the Explorer that was parked at Stevenâ€™s grandmotherâ€™s house. Â Steven asked the woman if she wanted them to wait with her since there had been problems with people vandalizing the house in the past.Â  The woman declined, stating her boyfriend would be back shortly.Â  The woman then got in the driverâ€™s seat of the Explorer.Â  Steven was shown a photographic array approximately two to three weeks later, but was unable to definitely pick out the woman he gave a ride to that night.Â  
Ginger Lawrimore testified that on January 6, 2001, she and her husband noticed a white Ford Explorer sitting in her husbandâ€™s grandmotherâ€™s driveway.Â  They pulled into the driveway and saw a lady standing on the porch of Stevenâ€™s deceased uncleâ€™s house.Â  They backed out of the grandmotherâ€™s driveway and drove over to the uncleâ€™s house.Â  As the woman approached the car, Gingerâ€™s husband rolled down his window and asked her if there was a problem.Â  The woman stated that she and her boyfriend had run out of gas, but that he had caught a ride with someone.Â  Steven and Ginger then gave the woman a ride to his parentsâ€™ home.Â  Ginger described the woman as being very nervous, â€œtwiddling her handsâ€ and making no conversation.Â  Thereafter, while watching the news one day, Steven and Ginger learned that a dead body had been discovered in Stevenâ€™s grandmotherâ€™s house.Â  They also heard that the dead man owned a white Explorer, which was missing.Â  The couple then contacted the police. Â On January 24, the day Mr. Coatesâ€™ body was found, a detective with the Horry County Police Department spoke with Steven and Ginger about the matter.Â  Ginger picked out Haithcockâ€™s picture as the individual she had seen near the abandoned house on January 6.Â  Ginger also made an in-court identification of Haithcock as the person she saw on Dongola Highway that day.Â  
Haithcockâ€™s sister, Cynthia Bowling also testified on behalf of the State.Â  In January 2001, Cynthia, who lived in Charleston, was contacted by Haithcock.Â  Haithcock was living in Myrtle Beach at the time, and she told Cynthia she was coming to Charleston at 10:00 a.m. on January 25 and she wanted Cynthia to meet her at a Burger King there. Â Â When Cynthia met her as requested, Haithcock was driving a white Ford Explorer.Â  Haithcock told Cynthia she needed a place to park the car.Â  Cynthia told Haithcock it was not a problem, that she had a friend with a big yard, and she could park the car there as long as she needed. Â After Haithcock followed Cynthia to her friendsâ€™ house, the Colaskoâ€™s, she parked the Explorer and Cynthia gave Haithcock a ride to their motherâ€™s home.Â  Thereafter, Cynthia contacted the Horry County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  She told officers she did not know what was going on, but that her sister had brought her an Explorer and asked her to park it, and whatever was going on with the situation, she did not want anything to do with it.Â  Cynthia further testified that, prior to 1997 or 1998, Haithcock and Mr. Coates had a close relationship, having lived together and bought properties together, including land, a condo, and a boat.Â  After that time, they still engaged in sexual relations and would have dinner together, but they lived separately.Â  
After receiving information from Horry County authorities regarding an Explorer being located on Johnâ€™s Island, officers from Charleston County went to the Colasko residence and found the automobile parked in a wooded area next to a house.Â  The tag on the vehicle was run through the system and it came back as being registered to the victim, Mr. Coates.Â  
At trial, the State presented gun and bullet evidence providing possible links between Haithcock and the weapon and ammunition used to kill Mr. Coates.Â  Records from a Myrtle Beach pawn shop showed Haithcock had purchased a Taurus PT-25 caliber handgun on August 8, 1997.Â  During their investigation, officers also discovered in a bag belonging to Haithcock a receipt for a magazine clip for a Taurus PT-25 caliber pistol which showed the clip was purchased by Wanda Haithcock on November 7, 2000.Â  A search of Haithcockâ€™s residence turned up a .25 caliber live round of ammunition found on a bookshelf in the living room area.Â  The State presented the testimony of SLED Agent Ira Parnell, who was qualified as an expert in firearm identification, including ammunition and ammunition component.Â  Agent Parnell examined the two .25 caliber cartridge cases found at the crime scene, the unfired cartridge found in Haithcockâ€™s home, and the two bullets retrieved from Coatesâ€™ body.Â  The agent testified they were â€œlooking at a semi automatic .25 auto caliber pistolâ€ that was used in this case.Â  In comparing the two fired bullets retrieved from Mr. Coatesâ€™ body, he determined they were fired from the same gun.Â  He also stated, while there were hundreds of different .25 caliber firearms, there were only seven brands of guns that could have fired those bullets, and one of those brands was a Taurus.Â  In comparing the two fired cartridge cases found at the scene, Agent Parnell was able to determine they had been fired from the same firearm.Â  Additionally, in comparing the two fired cartridge cases microscopically to the unfired cartridge found in Haithcockâ€™s home, he concluded from the extractor and ejector and other handling marks that the unfired cartridge had been loaded into and extracted from the same firearm that had fired the two shell casings found at the crime scene.Â  Thus, all three had been loaded into the same gun at some time.Â  Additionally, the two fired cartridge cases and the one unfired cartridge were all the same caliber, manufacturer and brand.Â  
Following the close of the Stateâ€™s case, Haithcock moved for a directed verdict arguing the evidence was insufficient to support the charge against her.Â  The trial court denied the motion finding the evidence, albeit circumstantial, was sufficient to send the case to the jury when considered in the light most favorable to the State.Â  Thereafter, the jury convicted Haithcock of murder, and this appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Haithcock contends the trial court erred in denying her motion for directed verdict based on the evidence presented.Â  She argues there was no evidence of any animosity between her and the victim, the evidence as to the time of the victimâ€™s death was weak and she was only placed at the abandoned house nineteen days before the victimâ€™s body was discovered, there was no evidence placing her inside of the house where the body was found, and the evidence showed the house was a haven for unseemly activity.Â  Additionally, she argues the evidence of the chambered bullet could be explained by the fact that she and the victim had access to each otherâ€™s property, such that the victim could have had her gun at the time of his death, giving access to anyone who had access to him.Â  Accordingly, Haithcock contends the State failed to show substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove her guilt, and the trial court therefore erred in failing to direct a verdict of not guilty.Â  We disagree.
In reviewing the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 270, 531 S.E.2d 512, 514 (2000). Â If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. McCombs, 368 S.C. 489, 493, 629 S.E.2d 361, 363 (2006).Â Â  When a motion for directed verdict is made where the state relies exclusively on circumstantial evidence, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not with its weight.Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 594, 606 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004).Â  Â Â Â Â  
Where the evidence is circumstantial, the trial court has a duty to submit the case to the jury if there is substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which the accusedâ€™s guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Arnold, 361 S.C. 386, 389, 605 S.E2d 529, 531 (2004).Â  â€œUnless there is a total failure of competent evidence as to the charges alleged, refusal by the trial judge to direct a verdict of acquittal is not error.â€Â  Id. Â On the other hand, the trial court should grant a directed verdict motion when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the accused is guilty.Â  Id. at 390, 605 S.E.2d at 531.Â  â€œâ€˜Suspicionâ€™ implies a belief or opinion as to guilt based upon facts or circumstances which do not amount to proof.â€ Â Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478. Â However, the trial court is not required to find that the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypothesis before denying a motion for directed verdict.Â  Id.Â  Rather, our supreme court has â€œrejected the contention that in ruling on a directed verdict motion, the trial judge must grant a directed verdict unless the circumstantial evidence pointed conclusively to the defendantâ€™s guilt, to the exclusion of every other reasonable hypothesis.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
In the instant case, considering the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, the record provides substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove Haithcockâ€™s guilt.Â  Haithcock was identified by two people as the woman who was found outside the same abandoned home where Mr. Coates was found shot, on the exact same day as Mr. Coatesâ€™ disappearance.Â  Not only was she was identified as being present at the scene of the crime around mid-day, she was identified as being seen there some time after darkness on that date by another individual. Â While she gave the story earlier in the day that she had run out of gas and that her boyfriend had had already caught a ride to go bring some back, she was again seen at the location after dark, giving the same story about having run out of gas and her boyfriend catching a ride to go retrieve some.Â  Additionally, she was seen earlier in the day sitting in the driverâ€™s seat of a white Ford Explorer at the abandoned house, the same color and make of car as owned by Mr. Coates.Â  Â She was later observed getting into the driverâ€™s side of the Explorer when she was returned to the car that night after making a phone call. Â The case received media attention on January 24, 2001, and the very next day, Haithcock drove Mr. Coatesâ€™ white Ford Explorer to Charleston and asked her sister for help finding a place to park the car.Â  Finally, there was evidence presented that Haithcock owned a Taurus PT-25 caliber handgun, the same caliber as that used in the murder of Mr. Coates and one of only seven out of hundreds of .25 caliber guns that could have fired the bullets recovered from Mr. Coatesâ€™ body.Â Â  The evidence also showed Haithcock had purchased a magazine clip for a Taurus PT-25 caliber pistol approximately two months before the murder, and a .25 caliber live round of ammunition found in Haithcockâ€™s home was determined to have been chambered in the same firearm that had fired the two shell casings found at the crime scene.Â  As well, the two fired cartridge cases found at the scene and the one unfired cartridge found in Haithcockâ€™s home were all the same caliber, manufacturer and brand.
Given the evidence of (1) Haithcockâ€™s presence at the scene of the crime at two different times on the same day as Mr. Coatesâ€™ disappearance, (2) the fact that she was observed at the scene with the same color and make of car as owned by Mr. Coates, (3) the fact that she was inexplicably seen around mid-day and again after dark, both times claiming to have run out of gas and that her boyfriend had caught a ride to get some gasoline, (4) the fact that she drove Mr. Coatesâ€™ white Ford Explorer to Charleston the day after Mr. Coatesâ€™ body was discovered and the news was disseminated through the media, inferably attempting to hide the vehicle, (5) and the fact that there was gun and bullet evidence possibly linking Haithcock and the weapon and ammunition used to kill Mr. Coates, we find there was substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of Haithcock, and that the case was properly submitted to the jury.
For the foregoing reasons, appellantâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Dutch Fork Development Group II LLC, & Dutch Fork Realty, LLC, Appellants,
        v.
        SEL Properties, LLC & Stephen E. Lipscomb, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-100
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 23, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        M. Turner Pope, Jr., Glenn E. Bowens, and Tony S. Catone, allÂ  of Blythewood, for Appellants.
        Camden Lewis, Keith M. Babcock and Brady R. Thomas, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dutch Fork Development Group II and Dutch Fork Realty (collectively referred to hereinafter as Dutch Fork) appeal the trial courtâ€™s quashing of three notices of lis pendens filed on real estate owned by SEL Properties, LLC.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
In November 2000 and October 2002, Dutch Fork entered into two separate contracts with SEL.Â  Each contract provided Dutch Fork would develop, market, and sell certain real property owned by SEL; the November 2000 contract covers phases I, II, and III of SELâ€™s development, while the October 2002 contract covers phase IV of SELâ€™s development, which encompasses separate property located in close proximity to the original development.Â  Under the terms of the contracts, SEL agreed to pay Dutch Fork certain monthly compensation for the services provided.Â  In addition, the contracts gave Dutch Fork: (1) the exclusive right to sell the developed lots and receive a 10% commission upon closing the sale; and (2) the right to receive 25% of the net profits from the lots sold. Â 
In February 2005, Dutch Fork filed an action against SEL alleging causes of action for breach of contract, conversion, and tortious interference with contract.Â  Thereafter, Dutch Fork filed a lis pendens affecting land owned by SEL in phases I, II, and III on March 4, 2005.Â  Dutch Fork filed a second lis pendens affecting the same property on April 6, 2005.Â  Finally, on April 8, 2005, Dutch Fork filed another lis pendens affecting SEL land in phase IV.Â  
Subsequently, SEL filed this action to â€œQuash Lis Pendens.â€Â  After a hearing, the trial court found the notices of lis pendens did not comply with section 15-11-10 of the South Carolina Code (2005) because the underlying action allegedly giving rise to each lis pendens did not affect title to real property.Â  Thus, the trial court ordered the cancellation of each lis pendens.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Real Property Affected 
Dutch Fork argues the trial court erred in finding each lis pendens does not comply with section 15-11-10.Â  Specifically, Dutch Fork contends the action giving rise to the notices of lis pendens affects real property, and therefore, the trial court erred in granting SELâ€™s motion to quash each lis pendens.Â  We disagree.Â  
In reviewing a lis pendens, courts generally look only to the underlying cause of action to determine whether the action comes within the provisions of the lis pendens statute.Â  54 C.J.S. Lis Pendens Â§ 40 (2005). Â Since the filing of a lis pendens is an extraordinary privilege granted by statute, strict compliance with the statutory provisions is required.Â  Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 17, 567 S.E.2d 881, 889 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Generally, â€œ[t]he lis pendens statute applies to an in rem interest in real estate that affects either the title to the property, or a right to the possession of it.â€Â  51 Am. Jur. 2d Lis Pendens Â§ 19 (2000).Â  â€œ[I]n order to invoke the doctrine of lis pendens, it is not sufficient that a property be the source out of which the plaintiff will be compensated.Â  Rather, the property that is described for the purpose of invoking the doctrine must be at the very essence of the controversy between the litigants.â€Â  Id.
â€œThe purpose of a notice of pendency of an action is to inform a purchaser or encumbrancer that a particular piece of real property is subject to litigation.â€Â  Shelley Constr. Co., v. Sea Garden Homes, Inc., 287 S.C. 24, 30, 336 S.E.2d 488, 491 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  The filing of a lis pendens places a cloud on title and prevents the owner from freely disposing of the property before the litigation is resolved.Â  Id. at 30, 336 S.E.2d at 491-92.Â  
In Pond Place Partners, this court explained the principal reason for allowing the filing of a lis pendens: 

  The lis pendens mechanism is not designed to aid either side in a dispute between private parties. Rather, lis pendens is designed primarily to protect unidentified third parties by alerting prospective purchasers of property as to what is already on public record, i.e., the fact of a suit involving property. Thus, it notifies potential purchasers that there is pending litigation that may affect their title to real property and that the purchaser will take subject to the judgment, without any substantive rights.

351 S.C. at 17, 567 S.E.2d at 889. 
In South Carolina, a lis pendens may be filed â€œ[i]n an action affecting the title to real property.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-11-10 (2005).Â  â€œ[A]n action â€˜affecting the title to real propertyâ€™ clearly allows the filing of a lis pendens by an interested party in order to protect their ownership interest in the property subject to the litigation.â€Â  Pond Place Partners, 351 S.C. at 17, 567 S.E.2d at 889.Â  Such actions include: (1) actions attempting to set aside a fraudulent conveyance of real property; (2) actions to establish a constructive trust over real estate; (3) actions to quiet title; (4) actions to establish the existence of an easement; (5) actions to reform deeds to resolve a boundary dispute; (6) actions for specific performance; and (7) actions for mortgage foreclosure.Â  Id. at 17-18, 567 S.E.2d at 889-90 (citations omitted).
In the lawsuit giving rise to the notices of lis pendens, Dutch Fork only requests actual and punitive damages for injuries stemming from SELâ€™s alleged breach of contract, conversion, and tortious interference with contract.Â  We find Dutch Forkâ€™s underlying action does not affect title to SELâ€™s real property but rather seeks money damages arising from a contractual dispute involving the development of real property.Â  In general, â€œan action for money only, even if it relates in some way to specific real property, will not support a lis pendens.â€Â  54 C.J.S. Lis Pendens Â§ 11 (2005); see also Armstrong v. Carwile, 56 S.C. 463, 476, 35 S.E. 196, 203 (1900) (holding an ordinary action on a money demand that did not in any way affect the title to real estate is not an action in which the filing of a notice of lis pendens is authorized).Â  
Dutch Fork argues the United States District Courtâ€™s analysis of South Carolinaâ€™s lis pendens statute in Finley v. Hughes, 106 F. Supp. 355 (E.D.S.C. 1952), suggests each lis pendens in this action complies with section 15-11-10.Â  In Finley, the court determined an action which referenced real estate and sought, in part, to establish a constructive trust allowed for the filing of a lis pendens because the action affected title to real estate.Â  Id. at 356.Â  In so finding the court held:Â Â Â  

  The doctrine of lis pendens applies to all suits or actions which directly affect real property, and not only those which involve the question of title, but also those which are brought to establish an equitable estate, interest, or right in specific real property or to enforce any lien, charge, or encumbrance against it, there being in some cases a lis pendens, although at the commencement of the suit there is no present vested interest, claim, or lien in or on the property which it seeks to charge.

Â Id. (quoting 54 C.J.S. Lis Pendens Â§ 9).Â  
Even if we adopted the United States District Courtâ€™s interpretation, our analysis in this case is unaffected.Â  Finley is distinguishable from the subject action.Â  In their final issue in their brief, Dutch Fork argues equitable remedies support upholding each lis pendens.Â  Specifically, Dutch Fork argues a constructive trust could be established in its favor which should justify each lis pendens.Â  It also claims its relationship with SEL Properties was essentially a partnership and one of the objectives of this litigation was to settle the interests of the partiesâ€™ in the property. Â Â However, Dutch Fork never actually asserted causes of action for constructive trust or settlement of a partnership.Â  Dutch Fork merely prayed for â€œsuch other relief as [the] Court would deem just and properâ€ in the complaint.Â  Such a broad prayer for relief cannot be considered as the basis for the filing of a lis pendens.Â  SeeÂ  Speizman v. Guill, 202 S.C. 498, 515, Â 25 S.E.2d 731, 739 (1943) (â€œThe prayer is no part of the cause of action.Â  It cannot add anything to or take anything away from the facts pleaded.Â  The prayer is no part of the charging or pleading portion of the complaint, which is the controlling factor in determining what are the ultimate facts alleged.â€).
Thus, Dutch Fork, unlike the plaintiff in Finley, did not seek to establish a constructive trust in the underlying action.Â  Moreover, causes of action for breach of contract, conversion, and/or tortious interference with contract are not brought â€œto establish an equitable estate, interest, or right in specific real property or to enforce any lien, charge, or encumbrance against it.â€Â  Finley, 106 F. Supp. at 356.Â  Thus, even when considering Finley, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the notices of lis pendens do not comply with section 15-11-10.
II.  Effect of Mechanicâ€™s Lien Statute
Dutch Fork contends title to real property is affected by this case because Dutch Fork has an â€œautomaticâ€ lien on the subject property arising from the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (Supp. 2005).Â  We disagree. 
Under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute, â€œany person to whom a debt is due for labor performed or materials furnished in the erection, alteration or repair of a building or structure upon real estate is given a lien on the property to secure payment of the debt.â€Â  Shelley Constr. Co., v. Sea Garden Homes, Inc., 287 S.C. 24, 26, 336 S.E.2d 488, 489 (Ct. App. 1985); Â§ 29-5-10.Â  â€œThe lien arises, inchoate, when the labor is performed or the materials are furnished.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œHowever, to be valid, the lien must be perfected and enforced in compliance with the Mechanicâ€™s Lien Statutes . . . .â€Â  Preferred Sav. & Loan Assn., Inc. v. Royal Garden Resort, Inc., 301 S.C. 1, 3, 389 S.E.2d 853, 854 (1990).Â  In order to perfect and enforce the lien against the property, the person claiming it must: (1) serve and record a certificate of lien within ninety days after he ceases to furnish labor or materials, (2) bring suit to foreclose the lien within six months after he ceases to furnish labor or materials, and (3) file notice of pendency of the action within six months after he ceases to furnish labor or materials.Â  Shelley Constr. Co., 287 S.C. at 27, 336 S.E.2d at 490; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 & -120 (1991 & Supp. 2005). Â As a mechanicâ€™s lien is purely statutory, the requirements of the statute must be strictly followed. Â Muller v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club, 303 S.C. 137, 140, 399 S.E.2d 430, 432 (Ct. App. 1990), overruled on other grounds by Myrtle Beach Hosp., Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 532 S.E.2d 868 (2000).Â Â  
While Dutch Fork may have an inchoate lien on SELâ€™s property,[2] Dutch Fork has not attempted to perfect the lien and, therefore, cannot enforce the lien against the property at this time.Â  Id.Â  Dutch Forkâ€™s alleged inchoate lien cannot support any lis pendens filing because the inchoate lien is not mentioned as a basis for the underlying cause of action.Â  See 54 C.J.S. Lis Pendens Â§ 40 (2005) (stating courts generally look only to the complaint to determine whether the action comes within the provisions of the lis pendens statute); see also, Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 17, 567 S.E.2d 881, 889 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œSince the filing of a lis pendens is an extraordinary privilege granted by statute, strict compliance with the statutory provisions is required.â€).Â  As a result, the alleged inchoate lien cannot be used to justify the filing of any lis pendens.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the trial court did not err in quashing the notices of lis pendens.
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, HUFF, and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.Â  Â 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] We note the determination of whether Dutch Fork may enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien against SELâ€™s properties is not before this court and we make no ruling on the matter.
